verses.textEn: There was a man in the land of Uz named Job, and he was a simple and honest man, fearing God and withdrawing from evil.
verses.textLa: Vir erat in Terra Hus, nomine Iob, et erat vir ille simplex, et rectus, ac timens Deum, et recedens a malo:

verses.textEn: And there had been born to him seven sons and three daughters.
verses.textLa: Natique sunt ei septem filii, et tres filiæ.

verses.textEn: And his possession was seven thousand sheep, and three thousand camels, along with five hundred pairs of oxen and five hundred she-donkeys, and also a very large family. And this man was great among all the people of the east.
verses.textLa: Et fuit possessio eius septem millia ovium, et tria millia camelorum, quingenta quoque iuga boum, et quingentæ asinæ, ac familia multa nimis: eratque vir ille magnus inter omnes Orientales.

verses.textEn: And his sons went and made a feast by houses, each one on his day. And sending, they called their three sisters to eat and drink with them.
verses.textLa: Et ibant filii eius, et faciebant convivium per domos, unusquisque in die suo. Et mittentes vocabant tres sorores suas, ut comederent et biberent cum eis.

verses.textEn: And when the days of their feasting had been completed, Job sent to them and sanctified them, and, getting up at dawn, he offered holocausts for each one. For he said, “Perhaps my sons have sinned and have not praised God in their hearts.” So Job did all the days.
verses.textLa: Cumque in orbem transissent dies convivii, mittebat ad eos Iob, et sanctificabat illos, consurgensque diluculo offerebat holocausta pro singulis. Dicebat enim: Ne forte peccaverint filii mei, et benedixerint Deo in cordibus suis. Sic faciebat Iob cunctis diebus.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘benedixerint Deo’ literally means ‘they have blessed God.’ But the expression ‘bless God’ in ancient times was sometimes used to mean the opposite, as in ‘they have cursed God.’ Job is concerned that his sons may have sinned either by cursing God in their hearts (or attitudes), or by not blessing God. For to refrain from praising God is to curse God.

verses.textEn: But on a certain day, when the sons of God came to attend in the presence of the Lord, Satan also arrived among them.
verses.textLa: Quadam autem die cum venissent filii Dei ut assisterent coram Domino, affuit inter eos etiam Satan.

verses.textEn: The Lord said to him, “Where do you come from?” Answering, he said, “I have circled the land, and walked around in it.”
verses.textLa: Cui dixit Dominus: Unde venis? Qui respondens, ait: Circuivi terram, et perambulavi eam.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to him, “Have you not considered my servant, Job? For there is no one like him in the land, a simple and honest man, fearing God and withdrawing from evil.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Dominus ad eum: Numquid considerasti servum meum Iob, quod non sit ei similis in terra, homo simplex, et rectus ac timens Deum, et recedens a malo?

verses.textEn: Answering him, Satan said, “Does Job fear God to no purpose?
verses.textLa: Cui respondens Satan, ait: Numquid Iob frustra timet Deum?

verses.textEn: Have you not fortified him, as well as his house and every one of his belongings around him, blessed the works of his hands, and his possession has increased in the land?
verses.textLa: nonne tu vallasti eum, ac domum eius, universamque substantiam per circuitum, operibus manuum eius benedixisti, et possessio eius crevit in terra?

verses.textEn: But extend your hand a little, and touch all that he possesses, and see if he still praises you to your face.”
verses.textLa: Sed extende paululum manum tuam, et tange cuncta quæ possidet nisi in faciem benedixerit tibi.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the Lord said to Satan, “Behold, everything that he has is in your hand, only do not extend your hand against him.” And Satan departed from the face of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo Dominus ad Satan: Ecce, universa quæ habet, in manu tua sunt: tantum in eum ne extendas manum tuam. Egressusque est Satan a facie Domini.

verses.textEn: So, on a certain day, when his sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine, in the house of their first-born brother,
verses.textLa: Cum autem quadam die filii et filiæ eius comederent et biberent vinum in domo fratris sui primogeniti,

verses.textEn: a messenger came to Job, who said, “The oxen were plowing, and the donkeys were grazing beside them,
verses.textLa: nuncius venit ad Iob, qui diceret: Boves arabant, et asinæ pascebantur iuxta eos,

verses.textEn: and the Sabeans rushed in and carried away everything, and they struck the servants with the sword; and I alone evaded them to tell you.”
verses.textLa: et irruerunt Sabæi, tuleruntque omnia, et pueros percusserunt gladio, et evasi ego solus ut nunciarem tibi.

verses.textEn: And while he was still speaking, another arrived, and he said, “The fire of God fell from heaven, and, having struck the sheep and the servants, it consumed them; and I alone escaped to tell you.”
verses.textLa: Cumque adhuc ille loqueretur, venit alter, et dixit: Ignis Dei cecidit e cælo, et tactas oves puerosque consumpsit, et effugi ego solus ut nunciarem tibi.

verses.textEn: And while he also was still speaking, another arrived, and he said, “The Chaldeans organized three attacks, and advanced on the camels and took them; and not only that, but they have struck the servants with the sword; and I alone fled to tell you.”
verses.textLa: Sed et illo adhuc loquente, venit alius, et dixit: Chaldæi fecerunt tres turmas, et invaserunt camelos, et tulerunt eos, necnon et pueros percusserunt gladio, et ego fugi solus ut nunciarem tibi.
verses.notes: Blessed Anne Catherine Emmerich interprets the phrase ‘while he was still speaking’ in this passage to mean that, while the previous event was still a topic of conversation for people, the next event occurred. It is not literal, but figurative.

verses.textEn: He was still speaking, and behold, another entered, and he said, “Your sons and daughters were feasting and drinking wine in the house of their first-born brother,
verses.textLa: Adhuc loquebatur ille, et ecce alius intravit, et dixit: Filiis tuis et filiabus vescentibus et bibentibus vinum in domo fratris sui primogeniti,

verses.textEn: when suddenly a severe wind rushed forth from a region of the desert and shook the four corners of the house, which collapsed and crushed your children, and they are dead; and I alone escaped to tell you.”
verses.textLa: repente ventus vehemens irruit a regione deserti, et concussit quattuor angulos domus, quæ corruens oppressit liberos tuos et mortui sunt, et effugi ego solus ut nunciarem tibi.

verses.textEn: Then Job got up and tore his garments, and, having shaved his head, he collapsed on the ground, and worshipped,
verses.textLa: Tunc surrexit Iob, et scidit vestimenta sua, et tonso capite corruens in terram, adoravit,

verses.textEn: and he said, “Naked I departed from my mother’s womb, and naked I shall return. The Lord gave, and the Lord has taken away. Just as it pleased the Lord, so has it been done. Blessed be the name of the Lord.”
verses.textLa: et dixit: Nudus egressus sum de utero matris meæ, et nudus revertar illuc: Dominus dedit, Dominus abstulit: sicut Domino placuit, ita factum est: sit nomen Domini benedictum.

verses.textEn: In all this, Job did not sin by his lips, nor did he speak any foolish thing against God.
verses.textLa: In omnibus his non peccavit Iob labiis suis, neque stultum quid contra Deum locutus est.

verses.textEn: But it happened that, on a certain day, when the sons of God had arrived and they stood before the Lord, Satan likewise arrived among them, and he stood in his sight.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem cum quadam die venissent filii Dei, et starent coram Domino, venisset quoque Satan inter eos, et staret in conspectu eius,

verses.textEn: So the Lord said to Satan, “Where do you come from?” Answering, he said, “I have circled the land, and walked around in it.”
verses.textLa: ut diceret Dominus ad Satan: Unde venis? Qui respondens ait: Circuivi terram, et perambulavi eam.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Satan, “Have you not considered my servant, Job, that there is no one like him in the land, a simple and honest man, fearing God and withdrawing from evil, and still retaining his innocence? Yet you have stirred me against him, so that I would afflict him to no purpose.”
verses.textLa: Et dixit Dominus ad Satan: Numquid considerasti servum meum Iob, quod non sit ei similis in terra, vir simplex et rectus, ac timens Dem, et recedens a malo, et adhuc retinens innocentiam? Tu autem commovisti me adversus eum, ut affligerem eum frustra.

verses.textEn: Answering him, Satan said, “Skin for skin; and everything that a man has, he will give for his life.
verses.textLa: Cui respondens, Satan ait: Pellem pro pelle, et cuncta quæ habet homo, dabit pro anima sua:

verses.textEn: Yet send your hand and touch his bone and his flesh, and then you will see whether or not he blesses you to your face.”
verses.textLa: alioquin mitte manum tuam, et tange os eius et carnem, et tunc videbis quod in faciem benedicat tibi.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the Lord said to Satan, “Behold, he is in your hand, but even so, spare his life.”
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo Dominus ad Satan: Ecce in manu tua est, verumtamen animam illius serva.

verses.textEn: And so, Satan departed from the face of the Lord and he struck Job with a very serious ulcer from the sole of the foot all the way to the crown of his head.
verses.textLa: Egressus igitur Satan a facie Domini, percussit Iob ulcere pessimo, a planta pedis usque ad verticem eius:

verses.textEn: So he took a shard of earthenware and scraped the discharge, while sitting on a heap of refuse.
verses.textLa: qui testa saniem radebat, sedens in sterquilinio.

verses.textEn: But his wife said to him, “Do you still continue in your simplicity? Bless God and die.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem illi uxor sua: Adhuc tu permanes in simplicitate tua? benedic Deo et morere.
verses.notes: Job’s wife says, ‘Bless God,’ but she means, ‘Curse God.’ The expression ‘Curse God’ is so reprehensible to the devout that they would express this idea by saying ‘Bless God,’ not wanting to even speak the word.

verses.textEn: He said to her, “You have spoken like one of the foolish wives. If we accepted good things from the hand of God, why should we not accept bad things?” In all this, Job did not sin with his lips.
verses.textLa: Qui ait ad illam: Quasi una de stultis mulieribus locuta es: si bona suscepimus de manu Dei, mala quare non suscipiamus? in omnibus his non peccavit Iob labiis suis.

verses.textEn: And so, three friends of Job, hearing about all the evil that had befallen him, arrived, each one from his own place, Eliphaz the Themanite, and Baldad the Suhite, and Zophar the Naamathite. For they had agreed to come together to visit and console him.
verses.textLa: Igitur audientes tres amici Iob omne malum, quod accidisset ei, venerunt singuli de loco suo, Eliphaz Themanites, et Baldad Suhites, et Sophar Naamathites. Condixerant enim, ut pariter venientes visitarent eum, et consolarentur.

verses.textEn: And when they had raised up their eyes from a distance, they did not recognize him, and, crying out, they wept, and, tearing their garments, they scattered dust over their heads into the sky.
verses.textLa: Cumque elevassent procul oculos suos, non cognoverunt eum, et exclamantes ploraverunt, scissisque vestibus sparserunt pulverem super caput suum in cælum.

verses.textEn: And they sat with him on the ground for seven days and seven nights, and no one spoke a word to him, for they saw that his sorrow was very great.
verses.textLa: Et sederunt cum eo in terra septem diebus et septem noctibus, et nemo loquebatur ei verbum: videbant enim dolorem esse vehementem.

verses.textEn: After this, Job opened his mouth and cursed his day,
verses.textLa: Post hæc aperuit Iob os suum, et maledixit diei suo,

verses.textEn: and this is what he said:
verses.textLa: et locutus est.

verses.textEn: May the day perish on which I was born, and the night, in which it was said, “A man has been conceived.”
verses.textLa: Pereat dies in qua natus sum, et nox in qua dictum est: Conceptus est homo.

verses.textEn: May that day be turned into darkness, may God not seek it from above, and may light not illuminate it.
verses.textLa: Dies ille vertatur in tenebras, non requirat eum Deus desuper, et non illustretur lumine.

verses.textEn: Let darkness and the shadow of death obscure it, let a fog overtake it, and let it be enveloped in bitterness.
verses.textLa: Obscurent eum tenebræ et umbra mortis, occupet eum caligo, et involvatur amaritudine.

verses.textEn: Let a whirlwind of darkness take hold of that night, let it not be counted in the days of the year, nor numbered in the months.
verses.textLa: Noctem illam tenebrosus turbo possideat, non computetur in diebus anni, nec numeretur in mensibus:

verses.textEn: May that night be alone and unworthy of praise.
verses.textLa: Sit nox illa solitaria, nec laude digna:

verses.textEn: May they curse it, who curse the day, who are prepared to awaken a leviathan.
verses.textLa: Maledicant ei qui maledicunt diei, qui parati sunt suscitare Leviathan:

verses.textEn: Let the stars be concealed with its darkness. Let it expect light, and not see it, nor the rising of the dawn in the East.
verses.textLa: Obtenebrentur stellæ caligine eius: expectet lucem et non videat, nec ortum surgentis auroræ:

verses.textEn: For it did not close the doors of the womb that bore me, nor take away evils from my eyes.
verses.textLa: Quia non conclusit ostia ventris, qui portavit me, nec abstulit mala ab oculis meis.

verses.textEn: Why did I not die in the womb? Having left the womb, why did I not immediately perish?
verses.textLa: Quare non in vulva mortuus sum, egressus ex utero non statim perii?

verses.textEn: Why was I received upon the knees? Why was I suckled at the breasts?
verses.textLa: Quare exceptus genibus? cur lactatus uberibus?

verses.textEn: For by now, I should have been sleeping silently, and taking rest in my sleep
verses.textLa: Nunc enim dormiens silerem, et somno meo requiescerem:

verses.textEn: with the kings and consuls of the earth, who build themselves solitudes,
verses.textLa: Cum regibus et consulibus terræ, qui ædificant sibi solitudines:

verses.textEn: either with princes, who possess gold and fill their houses with silver,
verses.textLa: Aut cum principibus, qui possident aurum, et replent domos suas argento:

verses.textEn: or, like a hidden miscarriage, I should not have continued, just like those who, being conceived, have not seen the light.
verses.textLa: Aut sicut abortivum absconditum non subsisterem, vel qui concepti non viderunt lucem.

verses.textEn: There the impious cease from rebellion, and there the wearied in strength take rest.
verses.textLa: Ibi impii cessaverunt a tumultu, et ibi requieverunt fessi robore.

verses.textEn: And at such times, having been bound together without difficulty, they have not heard the voice of the bailiff.
verses.textLa: Et quondam vincti pariter sine molestia, non audierunt vocem exactoris.
verses.notes: The word ‘exactoris’ can mean bailiff or tax collector (as in a subsequent verse). Since this word is here used metaphorically, it is difficult to say which word would be the best translation. Job is referring to the dead, who do not hear the voice of ... tax collectors and government officials on earth ... or, perhaps, those in charge of their incarceration (in Purgatory?) in the afterlife.

verses.textEn: The small and great are there, and the servant is free from his master.
verses.textLa: Parvus et magnus ibi sunt, et servus liber a domino suo.

verses.textEn: Why is light given to the miserable, and life to those who are in bitterness of soul,
verses.textLa: Quare misero data est lux, et vita his, qui in amaritudine animæ sunt?

verses.textEn: who expect death, and it does not arrive, like those who dig for treasure
verses.textLa: qui expectant mortem, et non venit, quasi effodientes thesaurum:

verses.textEn: and who rejoice greatly when they have found the grave,
verses.textLa: Gaudentque vehementer cum invenerint sepulchrum.

verses.textEn: to a man whose way is hidden and whom God has surrounded with darkness?
verses.textLa: Viro cuius abscondita est via, et circumdedit eum Deus tenebris?

verses.textEn: Before I eat, I sigh; and like overflowing waters, so is my howl,
verses.textLa: Antequam comedam suspiro: et tamquam inundantes aquæ, sic rugitus meus:

verses.textEn: for the terror that I feared has happened to me, and so has the dread befallen me.
verses.textLa: Quia timor, quem timebam, evenit mihi: et quod verebar accidit.

verses.textEn: Have I not remained hidden? Have I not kept silence? Have I not remained calm? Yet indignation has overcome me.
verses.textLa: Nonne dissimulavi? nonne silui? nonne quievi? et venit super me indignatio.

verses.textEn: But Eliphaz the Themanite, answering, said:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Eliphaz Themanites, dixit:

verses.textEn: If we start to speak to you, perhaps you will take it badly, but who can hold back the words he has conceived?
verses.textLa: Si cœperimus loqui tibi, forsitan moleste accipies, sed conceptum sermonem tenere quis poterit?

verses.textEn: Behold, you have taught many, and you have strengthened weary hands.
verses.textLa: Ecce docuisti multos, et manus lassas roborasti:

verses.textEn: Your words have reassured the wavering, and you have fortified the trembling knees.
verses.textLa: Vacillantes confirmaverunt sermones tui, et genua trementia confortasti:

verses.textEn: But now the scourge has overcome you, and you falter. It has touched you, and you are disturbed.
verses.textLa: Nunc autem venit super te plaga, et defecisti: tetigit te, et conturbatus es.

verses.textEn: Where is your reverence, your fortitude, your patience, and the perfection of your ways?
verses.textLa: Ubi est timor tuus, fortitudo tua, patientia tua, et perfectio viarum tuarum?
verses.notes: The word ‘timor’ is usually translated as ‘fear,’ but, in this context, it refers to the reverence or awe for God; i.e. ‘fear of God.’

verses.textEn: Consider this, I beg you: who ever perished being innocent? Or when have the righteous been destroyed?
verses.textLa: Recordare obsecro te, quis umquam innocens periit? aut quando recti deleti sunt?

verses.textEn: In fact, I have instead seen those who work iniquity and who sow resentments, reap them,
verses.textLa: Quin potius vidi eos, qui operantur iniquitatem, et seminant dolores, et metunt eos,

verses.textEn: perishing by the breath of God, and being consumed by the wrath of his spirit.
verses.textLa: Flante Deo perisse, et spiritu iræ eius esse consumptos:

verses.textEn: The roaring of the lion, and the voice of the lioness, and the teeth of young lions have been worn away.
verses.textLa: Rugitus leonis, et vox leænæ, et dentes catulorum leonum contriti sunt.

verses.textEn: The tiger has perished because it does not have prey, and the young lions have been scattered.
verses.textLa: Tigris periit, eo quod non haberet prædam, et catuli leonis dissipati sunt.

verses.textEn: Furthermore, a word was spoken to me in secret, and, as if by theft, my ears received the pulse of its whisper.
verses.textLa: Porro ad me dictum est verbum absconditum, et quasi furtive suscepit auris mea venas susurri eius.

verses.textEn: In the horror of a vision by night, when men are accustomed to be overtaken by a deep sleep,
verses.textLa: In horrore visionis nocturnæ, quando solet sopor occupare homines,

verses.textEn: fear and trembling seized me and all my bones were terrified.
verses.textLa: Pavor tenuit me, et tremor, et omnia ossa mea perterrita sunt:

verses.textEn: And when a spirit passed before me, the hair on my body stood up.
verses.textLa: Et cum spiritus me præsente transiret, inhorruerunt pili carnis meæ.

verses.textEn: There appeared an image before my eyes, someone whose face I did not recognize, and I heard a voice like a gentle breeze.
verses.textLa: Stetit quidam, cuius non agnoscebam vultum, imago coram oculis meis, et vocem quasi auræ lenis audivi.

verses.textEn: Should man be justified in relation to God, or will a man be more pure than his Maker?
verses.textLa: Numquid homo, Dei comparatione iustificabitur, aut Factore suo purior erit vir?

verses.textEn: Behold, those who serve him are not steadfast, and in his angels he finds imperfection.
verses.textLa: Ecce qui serviunt ei, non sunt stabiles, et in angelis suis reperit pravitatem:

verses.textEn: How much more will those who live in houses of clay, which have an earthly foundation, be consumed like the moth?
verses.textLa: Quanto magis hi qui habitant domos luteas, qui terrenum habent fundamentum, consumentur velut a tinea?

verses.textEn: From morning all the way to evening, they will be cut down, and because no one understands, they will be destroyed without ceasing.
verses.textLa: De mane usque ad vesperam succidentur: et quia nullus intelligit, in æternum peribunt.

verses.textEn: But those who are left behind will be taken away from them; they will die, and not in wisdom.
verses.textLa: Qui autem reliqui fuerint, auferentur ex eis: morientur, et non in sapientia.

verses.textEn: Therefore call, if there are any who will respond to you, and turn to one or another of the saints.
verses.textLa: Voca ergo, si est qui tibi respondeat, et ad aliquem sanctorum convertere.

verses.textEn: Truly, anger condemns the foolish to death, and envy kills the petty.
verses.textLa: Vere stultum interficit iracundia, et parvulum occidit invidia.

verses.textEn: I have seen a fool with a strong root, and I have cursed his excellence without hesitation.
verses.textLa: Ego vidi stultum firma radice, et maledixi pulchritudini eius statim.

verses.textEn: His sons will be far from prosperity and will be crushed at the gate, and there will be none who can rescue them.
verses.textLa: Longe fient filii eius a salute, et conterentur in porta, et non erit qui eruat.
verses.notes: The expression ‘crushed at the gate’ may refer to an unfortunate outcome when they are being judged in court, for the ancient equivalent of the court case took place at the gates of the city, where the public could take notice of the event.

verses.textEn: Their harvest, the starving will eat. The armed man will rob him, and the thirsty will drink his resources.
verses.textLa: Cuius messem famelicus comedet, et ipsum rapiet armatus, et bibent sitientes divitias eius.

verses.textEn: Nothing on earth occurs without a reason, and sorrow does not rise from the earth.
verses.textLa: Nihil in terra sine causa fit, et de humo non oritur dolor.

verses.textEn: Man is born to labor, and the bird to fly.
verses.textLa: Homo nascitur ad laborem, et avis ad volatum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, because of this, I will beg the Lord, and place my eloquence before God.
verses.textLa: Quam ob rem ego deprecabor Dominum, et ad Deum ponam eloquium meum:

verses.textEn: He does great and unfathomable and miraculous things without number.
verses.textLa: Qui facit magna et inscrutabilia et mirabilia absque numero:

verses.textEn: He gives rain over the face of the earth and irrigates all things with the waters.
verses.textLa: Qui dat pluviam super faciem terræ, et irrigat aquis universa:

verses.textEn: He places the humble on high and encourages the grieving towards health.
verses.textLa: Qui ponit humiles in sublime, et mœrentes erigit sospitate:

verses.textEn: He dispels the thoughts of the spiteful, lest their hands be able to complete what they had begun.
verses.textLa: Qui dissipat cogitationes malignorum, ne possint implere manus eorum quod cœperant:

verses.textEn: He catches the wise in their cleverness and dissipates the counsel of the perverse.
verses.textLa: Qui apprehendit sapientes in astutia eorum, et consilium pravorum dissipat:

verses.textEn: They will encounter darkness in the daytime, and they will grope at midday just as in the night.
verses.textLa: Per diem incurrent tenebras, et quasi in nocte sic palpabunt in meridie.
verses.notes: This verse refers to the three hours of darkness when Jesus was on the Cross. An eschatolotical interpreation, referring to the Three Days of Darkness is also possible.

verses.textEn: Thereafter, he will act to save the needy from the sword of their mouth, and the poor from the hand of the violent.
verses.textLa: Porro salvum faciet egenum a gladio oris eorum, et de manu violenti pauperem.

verses.textEn: And there will be hope for those in need, for iniquity will diminish its speech.
verses.textLa: Et erit egeno spes, iniquitas autem contrahet os suum.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the man whom God corrects; therefore, do not reject the chastisement of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Beatus homo qui corripitur a Deo: increpationem ergo Domini ne reprobes:

verses.textEn: For he wounds and he cures; he strikes and his hands will heal.
verses.textLa: Quia ipse vulnerat, et medetur: percutit, et manus eius sanabunt.

verses.textEn: He will deliver you into six tribulations, and in the seventh, evil will not touch you.
verses.textLa: In sex tribulationibus liberabit te, et in septima non tangent te malum.
verses.notes: The ‘six tribulations’ could also be translated as ‘six years of tribulation.’ The translation ‘six years’ is a loose translation which favors the meaning of the passage over the literal wording. The six years of tribulation refers to the six plus years of the Antichrist’s reign. In the seventh year of the Antichrist’s reign, he will be defeated; he will not complete the seventh year of his reign. (Compare this translation to the translation, in the book of Daniel, where the text says seventy groups of seven, but the usual translation is seventy weeks of years.)

verses.textEn: During famine, he will rescue you from death, and during war, from the hand of the sword.
verses.textLa: In fame eruet te de morte, et in bello de manu gladii.

verses.textEn: You will be hidden from the scourge of the tongue, and you will not fear calamity when it arrives.
verses.textLa: A flagello linguæ absconderis, et non timebis calamitatem cum venerit.

verses.textEn: In desolation and in famine, you will laugh, and you will not dread the beasts of the earth.
verses.textLa: In vastitate, et fame ridebis, et bestias terræ non formidabis.

verses.textEn: For you are in harmony with the stones of the land, and the beasts of the earth will make peace with you.
verses.textLa: Sed cum lapidibus regionum pactum tuum, et bestiæ terræ pacificæ erunt tibi.

verses.textEn: And you will know that your home has peace, and, concerning your appearance, you will not sin.
verses.textLa: Et scies quod pacem habeat tabernaculum tuum, et visitans speciem tuam, non peccabis.

verses.textEn: Likewise, you will know that your offspring will be manifold and your progeny will be like the grass of the earth.
verses.textLa: Scies quoque quoniam multiplex erit semen tuum, et progenies tua quasi herba terræ.

verses.textEn: You will enter the grave with abundance, just as a crop of wheat is gathered in its time.
verses.textLa: Ingredieris in abundantia sepulchrum, sicut infertur acervus tritici in tempore suo.

verses.textEn: Behold, this is just as we have found it, which you have heard; walk it through your mind.
verses.textLa: Ecce, hoc, ut investigavimus, ita est: quod auditum, mente pertracta.

verses.textEn: But Job, responding, said:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iob, dixit:

verses.textEn: I wish that my sins, for which I deserve wrath, and the calamity that I endure, were weighed out on a balance.
verses.textLa: Utinam appenderentur peccata mea, quibus iram merui: et calamitas, quam patior, in statera.

verses.textEn: Compared to the sand of the sea, they would appear heavier, and so my words are full of sorrow.
verses.textLa: Quasi arena maris hæc gravior appareret: unde et verba mea dolore sunt plena:

verses.textEn: For the arrows of the Lord are in me, my spirit drinks of their indignation, and the terrors of the Lord are soldiers against me.
verses.textLa: Quia sagittæ Domini in me sunt, quarum indignatio ebibit spiritum meum, et terrores Domini militant contra me.

verses.textEn: Will the wild ass bray when he has grass? Or will the ox bellow when he stands before a full manger?
verses.textLa: Numquid rugiet onager cum habuerit herbam? aut mugiet bos cum ante præsepe plenum steterit?
verses.notes: Numquid introduces a questions whose answer is expected to be “no.”

verses.textEn: Or can one eat bland food, which is not seasoned with salt? Or can anyone taste that which, if tasted, causes death?
verses.textLa: Aut poterit comedi insulsum, quod non est sale conditum? aut potest aliquis gustare, quod gustatum affert mortem?

verses.textEn: The things that my soul was unwilling to touch before, now, because of anguish, are my foods.
verses.textLa: Quæ prius nolebat tangere anima mea, nunc præ angustia, cibi mei sunt.

verses.textEn: Who will grant that my petition may arrive and that God may bestow on me what I expect,
verses.textLa: Quis det ut veniat petitio mea: et quod expecto, tribuat mihi Deus?

verses.textEn: and that he who, at first, had crushed me, will let loose his hand and cut me down?
verses.textLa: Et qui cœpit, ipse me conterat: solvat manum suam, et succidat me?

verses.textEn: And may this be my consolation, that in afflicting me with sorrow, although he might not be lenient with me, I still do not contradict the words of the Holy One.
verses.textLa: Et hæc mihi sit consolatio ut affligens me dolore, non parcat, nec contradicam sermonibus Sancti.

verses.textEn: For what is my strength, that I may continue? Or what is my goal, so that I may act patiently?
verses.textLa: Quæ est enim fortitudo mea ut sustineam? aut quis finis meus, ut patienter agam?

verses.textEn: My strength is not the strength of stones, nor is my flesh made of bronze.
verses.textLa: Nec fortitudo lapidum fortitudo mea, nec caro mea ænea est.

verses.textEn: Behold, there is no help for me in myself, and my loved ones also have withdrawn from me.
verses.textLa: Ecce, non est auxilium mihi in me, et necessarii quoque mei recesserunt a me.

verses.textEn: He who takes away mercy from his friend, abandons the fear of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Qui tollit ab amico suo misericordiam, timorem Domini derelinquit.

verses.textEn: My brethren have disregarded me, like a torrent that passes swiftly through the steep valleys.
verses.textLa: Fratres mei præterierunt me, sicut torrens qui raptim transit in convallibus.

verses.textEn: Those who fear frost, snow will rush over them.
verses.textLa: Qui timent pruinam, irruet super eos nix.

verses.textEn: At that time, when they are scattered, they will perish, and when it becomes hot, they will be freed from their place.
verses.textLa: Tempore, quo fuerint dissipati, peribunt: et ut incaluerit, solventur de loco suo.

verses.textEn: The paths of their steps are entangled; they will walk in vain and will perish.
verses.textLa: Involutæ sunt semitæ gressuum eorum: ambulabunt in vacuum, et peribunt.

verses.textEn: Consider the paths of Thema, the ways of Saba, and wait a little while.
verses.textLa: Considerate semitas Thema, itinera Saba, et expectate paulisper.

verses.textEn: They have been thrown into confusion, just as I had hoped; they have even come to me and are overwhelmed with shame.
verses.textLa: Confusi sunt, quia speravi: venerunt quoque usque ad me, et pudore cooperti sunt.

verses.textEn: Now you have arrived, and merely by seeing my affliction, you are afraid.
verses.textLa: Nunc venistis: et modo videntes plagam meam timetis.

verses.textEn: Did I say: “Bring to me and give to me from your necessities?”
verses.textLa: Numquid dixi: Afferte mihi, et de substantia vestra donate mihi?

verses.textEn: or, “Free me from the hand of the enemy and rescue me from the hand of the strong?”
verses.textLa: Vel, Liberate me de manu hostis, et de manu robustorum eruite me?

verses.textEn: Teach me, and I will be silent, and if by chance I have been ignorant of anything, instruct me.
verses.textLa: Docete me, et ego tacebo: et siquid forte ignoravi, instruite me.

verses.textEn: Why have you diminished the words of truth, when there is none of you who is able to offer proof against me?
verses.textLa: Quare detraxistis sermonibus veritatis, cum e vobis nullus sit qui possit arguere me?

verses.textEn: You prepare speeches as so much noise, and you offer words into the wind.
verses.textLa: Ad increpandum tantum eloquia concinnatis, et in ventum verba profertis.

verses.textEn: You encroach upon the orphan, and you strive to undermine your friend.
verses.textLa: Super pupillum irruitis, et subvertere nitimini amicum vestrum.

verses.textEn: Such is true, so finish what you have begun. Listen closely, and see if I lie.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen quod cœpistis explete: præbete aurem, et videte an mentiar.

verses.textEn: Respond, I beg you, without contention, and, speaking what is just, pass judgment.
verses.textLa: Respondete obsecro absque contentione: et loquentes id quod iustum est, iudicate.

verses.textEn: And you will not find iniquity on my tongue, nor will foolishness resound in my throat.
verses.textLa: Et non invenietis in lingua mea iniquitatem, nec in faucibus meis stultitia personabit.

verses.textEn: The life of a man on the earth is a battle, and his days are like the days of a hired hand.
verses.textLa: Militia est vita hominis super terram: et sicut dies mercenarii, dies eius.

verses.textEn: Just as a servant desires the shade, and just as the hired hand looks forward to the end of his work,
verses.textLa: Sicut servus desiderat umbram, et sicut mercenarius præstolatur finem operis sui:

verses.textEn: so also have I had empty months and have counted my burdensome nights.
verses.textLa: Sic et ego habui menses vacuos, et noctes laboriosas enumeravi mihi.

verses.textEn: If I lie down to sleep, I will say, “When will I rise?” And next I will hope for the evening and will be filled with sorrows even until darkness.
verses.textLa: Si dormiero, dicam: Quando consurgam? et rursum expectabo vesperam, et replebor doloribus usque ad tenebras.

verses.textEn: My flesh is clothed with particles of rottenness and filth; my skin is dried up and tightened.
verses.textLa: Induta est caro mea putredine et sordibus pulveris, cutis mea aruit, et contracta est.

verses.textEn: My days have passed by more quickly than threads are cut by a weaver, and they have been consumed without any hope.
verses.textLa: Dies mei velocius transierunt quam a texente tela succiditur, et consumpti sunt absque ulla spe.

verses.textEn: Remember that my life is wind, and my eye will not return to see good things.
verses.textLa: Memento quia ventus est vita mea, et non revertetur oculus meus ut videat bona.

verses.textEn: Neither will the sight of man gaze upon me; your eyes are upon me, and I will not endure.
verses.textLa: Nec aspiciet me visus hominis: oculi tui in me, et non subsistam.

verses.textEn: Just as a cloud is consumed and passes away, so he who descends to hell will not ascend.
verses.textLa: Sicut consumitur nubes, et pertransit: sic qui descenderit ad inferos, non ascendet.
verses.notes: The word ‘infernos’ can mean hell or, more generally, ‘the underworld.’

verses.textEn: He will not return again to his house, nor will his own place know him any longer.
verses.textLa: Nec revertetur ultra in domum suam, neque cognoscet eum amplius locus eius.

verses.textEn: And because of this, I will not restrain my mouth. I will speak in the affliction of my spirit. I will converse from the bitterness of my soul.
verses.textLa: Quapropter et ego non parcam ori meo, loquar in tribulatione spiritus mei: confabulabor cum amaritudine animæ meæ.

verses.textEn: Am I an ocean or a whale, that you have encircled me in a prison?
verses.textLa: Numquid mare ego sum, aut cetus, quia circumdedisti me carcere?

verses.textEn: If I say, “My bed will comfort me, and I will find rest, speaking with myself on my blanket,”
verses.textLa: Si dixero: Consolabitur me lectulus meus, et relevabor loquens mecum in strato meo:

verses.textEn: then you will frighten me with dreams, and strike dread through visions,
verses.textLa: Terrebis me per somnia, et per visiones horrore concuties.

verses.textEn: so that, because of these things, my soul would choose hanging, and my bones, death.
verses.textLa: Quam ob rem elegit suspendium anima mea, et mortem ossa mea.

verses.textEn: I despair; by no means will I live any longer. Spare me, for my days are nothing.
verses.textLa: Desperavi, nequaquam ultra iam vivam: parce mihi, nihil enim sunt dies mei.

verses.textEn: What is man, that you should praise him? Or why do you place your heart near him?
verses.textLa: Quid est homo, quia magnificas eum? aut quid apponis erga eum cor tuum?

verses.textEn: You visit him at dawn, and you test him unexpectedly.
verses.textLa: Visitas eum diluculo, et subito probas illum:

verses.textEn: How long will you not spare me, nor release me to ingest my saliva?
verses.textLa: Usquequo non parcis mihi, nec dimittis me ut glutiam salivam meam?

verses.textEn: I have sinned; what should I do for you, O keeper of men? Why have you set me against you, so that I have become burdensome even to myself?
verses.textLa: Peccavi, quid faciam tibi o custos hominum? quare posuisti me contrarium tibi, et factus sum mihimetipsi gravis?

verses.textEn: Why do you not steal away my sin, and why do you not sweep away my iniquity? Behold, now I will sleep in the dust, and if you seek me in the morning, I will not remain.
verses.textLa: Cur non tollis peccatum meum, et quare non aufers iniquitatem meam? ecce, nunc in pulvere dormiam: et si mane me quæsieris, non subsistam.
verses.notes: Or, ‘why do you not steal away my sin...’ The word ‘tollis’ can also mean to steal. Again, aufers can mean to steal. Job is suggesting that God take away his sin, even if it is not fitting, even if it were analogous to stealing.

verses.textEn: But Baldad the Suhite, responding, said:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Baldad Suhites, dixit:

verses.textEn: How long will you speak this way, so that the words of your mouth are like a changeable wind?
verses.textLa: Usquequo loqueris talia, et spiritus multiplex sermones oris tui?

verses.textEn: Does God supplant judgment, or does the Almighty subvert that which is just?
verses.textLa: Numquid Deus supplantat iudicium? aut Omnipotens subvertit quod iustum est?

verses.textEn: And if now your children have sinned against him, and he has dismissed them into the power of their iniquity,
verses.textLa: Etiam si filii tui peccaverunt ei, et dimisit eos in manu iniquitatis suæ:

verses.textEn: even so, you should arise early to God, so as to beseech the Almighty.
verses.textLa: Tu tamen si diluculo consurrexeris ad Deum, et Omnipotentem fueris deprecatus:

verses.textEn: If you approach with purity and honesty, he will quickly be attentive to you, and a peaceful life will repay your righteousness,
verses.textLa: Si mundus et rectus incesseris, statim evigilabit ad te, et pacatum reddet habitaculum iustitiæ tuæ:

verses.textEn: so much so that, if your former things were small, your latter things would be multiplied greatly.
verses.textLa: In tantum, ut si priora tua fuerint parva, et novissima tua multiplicentur nimis.

verses.textEn: For inquire of the earliest generation, and investigate diligently the history of the fathers,
verses.textLa: Interroga enim generationem pristinam, et diligenter investiga patrum memoriam:

verses.textEn: (of course, we are but of yesterday and are ignorant that our days on earth are like a shadow,)
verses.textLa: (Hesterni quippe sumus, et ignoramus quoniam sicut umbra dies nostri sunt super terram.)

verses.textEn: and they will teach you; they will speak with you and will offer you the eloquence of their hearts.
verses.textLa: Et ipsi docebunt te: loquentur tibi, et de corde suo proferent eloquia.

verses.textEn: Can the marsh plant live without moisture? Or can sedges grow without water?
verses.textLa: Numquid vivere potest scirpus absque humore? aut crescere carectum sine aqua?

verses.textEn: When it is still in flower, and has not been pulled up by hand, it withers before all other plants.
verses.textLa: Cum adhuc sit in flore, nec carpatur manu, ante omnes herbas arescit:

verses.textEn: Just so are the ways of all who forget God, and the hope of the hypocrite will perish.
verses.textLa: Sic viæ omnium, qui obliviscuntur Deum, et spes hypocritæ peribit:

verses.textEn: His frenzy will not please him, and his faith will be like a spider’s web.
verses.textLa: Non ei placebit vecordia sua, et sicut tela aranearum fiducia eius.

verses.textEn: He will lean on his house, and it will not stand; he will prop it up, but it will not rise.
verses.textLa: Innitetur super domum suam, et non stabit: fulciet eam, et non consurget:

verses.textEn: He seems to have moisture before the sun arrives; and at sunrise, his sprout shoots forth.
verses.textLa: Humectus videtur antequam veniat Sol, et in ortu suo germen eius egredietur.

verses.textEn: His roots will crowd together over a heap of stones, and among the stones he will remain.
verses.textLa: Super acervum petrarum radices eius densabuntur, et inter lapides commorabitur.

verses.textEn: If someone is devoured right beside him, he will deny him and will say: “I do not know you.”
verses.textLa: Si absorbuerit eum de loco suo, negabit eum, et dicet: Non novi te.

verses.textEn: For this is the benefit of his way, that others in turn may spring up from the earth.
verses.textLa: Hæc est enim lætitia viæ eius, ut rursum de terra alii germinentur.
verses.notes: Or, ‘this is the happiness of his way.’

verses.textEn: God will not discard the simple, nor will he extend his hand to the spiteful,
verses.textLa: Deus non proiiciet simplicem, nec porriget manum malignis:

verses.textEn: even until your mouth is filled with laughter and your lips with rejoicing.
verses.textLa: Donec impleatur risu os tuum, et labia tua iubilo.

verses.textEn: Those who hate you, will be clothed with confusion, and the tabernacle of the impious will not continue.
verses.textLa: Qui oderunt te, induentur confusione: et tabernaculum impiorum non subsistet.

verses.textEn: And Job, responding, said:
verses.textLa: Et respondens Iob, ait:

verses.textEn: Truly, I know that it is so, and that man cannot be justified compared with God.
verses.textLa: Vere scio quod ita sit, et quod non iustificetur homo compositus Deo.

verses.textEn: If he chooses to contend with him, he is not able to respond to him once out of a thousand times.
verses.textLa: Si voluerit contendere cum eo, non poterit ei respondere unum pro mille.

verses.textEn: He is understanding in heart and mighty in strength; who has resisted him and yet had peace?
verses.textLa: Sapiens corde est, et fortis robore: quis restitit ei, et pacem habuit?

verses.textEn: He has moved mountains, and those whom he overthrew in his fury did not know it.
verses.textLa: Qui transtulit montes, et nescierunt hi quos subvertit in furore suo.

verses.textEn: He shakes the earth out of its place and its pillars tremble.
verses.textLa: Qui commovet terram de loco suo, et columnæ eius concutiuntur.

verses.textEn: He commands the sun and it does not rise, and he closes the stars as if under a seal.
verses.textLa: Qui præcipit Soli, et non oritur: et stellas claudit quasi sub signaculo:

verses.textEn: He alone extends the heavens, and he walks upon the waves of the sea.
verses.textLa: Qui extendit cælos solus, et graditur super fluctus maris.

verses.textEn: He fashions Arcturus, and Orion, and Hyades, and the interior of the south.
verses.textLa: Qui facit Arcturum, et Oriona, et Hyadas, et interiora austri.

verses.textEn: He accomplishes great and incomprehensible and miraculous things, which cannot be numbered.
verses.textLa: Qui facit magna, et incomprehensibilia, et mirabilia, quorum non est numerus.

verses.textEn: If he approaches me, I will not see him; if he departs, I will not understand.
verses.textLa: Si venerit ad me, non videbo eum: si abierit, non intelligam.

verses.textEn: If he suddenly should question, who will answer him? Or who can say, “Why did you do so?”
verses.textLa: Si repente interroget, quis respondebit ei? vel quis dicere potest: Cur ita facis?

verses.textEn: God, whose wrath no one is able to resist, and under whom they bend who carry the world,
verses.textLa: Deus, cuius iræ nemo resistere potest, et sub quo curvantur qui portant orbem.

verses.textEn: what am I then, that I should answer him and exchange words with him?
verses.textLa: Quantus ergo sum ego, ut respondeam ei, et loquar verbis meis cum eo?

verses.textEn: And if I now have any justice, I will not respond, but will beseech my judge.
verses.textLa: Qui etiam si habuero quippiam iustum, non respondebo, sed meum iudicem deprecabor.

verses.textEn: And if he should listen to me when I call, I would not believe that he had heard my voice.
verses.textLa: Et cum invocantem exaudierit me, non credo quod audierit vocem meam.

verses.textEn: For he will crush me in a whirlwind and multiply my wounds, even without cause.
verses.textLa: In turbine enim conteret me, et multiplicabit vulnera mea etiam sine causa.

verses.textEn: He does not permit my spirit to rest, and he fills me with bitterness.
verses.textLa: Non concedit requiescere spiritum meum, et implet me amaritudinibus.

verses.textEn: If strength is sought, he is most strong; if equity in judgment, no one would dare to give testimony for me.
verses.textLa: Si fortitudo quæritur, robustissimus est: si æquitas iudicii, nemo audet pro me testimonium dicere.

verses.textEn: If I wanted to justify myself, my own mouth will condemn me; if I would reveal my innocence, he would prove me depraved.
verses.textLa: Si iustificare me voluero, os meum condemnabit me: si innocentem ostendero, pravum me comprobabit.

verses.textEn: And if I now became simple, my soul would be ignorant even of this, and my life would weary me.
verses.textLa: Etiam si simplex fuero, hoc ipsum ignorabit anima mea, et tædebit me vitæ meæ.

verses.textEn: There is one thing that I have said: both the innocent and the impious he consumes.
verses.textLa: Unum est quod locutus sum, et innocentem et impium ipse consumit.

verses.textEn: If he scourges, let him kill all at once, and not laugh at the punishment of the innocent.
verses.textLa: Si flagellat, occidat semel, et non de pœnis innocentum rideat.

verses.textEn: Since the earth has been given into the hand of the impious, he covers the face of its judges; for if it is not him, then who is it?
verses.textLa: Terra data est in manus impii, vultum iudicum eius operit: quod si non ille est, quis ergo est?

verses.textEn: My days have been swifter than a messenger; they have fled and have not seen goodness.
verses.textLa: Dies mei velociores fuerunt cursore: fugerunt, et non viderunt bonum.

verses.textEn: They have passed by like ships carrying fruits, just like an eagle flying to food.
verses.textLa: Pertransierunt quasi naves poma portantes, sicut aquila volans ad escam.
verses.notes: Ships carrying fruits must travel quickly and without delay, because fruit is perishable.

verses.textEn: If I say: “By no means will I speak this way.” I change my face and I am tortured with sorrow.
verses.textLa: Cum dixero: Nequaquam ita loquar: commuto faciem meam, et dolore torqueor.

verses.textEn: I have dreaded all my works, knowing that you did not spare the offender.
verses.textLa: Verebar omnia opera mea, sciens quod non parceres delinquenti.

verses.textEn: Yet, if I am also just as impious, why have I labored in vain?
verses.textLa: Si autem et sic impius sum, quare frustra laboravi?

verses.textEn: If I had been washed with snow-like waters, and my hands were shining like the cleanest thing,
verses.textLa: Si lotus fuero quasi aquis nivis, et fulserit velut mundissimæ manus meæ:

verses.textEn: yet you would plunge me in filth, and my own garments would abhor me.
verses.textLa: Tamen sordibus intinges me, et abominabuntur me vestimenta mea.

verses.textEn: For even I would not answer a man who were like myself, nor one who could be heard with me equally in judgment.
verses.textLa: Neque enim viro qui similis mei est, respondebo: nec qui mecum in iudicio ex æquo possit audiri.

verses.textEn: There is no one who could both prevail in argument and in placing his hand between the two.
verses.textLa: Non est qui utrumque valeat arguere, et ponere manum suam in ambobus.

verses.textEn: Let him take his staff away from me, and let not the fear of him terrify me.
verses.textLa: Auferat a me virgam suam, et pavor eius non me terreat.

verses.textEn: I will speak and I will not fear him, for in fearfulness I am not able to respond.
verses.textLa: Loquar, et non timebo eum: neque enim possum metuens respondere.

verses.textEn: My soul is weary of my life. I will release my words against myself. I will speak in the bitterness of my soul.
verses.textLa: Tædet animam meam vitæ meæ, dimittam adversum me eloquium meum, loquar in amaritudine animæ meæ.

verses.textEn: I will say to God: Do not be willing to condemn me. Reveal to me why you judge me this way.
verses.textLa: Dicam Deo: Noli me condemnare: indica mihi cur me ita iudices.

verses.textEn: Does it seem good to you, if you find fault with me and oppress me, the work of your own hands, and assist the counsel of the impious?
verses.textLa: Numquid bonum tibi videtur, si calumnieris me, et opprimas me opus manuum tuarum, et consilium impiorum adiuves?

verses.textEn: Do you have bodily eyes? Or, just as man sees, will you see?
verses.textLa: Numquid oculi carnei tibi sunt: aut sicut videt homo, et tu videbis?

verses.textEn: Are your days just like the days of man, and are your years as the times of humans,
verses.textLa: Numquid sicut dies hominis dies tui, et anni tui sicut humana sunt tempora,

verses.textEn: so that you would inquire about my iniquity and examine my sin?
verses.textLa: Ut quæras iniquitatem meam, et peccatum meum scruteris?

verses.textEn: And you know that I have done nothing impious, yet there is no one who can deliver from your hand.
verses.textLa: Et scias quia nihil impium fecerim, cum sit nemo qui de manu tua possit eruere.

verses.textEn: Your hands have made me and formed me all around, and, in this way, do you suddenly throw me away?
verses.textLa: Manus tuæ fecerunt me, et plasmaverunt me totum in circuitu: et sic repente præcipitas me?

verses.textEn: Remember, I ask you, that you have fashioned me like clay, and you will reduce me to dust.
verses.textLa: Memento quæso quod sicut lutum feceris me, et in pulverem reduces me.

verses.textEn: Have you not extracted me like milk and curdled me like cheese?
verses.textLa: Nonne sicut lac mulsisti me, et sicut caseum me coagulasti?

verses.textEn: You have clothed me with skin and flesh. You have put me together with bones and nerves.
verses.textLa: Pelle et carnibus vestisti me: ossibus et nervis compegisti me.

verses.textEn: You have assigned to me life and mercy, and your visitation has preserved my spirit.
verses.textLa: Vitam et misericordiam tribuisti mihi, et visitatio tua custodivit spiritum meum.

verses.textEn: Though you may conceal this in your heart, yet I know that you remember everything.
verses.textLa: Licet hæc celes in corde tuo, tamen scio quia universorum memineris.

verses.textEn: If I have sinned, and you have spared me for an hour, why do you not endure me to be clean from my iniquity?
verses.textLa: Si peccavi, et ad horam pepercisti mihi: cur ab iniquitate mea mundum me esse non pateris?

verses.textEn: And if I should be impious, woe to me, and if I should be just, I will not lift up my head, being drenched with affliction and misery.
verses.textLa: Et si impius fuero, væ mihi est: et si iustus, non levabo caput, saturatus afflictione et miseria.

verses.textEn: And because of pride, you will seize me like a lioness, and having returned, you torment me to an extraordinary degree.
verses.textLa: Et propter superbiam quasi leænam capies me, reversusque mirabiliter me crucias.
verses.notes: The word ‘mirabile’ (upon which the word ‘mirabiliter’ is based) usually is translated as wonders or even miracles. It refers to something extraordinary. Thus, ‘mirabiliter’ means ‘to an extraordinary degree,’ but, when applied to God, it can also imply supernatural intervention. In other words, God sometimes punishes by supernatural means.

verses.textEn: You renew your testimony against me, and you multiply your wrath against me, and these punishments make war within me.
verses.textLa: Instauras testes tuos contra me, et multiplicas iram tuam adversum me, et pœnæ militant in me.

verses.textEn: Why did you lead me out of the womb? If only I had been consumed, so that no eye would ever see me!
verses.textLa: Quare de vulva eduxisti me? qui utinam consumptus essem ne oculus me videret.

verses.textEn: I should have been as if I had not been: transferred from the womb to the tomb.
verses.textLa: Fuissem quasi non essem, de utero translatus ad tumulum.

verses.textEn: Will not my few days be completed soon? Release me, therefore, so that I may lament my sorrows a little,
verses.textLa: Numquid non paucitas dierum meorum finietur brevi? dimitte ergo me, ut plangam paululum dolorem meum:

verses.textEn: before I depart and return no more to a land that is dark and covered with the fog of death,
verses.textLa: Antequam vadam et non revertar, ad terram tenebrosam, et opertam mortis caligine:

verses.textEn: a land of misery and darkness, where the shadow of death, and nothing else but everlasting horror, dwells.
verses.textLa: Terram miseriæ et tenebrarum, ubi umbra mortis, et nullus ordo, sed sempiternus horror inhabitat.

verses.textEn: But Zophar the Naamathite, responding, said:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Sophar Naamathites, dixit:

verses.textEn: Will he who speaks much, not also listen? Or will a talkative man be justified?
verses.textLa: Numquid qui multa loquitur, non et audiet? aut vir verbosus iustificabitur?

verses.textEn: Will men be silent only for you? And when you have mocked others, will no one refute you?
verses.textLa: Tibi soli tacebunt homines? et cum ceteros irriseris, a nullo confutaberis?

verses.textEn: For you said: “My word is pure, and I am clean in your sight.”
verses.textLa: Dixisti enim: Purus est sermo meus, et mundus sum in conspectu tuo.

verses.textEn: Yet I wish that God would speak with you, and would open his lips to you,
verses.textLa: Atque utinam Deus loqueretur tecum, et aperiret labia sua tibi,

verses.textEn: so that he might reveal to you the secrets of wisdom, and how intricate his law is, and that you would understand how much less he requires of you than your iniquity deserves.
verses.textLa: Ut ostenderet tibi secreta sapientiæ, et quod multiplex esset lex eius, et intelligeres quod multo minora exigaris ab eo, quam meretur iniquitas tua.

verses.textEn: By chance, will you comprehend the footsteps of God and reach all the way to the perfection of the Almighty?
verses.textLa: Forsitan vestigia Dei comprehendes, et usque ad perfectum Omnipotentem reperies?

verses.textEn: He is higher than heaven, and what will you do? He is deeper than hell, but how will you know?
verses.textLa: Excelsior cælo est, et quid facies? profundior inferno, et unde cognosces?

verses.textEn: His measure is longer than the earth and wider than the sea.
verses.textLa: Longior terra mensura eius, et latior mari.

verses.textEn: If he overturns all things, or packs them together, who will contradict him?
verses.textLa: Si subverterit omnia, vel in unum coarctaverit, quis contradicet ei?

verses.textEn: For he knows the vanity of men, and when he sees iniquity, does he not evaluate it?
verses.textLa: Ipse enim novit hominum vanitatem, et videns iniquitatem, nonne considerat?

verses.textEn: A vain man is lifted up in arrogance, and he thinks that he is born free like a wild ass’s colt.
verses.textLa: Vir vanus in superbiam erigitur, et tamquam pullum onagri se liberum natum putat.

verses.textEn: But you have fortified your heart and extended your hands to him.
verses.textLa: Tu autem firmasti cor tuum, et expandisti ad eum manus tuas.

verses.textEn: If you would send away from you the iniquity that is in your hand, and not let injustice remain in your tabernacle,
verses.textLa: Si iniquitatem, quæ est in manu tua, abstuleris a te, et non manserit in tabernaculo tuo iniustitia:

verses.textEn: then you would be able to lift up your face without blemish, and you would be steadfast and unafraid.
verses.textLa: Tunc levare poteris faciem tuam absque macula, et eris stabilis, et non timebis.

verses.textEn: Misery, likewise, you would forget, or would remember only like waters that have passed by.
verses.textLa: Miseriæ quoque oblivisceris, et quasi aquarum quæ præterierunt recordaberis.

verses.textEn: And brightness, like that of midday, will rise upon you until evening, and when you would think yourself consumed, you will rise up like the morning star.
verses.textLa: Et quasi meridianus fulgor consurget tibi ad vesperam: et cum te consumptum putaveris, orieris ut lucifer.

verses.textEn: And, when hope has been set before you, you will have faith, and, when buried, you will sleep secure.
verses.textLa: Et habebis fiduciam, proposita tibi spe, et defossus securus dormies.

verses.textEn: You will rest, and there will be nothing to make you afraid, and many will make requests before your face.
verses.textLa: Requiesces, et non erit qui te exterreat: et deprecabuntur faciem tuam plurimi.

verses.textEn: But the eyes of the impious will fade away, and the path to escape will perish before them, for the abomination of the soul is their hope.
verses.textLa: Oculi autem impiorum deficient, et effugium peribit ab eis, et spes illorum abominatio animæ.

verses.textEn: Then Job, answering, said:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iob, dixit:

verses.textEn: Are you, therefore, alone among men, and will wisdom die with you?
verses.textLa: Ergo vos estis soli homines, et vobiscum morietur sapientia?

verses.textEn: And I have a heart just as you also do, and I am not inferior to you. For who is ignorant of these things, which you know?
verses.textLa: Et mihi est cor sicut et vobis, nec inferior vestri sum: quis enim hæc, quæ nostis, ignorat?

verses.textEn: He who is mocked by his friends as I am, will call upon God, and he will listen to him because it is the sincerity of the just that is being mocked.
verses.textLa: Qui deridetur ab amico suo sicut ego, invocabit Deum, et exaudiet eum: deridetur enim iusti simplicitas.

verses.textEn: The lamp that is despised in the thoughts of the rich is ready for the appointed time.
verses.textLa: Lampas contempta apud cogitationes divitum, parata ad tempus statutum.

verses.textEn: The tabernacles of robbers are numerous, and they provoke God boldly; whereas, it is he who has given all things into their hands.
verses.textLa: Abundant tabernacula prædonum, et audacter provocant Deum, cum ipse dederit omnia in manus eorum.

verses.textEn: In truth, ask the mules, and they will teach you, and the birds of the sky, and they will reveal to you.
verses.textLa: Nimirum interroga iumenta, et docebunt te: et volatilia cæli, et indicabunt tibi.

verses.textEn: Speak with the earth, and it will respond to you, and the fish of the sea will explain.
verses.textLa: Loquere terræ, et respondebit tibi: et narrabunt pisces maris.

verses.textEn: Who is ignorant that the hand of the Lord has made all these things?
verses.textLa: Quis ignorat quod omnia hæc manus Domini fecerit?

verses.textEn: In his hand is the soul of all the living and the spirit of all the flesh of mankind.
verses.textLa: In cuius manu anima omnis viventis, et spiritus universæ carnis hominis.

verses.textEn: Does not the ear perceive words, and the palate, when eating, perceive flavor?
verses.textLa: Nonne auris verba diiudicat, et fauces comedentis, saporem?

verses.textEn: In old age is wisdom, and in length of days is prudence.
verses.textLa: In antiquis est sapientia, et in multo tempore prudentia.

verses.textEn: With him is wisdom and strength, he has counsel and understanding.
verses.textLa: Apud ipsum est sapientia et fortitudo, ipse habet consilium et intelligentiam.

verses.textEn: If he tears down, there is no one who can build up; if he encloses a man, there is no one who can open.
verses.textLa: Si destruxerit, nemo est qui ædificet: si incluserit hominem, nullus est qui aperiat.

verses.textEn: If he restrains the waters, everything will dry up; and if he sends them forth, they will subdue the land.
verses.textLa: Si continuerit aquas, omnia siccabuntur: et si emiserit eas, subvertent terram.

verses.textEn: With him is strength and wisdom; he knows both the deceiver and he who is deceived.
verses.textLa: Apud ipsum est fortitudo et sapientia: ipse novit et decipientem, et eum qui decipitur.

verses.textEn: He leads advisors to a foolish end and judges to stupidity.
verses.textLa: Adducit consiliarios in stultum finem, et iudices in stuporem.

verses.textEn: He removes the belt of kings and encircles their waist with a rope.
verses.textLa: Balteum regum dissolvit, et præcingit fune renes eorum.

verses.textEn: He leads away priests in dishonor and displaces nobles,
verses.textLa: Ducit sacerdotes inglorios, et optimates supplantat:

verses.textEn: altering the lips of those who speak the truth and sweeping away the teaching of the aged.
verses.textLa: Commutans labium veracium, et doctrinam senum auferens.

verses.textEn: He pours disdain upon the leaders, relieving those who had been oppressed.
verses.textLa: Effundit despectionem super principes, eos, qui oppressi fuerant, relevans.

verses.textEn: He reveals the depths of the darkness, and he brings the shadow of death into the light.
verses.textLa: Qui revelat profunda de tenebris, et producit in lucem umbram mortis.

verses.textEn: He multiplies peoples, and destroys them, and, having been overthrown, he restores them anew.
verses.textLa: Qui multiplicat gentes et perdit eas, et subversas in integrum restituit.

verses.textEn: He transforms the heart of the leaders of the people on earth, and misleads those who in vain advance upon the inviolable.
verses.textLa: Qui immutat cor principum populi terræ, et decipit eos ut frustra incedant per invium:

verses.textEn: They will grope as in the darkness, not the light, and he will make them stagger like drunkards.
verses.textLa: Palpabunt quasi in tenebris, et non in luce, et errare eos faciet quasi ebrios.

verses.textEn: Behold, my eye has seen all these things, and my ear has heard, and I have understood each one.
verses.textLa: Ecce omnia hæc vidit oculus meus, et audivit auris mea, et intellexi singula.

verses.textEn: In conformity with your knowledge, I also know. I am not inferior to you.
verses.textLa: Secundum scientiam vestram et ego novi: nec inferior vestri sum.

verses.textEn: Yet I speak this way to the Almighty, and I desire to argue with God,
verses.textLa: Sed tamen ad Omnipotentem loquar, et disputare cum Deo cupio:

verses.textEn: having first shown that you fabricate lies and cultivate perverse teachings.
verses.textLa: Prius vos ostendens fabricatores mendacii, et cultores perversorum dogmatum.

verses.textEn: And I wish that you would remain silent, so that you would be counted among the wise.
verses.textLa: Atque utinam taceretis, ut putaremini esse sapientes.

verses.textEn: Therefore, listen to my correction, and pay attention to the judgment of my lips.
verses.textLa: Audite ergo correptionem meam, et iudicium labiorum meorum attendite.

verses.textEn: Does God require your lie, so that you would speak deceitfully for him?
verses.textLa: Numquid Deus indiget vestro mendacio, ut pro illo loquamini dolos?

verses.textEn: Have you taken his place, and do you struggle to give judgment in favor of God?
verses.textLa: Numquid faciem eius accipitis, et pro Deo iudicare nitimini?
verses.notes: Literally, it says ‘Have you received his face....’ But the meaning is better expressed by, ‘Have you taken his place....’

verses.textEn: Or, will it please him, from whom nothing can be concealed? Or, will he be deceived, like a man, by your deceitfulness?
verses.textLa: Aut placebit ei quem celare nihil potest? aut decipietur ut homo, vestris fraudulentiis?

verses.textEn: He will accuse you because in secret you have preempted his presence.
verses.textLa: Ipse vos arguet, quoniam in abscondito faciem eius accipitis.
verses.notes: Similar to verse 13:8, the word ‘faciem,’ usually translated as face or appearance, prefers to the presence of God. In this case the same phrase, ‘faciem eius accipitis,’ is best translated as ‘preempted his presence,’ rather than as ‘taken his place.’ Context is a very important determinant of meaning.

verses.textEn: As soon as he moves himself, he will disturb you, and his dread will fall over you.
verses.textLa: Statim ut se commoverit, turbabit vos, et terror eius irruet super vos.

verses.textEn: Your remembrance will be compared to ashes, and your necks will be reduced to clay.
verses.textLa: Memoria vestra comparabitur cineri, et redigentur in lutum cervices vestræ.
verses.notes: ‘Necks’ is plural because Job is speaking to his three friends, not just to one of them.

verses.textEn: Be silent for a little while, so that I may speak whatever my mind suggests to me.
verses.textLa: Tacete paulisper ut loquar quodcumque mihi mens suggesserit.

verses.textEn: Why do I wound my flesh with my teeth, and carry my soul in my hands?
verses.textLa: Quare lacero carnes meas dentibus meis, et animam meam porto in manibus meis?

verses.textEn: And now, if he would kill me, I will hope in him; in this, truly, I will correct my ways in his sight.
verses.textLa: Etiam si occiderit me, in ipso sperabo: verumtamen vias meas in conspectu eius arguam.

verses.textEn: And he will be my savior, for no hypocrite at all will approach in his sight.
verses.textLa: Et ipse erit salvator meus: non enim veniet in conspectu eius omnis hypocrita.

verses.textEn: Listen to my words, and perceive an enigma with your ears.
verses.textLa: Audite sermonem meum, et ænigmata percipite auribus vestris.

verses.textEn: If I will be judged, I know that I will be found to be just.
verses.textLa: Si fuero iudicatus, scio quod iustus inveniar.

verses.textEn: Who is it that will go to judgment with me? Let him approach. Why should I be consumed in silence?
verses.textLa: Quis est qui iudicetur mecum? veniat: quare tacens consumor?

verses.textEn: Do not do such things to me twice, and then I will not hide from your face.
verses.textLa: Duo tantum ne facias mihi, et tunc a facie tua non abscondar:

verses.textEn: Take your hand far away from me, and do not let your dread terrify me.
verses.textLa: Manum tuam longe fac a me, et formido tua non me terreat.

verses.textEn: Call me, and I will answer you, or else I will speak, and you can answer me.
verses.textLa: Voca me, et ego respondebo tibi: aut certe loquar, et tu responde mihi.

verses.textEn: How many iniquities and sins do I have? Reveal my crimes and offenses to me.
verses.textLa: Quantas habeo iniquitates et peccata, scelera mea et delicta ostende mihi.

verses.textEn: Why do you conceal your face and consider me to be your enemy?
verses.textLa: Cur faciem tuam abscondis, et arbitraris me inimicum tuum?

verses.textEn: Against a leaf, which is carried away by the wind, you reveal your power, and you pursue dry straw.
verses.textLa: Contra folium, quod vento rapitur, ostendis potentiam tuam, et stipulam siccam persequeris:

verses.textEn: For you write bitter things against me, and you want to consume me for the sins of my youth.
verses.textLa: Scribis enim contra me amaritudines, et consumere me vis peccatis adolescentiæ meæ.

verses.textEn: You have put my feet on a tether, and you have observed all my paths, and you have considered the steps of my feet.
verses.textLa: Posuisti in nervo pedem meum, et observasti omnes semitas meas, et vestigia pedum meorum considerasti:
verses.notes: The word ‘pedem’ is singular in Latin, but, when English uses this expression, it is plural.

verses.textEn: I will be left to decay like something rotten and like a garment that is being eaten by moths.
verses.textLa: Qui quasi putredo consumendus sum, et quasi vestimentum quod comeditur a tinea.

verses.textEn: Man, born of woman, living for a short time, is filled with many miseries.
verses.textLa: Homo natus de muliere, brevi vivens tempore, repletur multis miseriis.

verses.textEn: He comes forth like a flower, and is crushed, and he flees, as if a shadow, and never remains in the same state.
verses.textLa: Qui quasi flos egreditur et conteritur, et fugit velut umbra, et numquam in eodem statu permanet.

verses.textEn: And do you consider it fitting to look down with your eyes on someone in this way and to lead him into judgment with you?
verses.textLa: Et dignum ducis super huiuscemodi aperire oculos tuos, et adducere eum tecum in iudicium?

verses.textEn: Who can make him clean who is conceived of unclean seed? Are you not the only one who can?
verses.textLa: Quis potest facere mundum de immundo conceptum semine? nonne tu qui solus es?

verses.textEn: The days of man are short, and the number of his months is with you; you have determined his limits, which cannot be surpassed.
verses.textLa: Breves dies hominis sunt: numerus mensium eius apud te est: constituisti terminos eius, qui præteriri non poterunt.

verses.textEn: Withdraw a little from him, so that he may rest, until his awaited day arrives, like that of the hired hand.
verses.textLa: Recede paululum ab eo, ut quiescat, donec optata veniat, sicut mercenarii, dies eius.

verses.textEn: A tree has hope: if it has been cut, it turns green again, and its branches spring forth.
verses.textLa: Lignum habet spem: si præcisum fuerit, rursum virescit, et rami eius pullulant.

verses.textEn: If its roots grow old in the earth, and its trunk passes into dust,
verses.textLa: Si senuerit in terra radix eius, et in pulvere emortuus fuerit truncus illius,

verses.textEn: at the scent of water, it will sprout and bring forth leaves, as when it had first been planted.
verses.textLa: Ad odorem aquæ germinabit, et faciet comam quasi cum primum plantatum est:

verses.textEn: Truly, when a man dies, and has been left unprotected, and has decayed, I ask you where is he?
verses.textLa: Homo vero cum mortuus fuerit, et nudatus atque consumptus, ubi quæso est?

verses.textEn: It is as if the waters had receded from the sea and an emptied river had dried up;
verses.textLa: Quomodo si recedant aquæ de mari, et fluvius vacuefactus arescat:

verses.textEn: just so, when a man is fallen asleep, he will not rise again, until the heavens are worn away; he will not awaken, nor rise from his sleep.
verses.textLa: Sic homo cum dormierit, non resurget, donec atteratur cælum, non evigilabit, nec consurget de somno suo.

verses.textEn: Who will grant this to me, that you will protect me in the underworld, and hide me until your fury passes by, and establish a time for me, in which you will remember me?
verses.textLa: Quis mihi hoc tribuat, ut in inferno protegas me, et abscondas me, donec pertranseat furor tuus, et constituas mihi tempus, in quo recorderis mei?

verses.textEn: Do you suppose that a dead man will live again? On each of the days in which I now battle, I wait until my transformation occurs.
verses.textLa: Putasne mortuus homo rursum vivat? cunctis diebus, quibus nunc milito, expecto donec veniat immutatio mea.

verses.textEn: You will call me and I will answer you; to the work of your hands, you will extend your right hand.
verses.textLa: Vocabis me, et ego respondebo tibi: operi manuum tuarum porriges dexteram.

verses.textEn: Indeed, you have numbered my steps, but you have been lenient with my sins.
verses.textLa: Tu quidem gressus meos dinumerasti, sed parce peccatis meis.

verses.textEn: You have sealed up my offenses, as if in a purse, but you have cured my iniquity.
verses.textLa: Signasti quasi in sacculo delicta mea, sed curasti iniquitatem meam.

verses.textEn: A falling mountain flows away, and a stone is transferred from its place.
verses.textLa: Mons cadens defluit, et saxum transfertur de loco suo.

verses.textEn: Waters wear away stones, and with a flood the land is reduced little by little; and similarly, you will destroy man.
verses.textLa: Lapides excavant aquæ, et alluvione paulatim terra consumitur: et hominem ergo similiter perdes.

verses.textEn: You have strengthened him for a little while, so that he may cross over into eternity. You will change his face and send him forth.
verses.textLa: Roborasti eum paululum ut in perpetuum transiret: immutabis faciem eius, et emittes eum.

verses.textEn: Whether his sons have been noble or ignoble, he will not understand.
verses.textLa: Sive nobiles fuerint filii eius, sive ignobiles, non intelliget.

verses.textEn: And in this way his body, while he yet lives, will have grief, and his soul will mourn over himself.
verses.textLa: Attamen caro eius dum vivet dolebit, et anima illius super semetipso lugebit.

verses.textEn: But Eliphaz the Themanite, answering, said:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Eliphaz Themanites, dixit:

verses.textEn: Will a wise man answer as if he were speaking wind, and will he fill his stomach with fire?
verses.textLa: Numquid sapiens respondebit quasi ventum loquens, et implebit ardore stomachum suum?

verses.textEn: You rebuke with words he who is not equal to you, and you speak what is not expedient for you,
verses.textLa: Arguis verbis eum, qui non est æqualis tibi, et loqueris quod tibi non expedit.

verses.textEn: to such an extent that, within yourself, you have expelled reverence and have taken away prayers from the presence of God.
verses.textLa: Quantum in te est evacuasti timorem, et tulisti preces coram Deo.
verses.notes: The word ‘timorem’ is usually translated as fear or dread, but in this context it means ‘fear of God’ or ‘reverence.’

verses.textEn: For your iniquity has mislead your mouth, and you imitate the tongue of blasphemers.
verses.textLa: Docuit enim iniquitas tua os tuum, et imitaris linguam blasphemantium.

verses.textEn: Your own mouth will condemn you, not I; and your own lips will answer you.
verses.textLa: Condemnabit te os tuum, et non ego: et labia tua respondebunt tibi.

verses.textEn: Are you the first man who was born, or were you formed before the hills?
verses.textLa: Numquid primus homo tu natus es, et ante colles formatus?

verses.textEn: Have you heard the intentions of God, and will his wisdom be inferior to you?
verses.textLa: Numquid consilium Dei audisti, et inferior te erit eius sapientia?

verses.textEn: What do you know, about which we are ignorant? What do you understand that we do not know?
verses.textLa: Quid nosti quod ignoremus? quid intelligis quod nesciamus?

verses.textEn: There are with us both aged and ancient men, even more senior than your fathers.
verses.textLa: Et senes, et antiqui sunt in nobis multo vetustiores quam patres tui.

verses.textEn: Is it so important that God should console you? But your own depraved words prevent this.
verses.textLa: Numquid grande est ut consoletur te Deus? sed verba tua prava hoc prohibent.

verses.textEn: Why does your heart exalt you, and why do you gaze with your eyes, as if thinking great things?
verses.textLa: Quid te elevat cor tuum, et quasi magna cogitans, attonitos habes oculos?

verses.textEn: Why does your spirit stir against God, so as to utter such speeches from your mouth?
verses.textLa: Quid tumet contra Deum spiritus tuus, ut proferas de ore tuo huiuscemodi sermones?

verses.textEn: What is man that he should be immaculate, and that he should appear just, having been born of woman?
verses.textLa: Quid est homo, ut immaculatus sit, et ut iustus appareat natus de muliere?

verses.textEn: Behold, among his holy ones not one is immutable, and even the heavens are not pure in his sight.
verses.textLa: Ecce inter sanctos eius nemo immutabilis, et cæli non sunt mundi in conspectu eius.

verses.textEn: How much more abominable and useless is the man who drinks as if from the water of iniquity?
verses.textLa: Quanto magis abominabilis et inutilis homo, qui bibit quasi aquam iniquitatem?

verses.textEn: I will reveal to you, so listen to me; and I will explain to you what I have seen.
verses.textLa: Ostendam tibi, audi me: quod vidi narrabo tibi.

verses.textEn: The wise acknowledge, and they do not leave behind, their fathers,
verses.textLa: Sapientes confitentur, et non abscondunt patres suos.

verses.textEn: to whom alone the earth has been given, and no stranger passed among them.
verses.textLa: Quibus solis data est terra, et non transivit alienus per eos.

verses.textEn: The impious is arrogant for all his days, and the number of the years of his tyranny is uncertain.
verses.textLa: Cunctis diebus suis impius superbit, et numerus annorum incertus est tyrannidis eius.

verses.textEn: The sound of terror is always in his ears; and when there is peace, he always suspects treason.
verses.textLa: Sonitus terroris semper in auribus illius: et cum pax sit, ille semper insidias suspicatur.

verses.textEn: He does not believe that it is possible for him to be turned from darkness into the light, for he sees around him the sword on every side.
verses.textLa: Non credit quod reverti possit de tenebris ad lucem, circumspectans undique gladium.

verses.textEn: When he moves himself to seek bread, he knows that the day of darkness has been prepared for his hand.
verses.textLa: Cum se moverit ad quærendum panem, novit quod paratus sit in manu eius tenebrarum dies.

verses.textEn: Tribulation will terrify him, and anguish will prevail over him, like a king who is being prepared to go to battle.
verses.textLa: Terrebit eum tribulatio, et angustia vallabit eum, sicut regem, qui præparatur ad prælium.

verses.textEn: For he has extended his hand against God, and he has strengthened himself against the Almighty.
verses.textLa: Tetendit enim adversus Deum manum suam, et contra Omnipotentem roboratus est.

verses.textEn: He has rushed against him with his throat exposed, and he has been armed with a fat neck.
verses.textLa: Cucurrit adversus eum erecto collo, et pingui cervice armatus est.

verses.textEn: Thickness has covered his face, and lard hangs down from his sides.
verses.textLa: Operuit faciem eius crassitudo, et de lateribus eius arvina dependet.

verses.textEn: He has lived in desolate cities and deserted houses, which have been turned into tombs.
verses.textLa: Habitavit in civitatibus desolatis, et in domibus desertis, quæ in tumulos sunt redactæ.

verses.textEn: He will not be enriched, nor will his basic necessities endure, nor will he establish his root in the earth.
verses.textLa: Non ditabitur, nec perseverabit substantia eius, nec mittet in terra radicem suam.

verses.textEn: He will not withdraw from the darkness; the flame will burn up his branches, and he will be defeated by the breath of his own mouth.
verses.textLa: Non recedet de tenebris: ramos eius arefaciet flamma, et auferetur spiritu oris sui.

verses.textEn: He will not believe, being vainly deceived by error, that he could be redeemed at any price.
verses.textLa: Non credet frustra errore deceptus, quod aliquo pretio redimendus sit.
