verses.textEn: Before his time is completed, he will pass into ruin and his hands will wither away.
verses.textLa: Antequam dies eius impleantur, peribit: et manus eius arescent.

verses.textEn: He will be wounded like a grapevine, when its cluster is in first flower, and like an olive tree that casts off its flower.
verses.textLa: Lædetur quasi vinea in primo flore botrus eius, et quasi oliva proiiciens florem suum.

verses.textEn: For the congregation of the hypocrites is fruitless, and fire will devour the tabernacles of those who love to accept money.
verses.textLa: Congregatio enim hypocritæ sterilis, et ignis devorabit tabernacula eorum, qui munera libenter accipiunt.

verses.textEn: He has conceived sorrow, and he has brought forth iniquity, and his womb prepares deceit.
verses.textLa: Concepit dolorem, et peperit iniquitatem, et uterus eius præparat dolos.

verses.textEn: Then Job, answering, said:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iob, dixit:

verses.textEn: I have often heard such things; you are all aggravating comforters.
verses.textLa: Audivi frequenter talia, consolatores onerosi omnes vos estis.

verses.textEn: Will there be no end to windy words? Or is it at all a burden to you, if you speak?
verses.textLa: Numquid habebunt finem verba ventosa? aut aliquid tibi molestum est si loquaris?

verses.textEn: I, too, can speak like you; and I also wish that your soul favored my soul.
verses.textLa: Poteram et ego similia vestri loqui: atque utinam esset anima vestra pro anima mea:

verses.textEn: I would also comfort you with speeches and would wag my head over you.
verses.textLa: Consolarer et ego vos sermonibus, et moverem caput meum super vos:

verses.textEn: I would strengthen you with my mouth, and would move my lips, as if being lenient to you.
verses.textLa: Roborarem vos ore meo: et moverem labia mea, quasi parcens vobis.

verses.textEn: But what can I do? When I am speaking, my grief will not be quiet; and if I am quiet, it will not withdraw from me.
verses.textLa: Sed quid agam? Si locutus fuero, non quiescet dolor meus: et si tacuero, non recedet a me.

verses.textEn: But now my grief has crushed me, and all my limbs have been reduced to nothing.
verses.textLa: Nunc autem oppressit me dolor meus, et in nihilum redacti sunt omnes artus mei.

verses.textEn: My wrinkles bear witness against me, and a liar rises up against my face, contradicting me.
verses.textLa: Rugæ meæ testimonium dicunt contra me, et suscitatur falsiloquus adversus faciem meam contradicens mihi.

verses.textEn: He has gathered together his fury towards me, and, threatening me, he has roared against me with his teeth; my enemy has beheld me with terrible eyes.
verses.textLa: Collegit furorem suum in me, et comminans mihi, infremuit contra me dentibus suis: hostis meus terribilibus oculis me intuitus est.

verses.textEn: They have opened their mouths against me, and, reproaching me, they have struck me on the cheek; they are nourished by my sufferings.
verses.textLa: Aperuerunt super me ora sua, et exprobrantes percusserunt maxillam meam, saciati sunt pœnis meis.

verses.textEn: God has confined me with the immoral, and he has delivered me into the hands of the impious.
verses.textLa: Conclusit me Deus apud iniquum, et manibus impiorum me tradidit.

verses.textEn: I, who once was wealthy, am now crushed. He has grabbed me by my neck; he has broken me and has placed me before him as a sign.
verses.textLa: Ego ille quondam opulentus repente contritus sum: tenuit cervicem meam, confregit me, et posuit me sibi quasi in signum.

verses.textEn: He has surrounded me with his lances. He has severely wounded my lower back, he has not been lenient, and he has poured out my organs upon the earth.
verses.textLa: Circumdedit me lanceis suis, convulneravit lumbos meos, non pepercit, et effudit in terra viscera mea.

verses.textEn: He has cut me with wound after wound. He has rushed upon me like a giant.
verses.textLa: Concidit me vulnere super vulnus, irruit in me quasi gigas.

verses.textEn: I have sewn sackcloth over my skin, and I have covered my body with ashes.
verses.textLa: Saccum consui super cutem meam, et operui cinere carnem meam.

verses.textEn: My face is swollen from weeping, and my eyelids have dimmed my vision.
verses.textLa: Facies mea intumuit a fletu, et palpebræ meæ caligaverunt.

verses.textEn: These things I have endured without iniquity in my hand, while I held pure prayers before God.
verses.textLa: Hæc passus sum absque iniquitate manus meæ, cum haberem mundas ad Deum preces.

verses.textEn: O earth, do not conceal my blood, nor let my outcry find a hiding place in you.
verses.textLa: Terra ne operias sanguinem meum, neque inveniat in te locum latendi clamor meus.

verses.textEn: For behold, my witness is in heaven, and my confidante is on high.
verses.textLa: Ecce enim in cælo testis meus, et conscius meus in excelsis.

verses.textEn: My friends are full of words; my eye rains tears upon God.
verses.textLa: Verbosi amivi mei: ad Deum stillat oculus meus.

verses.textEn: And I wish that a man might be so judged before God, just as the son of man is judged with his assistant!
verses.textLa: Atque utinam sic iudicaretur vir cum Deo, quomodo iudicatur filius hominis cum collega suo.

verses.textEn: For behold, a few years pass by, and I am walking a path by which I will not return.
verses.textLa: Ecce enim breves anni transeunt, et semitam, per quam non revertar, ambulo.

verses.textEn: My spirit will be wasted, my days will be shortened, and only the grave will be left for me.
verses.textLa: Spiritus meus attenuabitur, dies mei breviabuntur, et solum mihi superest sepulchrum.

verses.textEn: I have not sinned, yet my eye remains in bitterness.
verses.textLa: Non peccavi, et in amaritudinibus moratur oculus meus.

verses.textEn: Free me, O Lord, and set me beside you, and let the hand of anyone you wish fight against me.
verses.textLa: Libera me Dominue, et pone me iuxta te, et cuiusvis manus pugnet contra me.

verses.textEn: You have set their heart far from discipline; therefore, they will not be praised.
verses.textLa: Cor eorum longe fecisti a disciplina, propterea non exaltabuntur.

verses.textEn: He promises prey to his companions, but the eyes of his sons will grow faint.
verses.textLa: Prædam pollicetur sociis, et oculi filiorum eius deficient.

verses.textEn: He has posted me like a proverb to the people, and I am an example in their presence.
verses.textLa: Posuit me quasi in proverbium vulgi, et exemplum sum coram eis.

verses.textEn: My eyesight has been clouded by indignation, and my limbs have been reduced, as if to nothing.
verses.textLa: Caligavit ab indignatione oculus meus, et membra mea quasi in nihilum redacta sunt.

verses.textEn: The just will be astounded over this, and the innocent will be stirred up against the hypocrite.
verses.textLa: Stupebunt iusti super hoc, et innocens contra hypocritam suscitabitur.

verses.textEn: And the just will cling to his way, and clean hands will increase strength.
verses.textLa: Et tenebit iustus viam suam, et mundis manibus addet fortitudinem.

verses.textEn: Therefore, be converted, all of you, and approach, for I do not find in you any wisdom.
verses.textLa: Igitur omnes vos convertimini, et venite, et non inveniam in vobis ullum sapientem.

verses.textEn: My days have passed away; my thoughts have been scattered, tormenting my heart.
verses.textLa: Dies mei transierunt, cogitationes meæ dissipatæ sunt, torquentes cor meum:

verses.textEn: They have turned night into day, and I hope for light again after the darkness.
verses.textLa: Noctem verterunt in diem, et rursum post tenebras spero lucem.

verses.textEn: If I should wait, the underworld is my house, and in darkness I have spread out my bed.
verses.textLa: Si sustinuero, infernus domus mea est, et in tenebris stravi lectulum meum.

verses.textEn: I have said to decay and to worms: “You are my father, my mother, and my sister.”
verses.textLa: Putredini dixi: Pater meus es, mater mea, et soror mea, vermibus.

verses.textEn: Therefore, where is my expectation now, and who is it that considers my patience?
verses.textLa: Ubi est ergo nunc præstolatio mea, et patientiam meam quis considerat?

verses.textEn: Everything of mine will descend into the deepest underworld; do you think that, in that place at least, there will be rest for me?
verses.textLa: In profundissimum infernum descendent omnia mea: putasne saltem ibi erit requies mihi?

verses.textEn: But Baldad the Suhite responded by saying:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Baldad Suhites, dixit:

verses.textEn: How long will you throw around words? Understand first, and then let us speak.
verses.textLa: Usque ad quem finem verba iactabitis? intelligite prius, et sic loquamur.

verses.textEn: Why have we been treated like mules, as if we were unworthy before you?
verses.textLa: Quare reputati sumus ut iumenta, et sorduimus coram vobis?

verses.textEn: You, who ruins your own soul in your fury, will the earth be forsaken because of you, and will the cliffs be moved from their place?
verses.textLa: Qui perdis animam tuam in furore tuo, numquid propter te derelinquetur terra, et transferentur rupes de loco suo?

verses.textEn: Will not the light of the impious be put out, and the flame of his fire refuse to shine?
verses.textLa: Nonne lux impii extinguetur, nec splendebit flamma ignis eius?

verses.textEn: Light will become darkness in his tabernacle, and the lamp that is over him will be extinguished.
verses.textLa: Lux obtenebrescet in tabernaculo illius, et lucerna, quæ super eum est, extinguetur.

verses.textEn: His strong steps will be constrained, and his own counsel will cast him down uncontrollably.
verses.textLa: Arctabuntur gressus virtutis eius, et præcipitabit eum consilium suum.
verses.notes: The word ‘præcipitabit’ means to cast down headlong or in an uncontrollable fashion.

verses.textEn: For he has caused his own feet to go into a net, and he has walked into its web.
verses.textLa: Immisit enim in rete pedes suos, et in maculis eius ambulat.

verses.textEn: His heel will be held in a snare, and thirst will rage against him.
verses.textLa: Tenebitur planta illius laqueo, et exardescet contra eum sitis.

verses.textEn: A trap has been hidden for him in the earth, and a decoy, along his path.
verses.textLa: Abscondita est in terra pedica eius, et decipula illius super semitam.

verses.textEn: Horrifying things will terrify him everywhere and will entangle his feet.
verses.textLa: Undique terrebunt eum formidines, et involvent pedes eius.

verses.textEn: Let his strength be diminished by famine, and let starvation invade his ribs.
verses.textLa: Attenuetur fame robur eius, et inedia invadat costas illius.

verses.textEn: Let it devour the beauty of his skin; let the ancient death consume his arms.
verses.textLa: Devoret pulchritudinem cutis eius, consumat brachia illius primogenita mors.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘primogenita mors’ means ‘first-born death,’ but it has been translated as ‘ancient death’ because the first-born is the eldest son.

verses.textEn: Let his confidence be torn away from his tabernacle, and let ruin trample over him like a king.
verses.textLa: Avellatur de tabernaculo suo fiducia eius, et calcet super eum, quasi rex, interitus.
verses.notes: Here tabernacle can mean tent or house, but it is translated more literally so that the additional possible meaning of a religious house or church can be included in the range of possible meanings.

verses.textEn: Let the companions of he who is not, dwell in his tabernacle; let brimstone rain down upon his tabernacle.
verses.textLa: Habitent in tabernaculo illius socii eius, qui non est, aspergatur in tabernaculo eius sulphur.
verses.notes: The meaning is obscure. It may refer to demons, who are companions of Satan. It may refer to the companions of death, since death is not so much an ‘is’ and an ‘is not.’

verses.textEn: Let his roots be dried up from beneath him, and his harvest be crushed from above.
verses.textLa: Deorsum radices eius siccentur, sursum autem atteratur messis eius.

verses.textEn: Let the memory of him perish from the earth, and let not his name be celebrated in the streets.
verses.textLa: Memoria illius pereat de terra, et non celebretur nomen eius in plateis.

verses.textEn: He will expel him from light into darkness, and he will remove him from the world.
verses.textLa: Expellet eum de luce in tenebras, et de orbe transferet eum.

verses.textEn: Neither his offspring, nor his descendants, will exist among his people, nor will there be any remnants in his country.
verses.textLa: Non erit semen eius, neque progenies in populo suo, nec ullæ reliquiæ in regionibus eius.

verses.textEn: The last will be astonished at his day, and the first will be overcome with horror.
verses.textLa: In die eius stupebunt novissimi, et primos invadet horror.
verses.notes: The word ‘novissimi’ refers to the last to arrive or the newest arrivals. When paired with ‘primos’ it clearly refers to the last as opposed to the first. In other words, the first persons after this time period will be overcome with horror at such evil deeds and horrific events, and the last persons on earth will still know of these things and still be astonished.

verses.textEn: And so, these are the tabernacles of the sinful, and this the place of he who does not know God.
verses.textLa: Hæc sunt ergo tabernacula iniqui, et iste locus eius, qui ignorat Deum.
verses.notes: The word ‘iniqui,’ and similar words in the Bible, tend to be translated by scholars with more extreme terms like wicked or evil-doers, because the scholars don’t want to use words that might apply such passages to themselves. But, truly, each of us is, to one extent or another, a sinner or an impious person. Such passages are not referring only to the extreme case of the most wicked, but to all sinners.

verses.textEn: But Job answered by saying:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iob, dixit:

verses.textEn: How long will you afflict my soul and wear me down with words?
verses.textLa: Usquequo affligitis animam meam, et atteritis me sermonibus?

verses.textEn: So, ten times you confound me and are not ashamed to oppress me.
verses.textLa: En, decies confunditis me, et non erubescitis opprimentes me.

verses.textEn: Now, of course, if I have been ignorant, my ignorance will be with me.
verses.textLa: Nempe, et si ignoravi, mecum erit ignorantia mea.

verses.textEn: But you have risen up against me, and you accuse me to my disgrace.
verses.textLa: At vos contra me erigimini, et arguitis me opprobriis meis.

verses.textEn: At least now you should understand that God has not afflicted me with a balanced judgment, though he has encompassed me with his scourges.
verses.textLa: Saltem nunc intelligite quia Deus non æquo iudicio afflixerit me, et flagellis suis me cinxerit.

verses.textEn: Behold, I will cry out, enduring violence, and no one will hear. I will announce loudly, but there is no one who may judge.
verses.textLa: Ecce clamabo vim patiens, et nemo audiet: vociferabor, et non est qui iudicet.

verses.textEn: He has hemmed in my path, and I cannot pass; he has added darkness to my difficult path.
verses.textLa: Semitam meam circumsepsit, et transire non possum, et in calle meo tenebras posuit.
verses.notes: A looser translation better expresses the meaning of this passage. A ‘calle’ is not any path, but a rough or mountainous path, a difficult path. God has placed or set or added darkness to an already difficult path.

verses.textEn: He has plundered me of my glory, and he has stolen the crown from my head.
verses.textLa: Spoliavit me gloria mea, et abstulit coronam de capite meo.

verses.textEn: He has destroyed me on every side, and I am lost, and, like an uprooted tree, he has taken away my hope.
verses.textLa: Destruxit me undique, et pereo, et quasi evulsæ arbori abstulit spem meam.

verses.textEn: His fury has raged against me, and in this way he has treated me like his enemy.
verses.textLa: Iratus est contra me furor eius, et sic me habuit quasi hostem suum.

verses.textEn: His troops have gathered together, and they have made their way to me, and they have besieged my tabernacle all around.
verses.textLa: Simul venerunt latrones eius, et fecerunt sibi viam per me, et obsederunt in gyro tabernaculum meum.

verses.textEn: He has put my brothers far from me, and my friends have withdrawn from me like strangers.
verses.textLa: Fratres meos longe fecit a me, et noti mei quasi alieni recesserunt a me.

verses.textEn: My kinsmen have forsaken me, and those who knew me, have forgotten me.
verses.textLa: Dereliquerunt me propinqui mei: et qui me noverant, obliti sunt mei.

verses.textEn: The inhabitants of my house and my maidservants treat me just as if I were a stranger, and I have been like a sojourner in their eyes.
verses.textLa: Inquilini domus meæ, et ancillæ meæ sicut alienum habuerunt me, et quasi peregrinus fui in oculis eorum.

verses.textEn: I called my servant, and he did not respond; I pleaded with him with my own mouth.
verses.textLa: Servum meum vocavi, et non respondit, ore proprio deprecabar illum.

verses.textEn: My wife has shuddered at my breath, and I have begged the sons of my loins.
verses.textLa: Halitum meum exhorruit uxor mea, et orabam filios uteri mei.

verses.textEn: Even the foolish have looked down on me, and, when I withdrew from them, they spoke ill of me.
verses.textLa: Stulti quoque despiciebant me, et cum ab eis recessissem, detrahebant mihi.

verses.textEn: Those who were sometimes my counselors, treat me like an abomination; and he whom I valued the most has turned against me.
verses.textLa: Abominati sunt me quondam consiliarii mei: et quem maxime diligebam, aversatus est me.

verses.textEn: Since my flesh has been consumed, my bone adheres to my skin, and only my lips have been left around my teeth.
verses.textLa: Pelli meæ, consumptis carnibus, adhæsit os meum, et derelicta sunt tantummodo labia circa dentes meos.

verses.textEn: Have mercy on me, have compassion on me, at least you my friends, because the hand of the Lord has touched me.
verses.textLa: Miseremini mei, miseremini mei, saltem vos amici mei, quia manus Domini tetigit me.

verses.textEn: Why do you pursue me just as God does, and satiate yourselves with my flesh?
verses.textLa: Quare persequimini me sicut Deus, et carnibus meis saturamini?

verses.textEn: Who will grant to me that my words may be written down? Who will grant to me that they may be inscribed in a book,
verses.textLa: Quis mihi tribuat ut scribantur sermones mei? quis mihi det ut exarentur in libro

verses.textEn: with an iron pen and a plate of lead, or else be carved in stone?
verses.textLa: stylo ferreo, et plumbi lamina, vel celte sculpantur in silice?

verses.textEn: For I know that my Redeemer lives, and on the last day I will rise out of the earth.
verses.textLa: Scio enim quod Redemptor meus vivit, et in novissimo die de terra surrecturus sum:

verses.textEn: And I will be enveloped again with my skin, and in my flesh I will see my God.
verses.textLa: Et rursum circumdabor pelle mea, et in carne mea videbo Deum meum.

verses.textEn: It is he whom I myself will see, and he whom my eyes will behold, and no other. This, my hope, has taken rest in my bosom.
verses.textLa: Quem visurus sum ego ipse, et oculi mei conspecturi sunt, et non alius: reposita est hæc spes mea in sinu meo.

verses.textEn: Why then do you now say: “Let us pursue him, and let us find a basis to speak against him?”
verses.textLa: Quare ergo nunc dicitis: Persequamur eum, et radicem verbi inveniamus contra eum?
verses.notes: The word ‘radicem’ refers to the root of something, but here it is used metaphorically to refer to the basis for finding words to use against someone.

verses.textEn: So then, flee from the face of the sword, for the sword is the avenger of iniquities; but know this: there is to be a judgment.
verses.textLa: Fugite ergo a facie gladii, quoniam ultor iniquitatum gladius est: et scitote esse iudicium.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘et scitote esse iudicium’ literally means ‘and know judgment (is) to be.’ The verb ‘to be’ is implied. The translation is less literal, so that the meaning is clear and the expression sounds better in English: ‘but know this: there is to be a judgment.’ The word ‘et’ is typically translated as ‘and’ but not infrequently can mean ‘also’ or ‘but’ or similar things.

verses.textEn: Then Zophar the Naamathite answered by saying:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Sophar Naamathites, dixit:

verses.textEn: In response, various thoughts succeed one another in me, and my mind moves quickly through different ideas.
verses.textLa: Idcirco cogitationes meæ variæ succedunt sibi, et mens in diversa rapitur.

verses.textEn: The teaching you use to admonish me, I will hear, and the spirit of my understanding will respond for me.
verses.textLa: Doctrinam, qua me arguis, audiam, et spiritus intelligentiæ meæ respondebit mihi.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘spiritus intelligentiæ meæ’ means ‘the spirit of my understanding.’ However, in English, we tend to phrase that idea in this way: ‘my spirit of understanding.’ It could be phrased either way.

verses.textEn: This, I know, is from the beginning, from the time that man was set over the earth:
verses.textLa: Hoc scio a principio, ex quo positus est homo super terram:

verses.textEn: that the praise of the impious shall be short, and the joy of the hypocrite lasts only a moment.
verses.textLa: Quod laus impiorum brevis sit, et gaudium hypocritæ ad instar puncti.

verses.textEn: If his pride ascends even towards the heavens, and his head touches the clouds,
verses.textLa: Si ascenderit usque ad cælum superbia eius, et caput eius nubes tetigerit:

verses.textEn: in the end, he will be destroyed like a trash heap, and those who had seen him will say: “Where is he?”
verses.textLa: Quasi sterquilinium in fine perdetur: et qui eum viderant, dicent: Ubi est?
verses.notes: These two verses refer to the Antichrist, in his attempt at a false ascension to Heaven.

verses.textEn: Like a dream that flies away, he will not be found; he will pass away like a nightmare.
verses.textLa: Velut somnium avolans non invenietur, transiet sicut visio nocturna.

verses.textEn: The eyes that had seen him, will not see him; no longer will his own place admire him.
verses.textLa: Oculus, qui eum viderat, non videbit, neque ultra intuebitur eum locus suus.

verses.textEn: His sons will be worn away by poverty, and his own hands will deliver his grief to him.
verses.textLa: Filii eius atterentur egestate, et manus illius reddent ei dolorem suum.

verses.textEn: His bones will be filled with the vices of his youth, and they will sleep with him in the dust.
verses.textLa: Ossa eius implebuntur vitiis adolescentiæ eius, et cum eo in pulvere dormient.

verses.textEn: For, when evil will be sweet in his mouth, he will hide it under his tongue.
verses.textLa: Cum enim dulce fuerit in ore eius malum, abscondet illud sub lingua sua.

verses.textEn: He will permit it, and not abandon it, and he will conceal it in his throat.
verses.textLa: Parcet illi, et non derelinquet illud, et celabit in gutture suo.

verses.textEn: His bread in his belly will be turned into the venom of snakes within him.
verses.textLa: Panis eius in utero illius vertetur in fel aspidum intrinsecus.

verses.textEn: The riches that he devours, he will vomit up, and from his stomach God will draw them out.
verses.textLa: Divitias, quas devoravit, evomet, et de ventre illius extrahet eas Deus.

verses.textEn: He will suck the head of snakes, and the tongue of the viper will kill him.
verses.textLa: Caput aspidum suget, et occidet eum lingua viperæ.

verses.textEn: (May he never see the streams of the river, the torrents of honey and butter.)
verses.textLa: (Non videat rivulos fluminis, torrentes mellis, et butyri.)

verses.textEn: He will be repaid for all he has done, yet he will not be consumed; according to the multitude of his schemes, so also will he suffer.
verses.textLa: Luet quæ fecit omnia, nec tamen consumetur: iuxta multitudinem adinventionum suarum, sic et sustinebit.

verses.textEn: For, having broken in, he stripped the poor. He has quickly stolen away a house he did not build.
verses.textLa: Quoniam confringens nudavit pauperes: domum rapuit, et non ædificavit eam.

verses.textEn: And yet his stomach will not be satisfied, and when he has the things he desires, he will not be able to possess them.
verses.textLa: Nec est satiatus venter eius: et cum habuerit quæ concupierat, possidere non poterit.

verses.textEn: Nothing remained of his portion, and, because of this, nothing will continue of his kind.
verses.textLa: Non remansit de cibo eius, et propterea nihil permanebit de bonis eius.

verses.textEn: When he will be satisfied, he will be constrained; he will seethe, and all anguish will fall upon him.
verses.textLa: Cum satiatus fuerit, arctabitur, æstuabit, et omnis dolor irruet super eum.

verses.textEn: May his stomach be filled, so that God may send forth the fury of his wrath to him and may rain down his battle upon him.
verses.textLa: Utinam impleatur venter eius, ut emittat in eum iram furoris sui, et pluat super illum bellum suum.

verses.textEn: He will flee from weapons of iron, and he will fall in an arc of brass,
verses.textLa: Fugiet arma ferrea, et irruet in arcum æreum:
verses.notes: This last phrase can also be translated as: ‘will fall in a flying fortress.’ Such a translation implies an eschatological meaning to this passage, a passage which in my view refers to the Antichrist.

verses.textEn: which had been drawn and had issued forth from its sheath, glittering in its bitterness: the horrible ones will go forth and approach over him.
verses.textLa: Eductus, et egrediens de vagina sua, et fulgurans in amaritudine sua: vadent, et venient super eum horribiles.

verses.textEn: All darkness has been hidden in his secrecy. A fire that has not been set will devour him; he will be thrown down and forsaken in his tabernacle.
verses.textLa: Omnes tenebræ absconditæ sunt in occultis eius: devorabit eum ignis, qui non succenditur, affligetur relictus in tabernaculo suo.

verses.textEn: The heavens will reveal his sinfulness, and the earth will rise up against him.
verses.textLa: Revelabunt cæli iniquitatem eius, et terra consurget adversus eum.

verses.textEn: The offspring of his house will be exposed; he will be pulled down in the day of God’s wrath.
verses.textLa: Apertum erit germen domus illius, detrahetur in die furoris Dei.

verses.textEn: This is the portion of a wicked man from God, and the inheritance of his words from the Lord.
verses.textLa: Hæc est pars hominis impii a Deo, et hereditas verborum eius a Domino.

verses.textEn: Then Job responded by saying:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iob, dixit:

verses.textEn: I beseech you to hear my words and to do penance.
verses.textLa: Audite quæso sermones meos, et agite pœnitentiam.

verses.textEn: Permit me, and I will speak, and afterwards, if you see fit, you can laugh at my words.
verses.textLa: Sustinete me, et ego loquar, et post mea, si videbitur, verba ridete.

verses.textEn: Is my dispute against man, so that I would have no reason to be discouraged?
verses.textLa: Numquid contra hominem disputatio mea est, ut merito non debeam contristari?

verses.textEn: Listen to me and be astonished, and place a finger over your mouth.
verses.textLa: Attendite me, et obstupescite, et superponite digitum ori vestro:

verses.textEn: As for me, when I think it over, I am afraid, and trembling convulses my body.
verses.textLa: Et ego quando recordatus fuero, pertimesco, et concutit carnem meam tremor.

verses.textEn: Why then do the impious live, having been lifted up and strengthened with riches?
verses.textLa: Quare ergo impii vivunt, sublevati sunt, confortatique divitiis?

verses.textEn: They see their offspring continue before them: a commotion of close relatives and of children’s children in their sight.
verses.textLa: Semen eorum permanet coram eis, propinquorum turba, et nepotum in conspectu eorum.

verses.textEn: Their houses have been secure and peaceable, and there is no staff of God over them.
verses.textLa: Domus eorum securæ sunt et pacatæ, et non est virga Dei super illos.
verses.notes: The ‘virga Dei super illos’ could refer to the staff of God in the sense of God protecting people, or it could refer to a rod of correction. So, the text has two possible meanings, which affect the translation. It could be translated as: ‘yet there is not staff of God over them.’ In other words, the impious prosper without God’s help. Or, it could be translated as: ‘and there is no rod of God over them,’ meaning that there is no rod of punishment from God hanging over their head.

verses.textEn: Their cattle have conceived and have not miscarried; their cow has given birth and is not deprived of her newborn.
verses.textLa: Bos eorum concepit, et non abortivit: vacca peperit, et non est privata fœtu suo.

verses.textEn: Their little ones go out like a flock, and their children jump around playfully.
verses.textLa: Egrediuntur quasi greges parvuli eorum, et infantes eorum exultant lusibus.

verses.textEn: They take up the timbrel and the lyre, and they rejoice at the sound of the organ.
verses.textLa: Tenent tympanum, et citharam, et gaudent ad sonitum organi.

verses.textEn: Their days are prolonged in wealth, yet, in an instant, they descend into hell.
verses.textLa: Ducunt in bonis dies suos, et in puncto ad inferna descendunt.

verses.textEn: Who has said to God, “Depart from us, for we do not want the knowledge of your ways.
verses.textLa: Qui dixerunt Deo: Recede a nobis, et scientiam viarum tuarum nolumus.

verses.textEn: Who is the Almighty that we should serve him? And how is it helpful to us if we pray to him?”
verses.textLa: Quis est Omnipotens, ut serviamus ei? et quid nobis prodest si oraverimus illum?

verses.textEn: It is true that their good things are not in their power. May the counsel of the impious be far from me!
verses.textLa: Verumtamen quia non sunt in manu eorum bona sua, consilium impiorum longe sit a me.

verses.textEn: How often will the lamp of the wicked be extinguished, and a deluge overtake them, and how often will he distribute the afflictions of his wrath?
verses.textLa: Quoties lucerna impiorum extinguetur, et superveniet eis inundatio, et dolores dividet furoris sui?

verses.textEn: They will be like chaff before the face of the wind, and like ashes that the whirlwind scatters.
verses.textLa: Erunt sicut paleæ ante faciem venti, et sicut favilla quam turbo dispergit.

verses.textEn: God will preserve the grief of the father for his sons, and, when he repays, then he will understand.
verses.textLa: Deus servabit filiis illius dolorem patris: et cum reddiderit, tunc sciet.
verses.notes: The word ‘reddiderit’ can also mean ‘returns.’ When Christ returns, then they will all understand.

verses.textEn: His eyes will see his own destruction, and he will drink from the wrath of the Almighty.
verses.textLa: Videbunt oculi eius interfectionem suam, et de furore Omnipotentis bibet.

verses.textEn: For what does he care what happens to his house after him, or if the number of its months are reduced by half?
verses.textLa: Quid enim ad eum pertinet de domo sua post se? et si numerus mensium eius dimidietur?
verses.notes: The word ‘eius’ in the second part of this verse refers to ‘domo’ (house), not to the individual (an impious person). This is clear because ‘pertinet’ can refer to something that ‘happens,’ can also refer to lengths of time or what happens over a length of time.

verses.textEn: Can anyone teach holy knowledge to God, who judges the exalted?
verses.textLa: Numquid Deus docebit quis piam scientiam, qui excelsos iudicat?

verses.textEn: This one dies strong and healthy, rich and happy.
verses.textLa: Iste moritur robustus et sanus, dives et felix.

verses.textEn: His gut is full of fat and his bones are moistened with marrow.
verses.textLa: Viscera eius plena sunt adipe, et medullis ossa illius irrigantur:

verses.textEn: In truth, another dies in bitterness of soul, without any resources.
verses.textLa: Alius vero moritur in amaritudine animæ absque ullis opibus:

verses.textEn: And yet they will sleep together in the dust, and worms will cover them.
verses.textLa: Et tamen simul in pulvere dormient, et vermes operient eos.

verses.textEn: Surely, I know your thoughts and your sinful judgments against me.
verses.textLa: Certe novi cogitationes vestras, et sententias contra me iniquas.

verses.textEn: For you say, “Where is the house of the ruler, and where are the tabernacles of the impious?”
verses.textLa: Dicitis enim: Ubi est domus principis? et ubi tabernacula impiorum?

verses.textEn: Ask any passerby whom you wish, and you will realize that he understands these same things:
verses.textLa: Interrogate quem libet de viatoribus, et hæc eadem illum intelligere cognoscetis:

verses.textEn: that the evil-doer is reserved for the day of destruction, and he will be led to the day of wrath.
verses.textLa: Quia in diem perditionis servatur malus, et ad diem furoris ducetur.

verses.textEn: Who will reprove his way to his face, and who will repay him for what he has done?
verses.textLa: Quis arguet coram eo viam eius? et quæ fecit, quis reddet illi?

verses.textEn: He will be led to the tomb, and he will remain awake in the chaos of the dead.
verses.textLa: Ipse ad sepulchra ducetur, et in congerie mortuorum vigilabit.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘in congerie mortuorum vigilabit’ could also be translated as ‘he will watch (or wait) in the congregation (or pile or heap) of the dead.’

verses.textEn: He has been found acceptable to the banks of the River of Lamentation, and he will draw any man towards him, and there are countless before him.
verses.textLa: Dulcis fuit glareis Cocyti, et post se omnem hominem trahet, et ante se innumerabiles.
verses.notes: Cocyti is the name of one of the five rivers of Hades; the name means ‘River of Lamentation.’

verses.textEn: Therefore, how long will you console me in vain, when your answer is shown to be repugnant to truth?
verses.textLa: Quomodo igitur consolamini me frustra, cum responsio vestra repugnare ostensa sit veritati?

verses.textEn: Then Eliphaz the Themanite responded by saying:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Eliphaz Themanites, dixit:

verses.textEn: Can man be compared with God, even if he were perfect in knowledge?
verses.textLa: Numquid Deo potest comparari homo, etiam cum perfectæ fuerit scientiæ?

verses.textEn: What advantage is it to God, if you were just? Or what do you provide for him, if your way should be immaculate?
verses.textLa: Qui prodest Deo si iustus fueris? aut quid ei confers si immaculata fuerit via tua?

verses.textEn: Will he reprove you and take you to judgment for being afraid,
verses.textLa: Numquid timens arguet te, et veniet tecum in iudicium,

verses.textEn: and not because of your many evil deeds and your infinite unfairness?
verses.textLa: Et non propter malitiam tuam plurimam, et infinitas iniquitates tuas?

verses.textEn: For you have taken away the collateral of your brothers without cause, and stripped them naked of their clothing.
verses.textLa: Abstulisti enim pignus fratrum tuorum sine causa, et nudos spoliasti vestibus.

verses.textEn: You have not given water to the weary; you have taken bread away from the hungry.
verses.textLa: Aquam lasso non dedisti, et esurienti subtraxisti panem.

verses.textEn: By the strength of your arm, you took possession of the land, and you retain it by being the strongest.
verses.textLa: In fortitudine brachii tui possidebas terram, et potentissimus obtinebas eam.

verses.textEn: You have sent widows away empty, and you have crushed the shoulders of orphans.
verses.textLa: Viduas dimisisti vacuas, et lacertos pupillorum comminuisti.

verses.textEn: Because of this, you are surrounded by traps, and unexpected fears will disturb you.
verses.textLa: Propterea circumdatus es laqueis, et conturbat te formido subita.

verses.textEn: And did you think that you would not see darkness and that you were not to be overwhelmed by the onrush of overflowing waters?
verses.textLa: Et putabas te tenebras non visurum, et impetu aquarum inundantium non oppressum iri?

verses.textEn: Have you not considered that God is higher than the heavens and is lifted above the height of the stars?
verses.textLa: An non cogitas quod Deus excelsior cælo sit, et super stellarum verticem sublimetur?

verses.textEn: And you say: “Well, what does God know?” and, “He judges, as if through a fog,”
verses.textLa: Et dicis: Quid enim novit Deus? et quasi per caliginem iudicat,

verses.textEn: and, “The clouds are his hiding-place,” and, “He does not examine us closely,” and, “He makes his rounds at the limits of the heavens.”
verses.textLa: Nubes latibulum eius, nec nostra considerat, et circa cardines cæli perambulat.

verses.textEn: Do you not want to tend the path of the ages, which wicked men have spurned?
verses.textLa: Numquid semitam sæculorum custodire cupis, quam calcaverunt viri iniqui?

verses.textEn: These were taken away before their time, and a flood overthrew their foundation.
verses.textLa: Qui sublati sunt ante tempus suum, et fluvius subvertit fundamentum eorum:

verses.textEn: They said to God, “Withdraw from us,” and they treated the Almighty as if he could do nothing,
verses.textLa: Qui dicebant Deo: Recede a nobis: et quasi nihil posset facere Omnipotens, æstimabant eum:

verses.textEn: though he had filled their houses with good things. May their way of thinking be far from me.
verses.textLa: Cum ille implesset domos eorum bonis, quorum sententia procul sit a me.

verses.textEn: The just will see and will rejoice, and the innocent will mock them.
verses.textLa: Videbunt iusti, et lætabuntur, et innocens subsannabit eos.

verses.textEn: Has not their haughtiness been cut down, and has not fire devoured the remnants of them?
verses.textLa: Nonne succisa est erectio eorum, et reliquias eorum devoravit ignis?

verses.textEn: So, repose yourself with him and be at peace, and, in this way, you will have the best fruits.
verses.textLa: Acquiesce igitur ei, et habeto pacem: et per hæc habebis fructus optimos.

verses.textEn: Accept the law from his mouth, and place his words in your heart.
verses.textLa: Suscipe ex ore illius legem, et pone sermones eius in corde tuo.

verses.textEn: If you will return to the Almighty, you will be rebuilt, and you will put sinfulness far from your tabernacle.
verses.textLa: Si reversus fueris ad Omnipotentem, ædificaberis, et longe facies iniquitatem a tabernaculo tuo.

verses.textEn: He will give you stone in place of dirt, and torrents of gold in place of stone.
verses.textLa: Dabit pro terra silicem, et pro silice torrentes aureos.

verses.textEn: And the Almighty will be against your enemies, and silver will be gathered together for you.
verses.textLa: Eritque Omnipotens contra hostes tuos, et argentum coacervabitur tibi.

verses.textEn: Then will you flock together in delight over the Almighty, and you will lift up your face to God.
verses.textLa: Tunc super Omnipotentem deliciis afflues, et elevabis ad Deum faciem tuam.

verses.textEn: You will plead with him, and he will listen to you, and you will pay your vows.
verses.textLa: Rogabis eum, et exaudiet te, et vota tua reddes.

verses.textEn: You will decide on something, and it will come to you, and the light will shine in your ways.
verses.textLa: Decernes rem, et veniet tibi, et in viis tuis splendebit lumen.

verses.textEn: For he who had been humbled, will be in glory; and he who will lower his eyes, will be the one saved.
verses.textLa: Qui enim humiliatus fuerit, erit in gloria: et qui inclinaverit oculos, ipse salvabitur.

verses.textEn: The innocent will be saved, and he will be saved with purity in his hands.
verses.textLa: Salvabitur innocens, salvabitur autem in munditia manuum suarum.

verses.textEn: Then Job answered by saying:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iob, ait:

verses.textEn: Now again my conversation is in bitterness, and the force of my scourging weighs more heavily on me because of my mourning.
verses.textLa: Nunc quoque in amaritudine est sermo meus, et manus plagæ meæ aggravata est super gemitum meum.
verses.notes: This last phrase is a figure of speech in Latin. Literally, ‘the hand of my scourging has been made heavier over my mourning.” In other words, Job’s suffering from physical pains is increased because it is on top of his spiritual sorrows. Christ’s suffering on the Cross was likewise increased greatly by the suffering of His soul.

verses.textEn: Who will grant me that I might know and find him, and that I may approach even to his throne?
verses.textLa: Quis mihi tribuat ut cognoscam et inveniam illum, et veniam usque ad solium eius?

verses.textEn: I would place judgment before his eye, and my mouth would fill with criticism,
verses.textLa: Ponam coram eo iudicium, et os meum replebo increpationibus,

verses.textEn: so that I may know the words that he will answer me and understand what he will say to me.
verses.textLa: Ut sciam verba, quæ mihi respondeat, et intelligam quid loquatur mihi.

verses.textEn: I do not want him to contend with me with much strength, nor to overwhelm me with the bulk of his greatness.
verses.textLa: Nolo multa fortitudine contendat mecum, nec magnitudinis suæ mole me premat.

verses.textEn: Let him show fairness in response to me, and let my judgment reach to victory.
verses.textLa: Proponat æquitatem contra me, et perveniat ad victoriam iudicium meum.

verses.textEn: If I go to the east, he does not appear; if I go to the west, I will not understand him.
verses.textLa: Si ad Orientem iero, non apparet: si ad Occidentem, non intelligam eum.

verses.textEn: If I turn to the left, what can I do? I will not take hold of him. If I turn myself to the right, I will not see him.
verses.textLa: Si ad sinistram, quid agam? non apprehendam eum: si me vertam ad dexteram, non videbo illum.

verses.textEn: Truly, he knows my way and has tested me like gold that passes through fire.
verses.textLa: Ipse vero scit viam meam, et probavit me quasi aurum, quod per ignem transit:

verses.textEn: My feet have been following his footsteps; I have kept to his way and have not strayed from it.
verses.textLa: Vestigia eius secutus est pes meus, viam eius custodivi, et non declinavi ex ea.

verses.textEn: I have not withdrawn from the commands of his lips, and the words of his mouth I have hidden in my sinews.
verses.textLa: A mandatis labiorum eius non recessi, et in sinu meo abscondi verba oris eius.

verses.textEn: For he is alone, and no one is able to disturb his intention; and whatever his spirit wills, that he accomplishes.
verses.textLa: Ipse enim solus est, et nemo avertere potest cogitationem eius: et anima eius quodcumque voluit, hoc fecit.

verses.textEn: And when he fulfills his will in me, many other similar ones will also be present with him.
verses.textLa: Cum expleverit in me voluntatem suam, et alia multa similia præsto sunt ei.

verses.textEn: And, for this reason, I have been troubled at his presence, and, when I consider him, I am approached by fear.
verses.textLa: Et idcirco a facie eius turbatus sum, et considerans eum, timore sollicitor.

verses.textEn: God has weakened my heart, and the Almighty has confused me.
verses.textLa: Deus mollivit cor meum, et Omnipotens conturbavit me.

verses.textEn: Yet I have not perished because of the threatening darkness, nor has gloom covered my face.
verses.textLa: Non enim perii propter imminentes tenebras, nec faciem meam operuit caligo.

verses.textEn: The times are not hidden from the Almighty; even those who know him, do not know his days.
verses.textLa: Ab Omnipotente non sunt abscondita tempora: qui autem noverunt eum, ignorant dies illius.

verses.textEn: Some have crossed the boundaries, plundered the flocks, and given them pasture.
verses.textLa: Alii terminos transtulerunt, diripuerunt greges, et paverunt eos.

verses.textEn: They have driven away the donkey of orphans, and have taken the cow from the widow as collateral.
verses.textLa: Asinum pupillorum abegerunt, et abstulerunt pro pignore bovem viduæ.

verses.textEn: They have undermined the way of the poor, and have pressed together the meek of the earth.
verses.textLa: Subverterunt pauperum viam, et oppresserunt pariter mansuetos terræ.

verses.textEn: Others, like wild asses in the desert, go forth to their work; by watching for prey, they obtain bread for their children.
verses.textLa: Alii quasi onagri in deserto egrediuntur ad opus suum: vigilantes ad prædam, præparant panem liberis.

verses.textEn: They reap a field that is not their own, and they harvest a vineyard that they have taken by force.
verses.textLa: Agrum non suum demetunt: et vineam eius, quem vi oppresserint, vindemiant.

verses.textEn: They send men away naked, having taken the clothing of those who have no covering in the cold;
verses.textLa: Nudos dimittunt homines, indumenta tollentes, quibus non est operimentum in frigore:

verses.textEn: these are wet with the mountain rain, and, having no covering, they embrace the rocks.
verses.textLa: Quos imbres montium rigant: et non habentes velamen, amplexantur lapides.

verses.textEn: They have used violence to deprive orphans, and they have robbed the poor common people.
verses.textLa: Vim fecerunt deprædantes pupillos, et vulgum pauperem spoliaverunt.

verses.textEn: From the naked and those who do not have enough clothing, and from the hungry, they have taken away sheaves of grain.
verses.textLa: Nudis et incedentibus absque vestitu, et esurientibus tulerunt spicas.
verses.notes:
The word ‘spicas’ is usually translated as ‘ears of corn.’ However, the Middle East had no maize (called ‘corn’ in the United States) at that time in history. The word ‘spicas’ and the word ‘corn’ refer to grain in general, such as wheat, barley, or flax.
 So, why does this passage complain that the naked as well as the hungry have grain taken away from them? Because clothing was made from flax, a type of grain, which also provided grain for food. This passage complains that they have taken away various types of grain from the poor, including types of grain used for food, and flax which was used for both food and clothing. The word ‘spicas’ is therefore translated as ‘sheaves of grain,’ so as to include the stalks of grain used to make clothing and the various types of grain used for food.

verses.textEn: They take their midday rest among the stockpiles of those who, though they have trodden the winepresses, suffer thirst.
verses.textLa: Inter acervos eorum meridiati sunt, qui calcatis torcularibus sitiunt.

verses.textEn: In the cities, they caused the men to groan and the spirit of the wounded to cry out, and so God does not allow this to go unpunished.
verses.textLa: De civitatibus fecerunt viros gemere, et anima vulneratorum clamavit, et Deus inultum abire non patitur.

verses.textEn: They have been rebellious against the light; they have not known his ways, nor have they returned by his paths.
verses.textLa: Ipsi fuerunt rebelles lumini, nescierunt vias eius, nec reversi sunt per semitas eius.

verses.textEn: The killer of men rises at first light; he executes the destitute and the poor, but, in truth, he is like a thief in the night.
verses.textLa: Mane primo consurgit homicida, interficit egenum et pauperem: per noctem vero erit quasi fur.
verses.notes: The use of the word ‘interficit’ implies that such killings are not the actions of criminals, but of persons with power and authority in society. The word ‘interficit’ is not used for criminal murders, but for executions by authority. This passage calls such persons, who unjustly use authority to cause the deaths of others, ‘homicida’ (killer of men), because this word can refer either to criminal murderers, or to others who kill without breaking the law (such as soldiers in battle). In other words, such persons kill under guise of authority, but are no better than murderers and theives (stealing peoples lives and livelihoods).

verses.textEn: The eye of the adulterer waits for darkness, saying, “No eye will see me,” and he covers his face.
verses.textLa: Oculus adulteri observat caliginem, dicens: Non me videbit oculus: et operiet vultum suum.

verses.textEn: He passes through houses in the nighttime, just as they had agreed among themselves in the daytime; and they are ignorant of the light.
verses.textLa: Perfodit in tenebris domos, sicut in die condixerant sibi, et ignoraverunt lucem.

verses.textEn: If sunrise should suddenly appear, it is treated by them like the shadow of death; and they walk in darkness, as if in light.
verses.textLa: Si subito apparuerit aurora, arbitrantur umbram mortis: et sic in tenebris quasi in luce ambulant.

verses.textEn: He is nimble on the surface of water. His place on land is to be accursed. May he not walk by way of the vineyards.
verses.textLa: Levis est super faciem aquæ: maledicta sit pars eius in terra, nec ambulet per viam vinearum.
verses.notes: The first part of this verse is difficult to understand. The passage talks about evil-doers, such as persons with power who abuse the poor, and murderers, and adulterers. Who is nimble on the surface (or face) of water? Christ walked on water, but this passage is about an evil person. It is about the Antichrist, who will be nimble on the surface of water, and a murderer, and an adulterer, and someone who abuses the poor.

verses.textEn: May he cross from the snowy waters to excessive heat, and his sin, all the way to hell.
verses.textLa: Ad nimium calorem transeat ab aquis nivium, et usque ad inferos peccatum illius.

verses.textEn: Let mercy forget him. His charm is worms. Let him not be remembered, but instead be broken like an unfruitful tree.
verses.textLa: Obliviscatur eius misericordia: dulcedo illius vermes: non sit in recordatione, sed conteratur quasi lignum infructuosum.

verses.textEn: For he has fed on the barren, who does not bear fruit, and he has not done good to the widow.
verses.textLa: Pavit enim sterilem, quæ non parit, et viduæ bene non fecit.

verses.textEn: He has pulled down the strong by his strength, and, when he stands up, he will not have trust in his life.
verses.textLa: Detraxit fortes in fortitudine sua: et cum steterit, non credet vitæ suæ.

verses.textEn: God has given him a place for repentance, and he abuses it with arrogance, but his eyes are upon his ways.
verses.textLa: Dedit ei Deus locum pœnitentiæ, et ille abutitur eo in superbiam: oculi autem eius sunt in viis illius.

verses.textEn: They are lifted up for a little while, but they will not continue, and they will be brought low, just like all things, and they will be taken away, and, like the tops of the ears of grain, they will be crushed.
verses.textLa: Elevati sunt ad modicum, et non subsistent, et humiliabuntur sicut omnia, et auferentur, et sicut summitates spicarum conterentur.

verses.textEn: But, if this is not so, who is able to prove to me that I have lied and to place my words before God?
verses.textLa: Quod si non est ita, quis me potest arguere esse mentitum, et ponere ante Deum verba mea?

verses.textEn: Then Baldad the Suhite answered by saying:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Baldad Suhites, dixit:

verses.textEn: Power and terror are with him that makes a pact with those in high places.
verses.textLa: Potestas et terror apud eum est, qui facit concordiam in sublimibus suis.

verses.textEn: Is there any limit to the number of his soldiers or to the number of those over whom his light rises?
verses.textLa: Numquid est numerus militum eius? et super quem non surget lumen illius?

verses.textEn: Is it right for man to compare himself to God, or to appear pure though he is born of woman?
verses.textLa: Numquid iustificari potest homo comparatus Deo, aut apparere mundus natus de muliere?

verses.textEn: Behold, even the moon is not radiant, and the stars are not pure, in his sight.
verses.textLa: Ecce luna etiam non splendet, et stellæ non sunt mundæ in conspectu eius:

verses.textEn: Is man much more than rottenness and the son of man much more than worms?
verses.textLa: Quanto magis homo putredo, et filius hominis vermis?

verses.textEn: Then Job responded by saying:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iob, dixit:

verses.textEn: Whose assistant are you? Is he weak-minded? And do you sustain the arm of him that is not strong?
verses.textLa: Cuius adiutor es? numquid imbecillis? et sustentas brachium eius, qui non est fortis?

verses.textEn: To whom have you given advice? Perhaps it is to him that has no wisdom or prudence that you have revealed your many ideas.
verses.textLa: Cui dedisti consilium? forsitan illi qui non habet sapientiam, et prudentiam tuam ostendisti plurimam.
verses.notes: Notice that in this verse and others the word ‘et’ is sometimes best translated as ‘or’ rather than as ‘and.’ In Latin, the word ‘et’ is sometimes used where English would favor the word ‘or,’ even though the meaning is the same. Also, notice that ‘plurimam’ means ‘many’ or ‘many things,’ but in this context it is translated as ‘many ideas.’

verses.textEn: Who is it that you wanted to teach? Was it not him that created the breath of life?
verses.textLa: Quem docere voluisti? nonne eum, qui fecit spiramentum?

verses.textEn: Behold, giant things groan under the waters, and they dwell with them.
verses.textLa: Ecce gigantes gemunt sub aquis, et qui habitant cum eis.

verses.textEn: The underworld is naked before him, and there is no covering for perdition.
verses.textLa: Nudus est infernus coram illo, et nullum est operimentum perditioni.

verses.textEn: He stretched out the North over emptiness, and he suspended the land over nothing.
verses.textLa: Qui extendit Aquilonem super vacuum, et appendit terram super nihilum.

verses.textEn: He secures the waters in his clouds, so that they do not burst forth downward all at once.
verses.textLa: Qui ligat aquas in nubibus suis, ut non erumpant pariter deorsum.

verses.textEn: He holds back the face of his throne, and he stretches his cloud over it.
verses.textLa: Qui tenet vultum solii sui, et expandit super illud nebulam suam.

verses.textEn: He has set limits around the waters, until light and darkness shall reach their limit.
verses.textLa: Terminum circumdedit aquis, usque dum finiantur lux et tenebræ.

verses.textEn: The pillars of heaven tremble and are frightened at his nod.
verses.textLa: Columnæ cæli contremiscunt, et pavent ad nutum eius.

verses.textEn: By his strength, the seas suddenly gather together, and his foresight has struck the arrogant.
verses.textLa: In fortitudine illius repente maria congregata sunt, et prudentia eius percussit superbum.

verses.textEn: His spirit has adorned the heavens, and his birthing hand has brought forth the winding serpent.
verses.textLa: Spiritus eius ornavit cælos: et obstetricante manu eius, eductus est coluber tortuosus.

verses.textEn: Behold, these things have been said about his ways in part, and, since we barely have heard a small drop of his word, who will be able to gaze upon the thunder of his greatness?
verses.textLa: Ecce, hæc ex parte dicta sunt viarum eius: et cum vix parvam stillam sermonis eius audierimus, quis poterit tonitruum magnitudinis illius intueri?

verses.textEn: Job also added to this, using figures of speech, and he said:
verses.textLa: Addidit quoque Iob, assumens parabolam suam, et dixit:

verses.textEn: As God lives, who has taken away my judgment, and the Almighty, who has led my soul to bitterness,
verses.textLa: Vivit Deus, qui abstulit iudicium meum, et Omnipotens, qui ad amaritudinem adduxit animam meam,

verses.textEn: as long as my breath remains in me and the breath of God remains in my nostrils,
verses.textLa: Quia donec superest halitus in me, et spiritus Dei in naribus meis,
verses.notes: The phrase ‘intuens locum eius’ could be more literally translated as ‘considering (beholding) his place.’ But the context makes it clear that he is considering his woeful situation, so the translation is less literal and more meaningful.

verses.textEn: my lips will not speak iniquity, nor will my tongue devise lies.
verses.textLa: Non loquentur labia mea iniquitatem, nec lingua mea meditabitur mendacium.

verses.textEn: Far be it from me that I should judge you to be right, for, until I expire, I will not withdraw from my innocence.
verses.textLa: Absit a me ut iustos vos esse iudicem: donec deficiam, non recedam ab innocentia mea.

verses.textEn: I will not forsake my justification, which I have just begun to grasp, for my heart does not find blame for me in my whole life.
verses.textLa: Iustificationem meam, quam cœpi tenere, non deseram: neque enim reprehendit me cor meum in omni vita mea.

verses.textEn: Let the impious be as my enemy, and the sinful, as my adversary.
verses.textLa: Sit ut impius, inimicus meus: et adversarius meus, quasi iniquus.

verses.textEn: For what hope is there for the hypocrite, if he greedily plunders and God does not free his soul?
verses.textLa: Quæ est enim spes hypocritæ si avare rapiat, et non liberet Deus animam eius?

verses.textEn: Will God pay attention to his cry, when anguish overcomes him?
verses.textLa: Numquid Deus audiet clamorem eius cum venerit super eum angustia?

verses.textEn: Or will he take delight in the Almighty and call upon God at all times?
verses.textLa: Aut poterit in Omnipotente delectari, et invocare Deum omni tempore?

verses.textEn: I will teach you through the hand of God, what the Almighty holds, and I will not conceal it.
verses.textLa: Docebo vos per manum Dei quæ Omnipotens habeat, nec abscondam.

verses.textEn: Behold, you know all this, and so why do you speak vain things without a reason?
verses.textLa: Ecce, vos omnes nostis, et quid sine causa vana loquimini?

verses.textEn: This is the portion of the impious man with God, and the inheritance of the violent, which they will receive from the Almighty.
verses.textLa: Hæc est pars hominis impii apud Deum, et hæreditas violentorum, quam ob Omnipotente suscipient.

verses.textEn: If his sons should happen to increase, they will be for the sword, and his grandsons will not be satisfied with bread.
verses.textLa: Si multiplicati fuerint filii eius, in gladio erunt, et nepotes eius non saturabuntur pane.

verses.textEn: Whatever will remain of him will be buried in the ruins, and his widows will not weep.
verses.textLa: Qui reliqui fuerint ex eo, sepelientur in interitu, et viduæ illius non plorabunt.

verses.textEn: If he will amass silver as if it were dirt and fabricate garments as if they were clay,
verses.textLa: Si comportaverit quasi terram argentum, et sicut lutum præparaverit vestimenta:

verses.textEn: then yes, he will gather, but the just will be clothed with it and the innocent will divide the silver.
verses.textLa: Præparabit quidem, sed iustus vestietur illis: et argentum innocens dividet.

verses.textEn: He has built his house like a moth, and he has made a makeshift shelter like a sentry.
verses.textLa: Ædificavit sicut tinea domum suam, et sicut custos fecit umbraculum.

verses.textEn: When he falls asleep, the rich man will leave him with nothing; he will open his eyes and find nothing.
verses.textLa: Dives cum dormierit, nihil secum auferet: aperiet oculos suos, et nihil inveniet.

verses.textEn: Destitution will surround him like water; a storm will overwhelm him in the night.
verses.textLa: Apprehendet eum quasi aqua inopia, nocte opprimet eum tempestas.

verses.textEn: A burning wind will pick him up and carry him away, and, like a whirlwind, it will rush him from his place.
verses.textLa: Tollet eum ventus urens, et auferet, et velut turbo rapiet eum de loco suo.

verses.textEn: And it will hurl over him and will not spare him; fleeing from its power, he will go into exile.
verses.textLa: Et mittet super eum, et non parcet: de manu eius fugiens fugiet.

verses.textEn: He will clasp his hands over himself, and he will hiss at himself, while considering his situation.
verses.textLa: Stringet super eum manus suas, et sibilabit super illum, intuens locum eius.

verses.textEn: Silver has its fissures where it is first found, and gold has a place where it is melted.
verses.textLa: Habet argentum, venarum suarum principia: et auro locus est, in quo conflatur.

verses.textEn: Iron is taken from the earth, and ore, unbound by heat, is turned into brass.
verses.textLa: Ferrum de terra tollitur: et lapis solutus calore, in æs vertitur.

verses.textEn: He has established a time for darkness, and he has settled on an end for all things, as well as for the stone that is in the gloom and shadow of death.
verses.textLa: Tempus posuit tenebris, et universorum finem ipse considerat, lapidem quoque caliginis, et umbram mortis.

verses.textEn: The burning separates a pilgrim people from those who have been forgotten by the feet of the destitute man and from the unapproachable.
verses.textLa: Dividit torrens a populo peregrinante, eos, quos oblitus est pes egentis hominis, et invios.
verses.notes: The word ‘torrens’ can be translated as ‘burning’ or as ‘torrent,’ but the context seems to refer to Hell, so ‘the burning’ is the translation. This verse refers to the dead, not just any dead, but those so forgotten by mankind that their graves are unknown and the wandering destitute man’s feet walks over their grave unknowingly. It also refers to the unapproachable, that is, to those who are in Hell. These are separated from the people of God, a pilgrim people, who are traveling towards God.

verses.textEn: The land, where bread appeared in its place, has been destroyed by fire.
verses.textLa: Terra, de qua oriebatur panis in loco suo, igni subversa est.
verses.notes: Context is very important to any translation. Here the context is the manna in the desert, that is, the bread which appeared in its place.

verses.textEn: Its stones are embedded with sapphires, and its soil, with gold.
verses.textLa: Locus sapphiri lapides eius, et glebæ illius aurum.

verses.textEn: The bird does not know its path, nor has the eye of the vulture beheld it.
verses.textLa: Semitam ignoravit avis, nec intuitus est eam oculus vulturis.

verses.textEn: The sons of merchants have not walked there, nor has the lioness traveled through it.
verses.textLa: Non calcaverunt eam filii institorum, nec pertransivit per eam leæna.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘filii institorum’ refers not to mere children of shopkeepers or merchants, but to the sons of the merchants, in other words, to their apprentices or trainees (which would usually be sons or other younger male relatives). These sons of merchants would be given the task of traveling to various places on business, i.e. running errands. Even these sons, who travel a great deal, have not heard of such a place.

verses.textEn: He has stretched out his hand to the rocks; he has overturned the foundations of the mountains.
verses.textLa: Ad silicem extendit manum suam, subvertit a radicibus montes.

verses.textEn: He has cut rivers through the rocks, and his eye has seen all precious things.
verses.textLa: In petris rivos excidit, et omne pretiosum vidit oculus eius.

verses.textEn: The depths of rivers he has also examined, and he has brought hidden things into the light.
verses.textLa: Profunda quoque fluviorum scrutatus est, et abscondita in lucem produxit.

verses.textEn: But, in truth, where is wisdom to be found, and where is the place of understanding?
verses.textLa: Sapientia vero ubi invenitur? et quis est locus intelligentiæ?

verses.textEn: Man does not know its price, nor is it found in the land of those who live in sweetness.
verses.textLa: Nescit homo pretium eius, nec invenitur in terra suaviter viventium.

verses.textEn: The abyss declares, “It is not in me.” And the sea says, “It is not with me.”
verses.textLa: Abyssus dicit: Non est in me: et mare loquitur: Non est mecum.

verses.textEn: The finest gold will not be paid for it, nor will silver be weighed in exchange for it.
verses.textLa: Non dabitur aurum obrizum pro ea, nec appendetur argentum in commutatione eius.

verses.textEn: It will not be compared with the dyed colors of India, nor with the very costly stone sardonyx, nor with the sapphire.
verses.textLa: Non conferetur tinctis Indiæ coloribus, nec lapidi sardonycho pretiosissimo, vel sapphiro.

verses.textEn: Neither gold nor crystal will be its equal; neither will vessels of gold be fitted for it.
verses.textLa: Non adæquabitur ei aurum vel vitrum, nec commutabuntur pro ea vasa auri:

verses.textEn: The exalted and the eminent will not be remembered in comparison with it. Yet wisdom is drawn out of concealment.
verses.textLa: Excelsa et eminentia non memorabuntur comparatione eius: trahitur autem sapientia de occultis.

verses.textEn: The topaz of Ethiopia will not be equal to it, nor will it be compared to the purest dyes.
verses.textLa: Non adæquabitur ei topazius de Æthiopia, nec tincturæ mundissimæ componetur.

verses.textEn: So then, where does wisdom begin, and where is the place of understanding?
verses.textLa: Unde ergo sapientia venit? et quis est locus intelligentiæ?

verses.textEn: It has been hidden from the eyes of all living things, just as the birds of the heavens escape notice.
verses.textLa: Abscondita est ab oculis omnium viventium, volucres quoque cæli latet.
verses.notes: This last phrase compares the birds of the sky (or the heavens) to wisdom in that both go mostly unnoticed by those living on earth.

verses.textEn: Perdition and death have said, “With our ears, we have heard its fame.”
verses.textLa: Perditio et mors dixerunt: Auribus nostris audivimus famam eius.

verses.textEn: God understands its way, and he knows its location.
verses.textLa: Deus intelligit viam eius, et ipse novit locum illius.

verses.textEn: For he beholds the limits of the world, and he looks upon all things that are under heaven.
verses.textLa: Ipse enim fines mundi intuetur: et omnia, quæ sub cælo sunt, respicit.

verses.textEn: He created a counterweight for the winds, and he suspended the waters to measure them.
verses.textLa: Qui fecit ventis pondus, et aquas appendit in mensura.

verses.textEn: At that time, he gave a law to the rain and a path to the resounding storms.
verses.textLa: Quando ponebat pluviis legem, et viam procellis sonantibus:

verses.textEn: Then he saw and explained it, and he made ready and examined it.
verses.textLa: Tunc vidit illam, et enarravit, et præparavit, et investigavit.

verses.textEn: And he said to man, “Behold the fear of the Lord. Such is wisdom. And to withdraw from evil, this is understanding.”
verses.textLa: Et dixit homini: Ecce timor Domini, ipsa est sapientia: et recedere a malo, intelligentia.

verses.textEn: Job also added to this, using figures of speech, and he said:
verses.textLa: Addidit quoque Iob, assumens parabolam suam, et dixit:

verses.textEn: Who will grant to me that I might be as I was in former months, according to the days when God kept watch over me?
verses.textLa: Quis mihi tribuat, ut sim iuxta menses pristinos secundum dies, quibus Deus custodiebat me?

verses.textEn: At that time, his lamp shined over my head, and by his light, I walked through the darkness.
verses.textLa: Quando splendebat lucerna eius super caput meum, et ad lumen eius ambulabam in tenebris?

verses.textEn: I was then just as in the days of my youth, when God was privately in my tabernacle.
verses.textLa: Sicut fui in diebus adolescentiæ meæ, quando secreto Deus erat in tabernaculo meo?

verses.textEn: At that time, the Almighty was with me and my children surrounded me.
verses.textLa: Quando erat Omnipotens mecum: et in circuitu meo pueri mei?

verses.textEn: Then, I washed my feet with butter, and a boulder poured out rivers of oil for me.
verses.textLa: Quando lavabam pedes meos butyro, et petra fundebat mihi rivos olei?

verses.textEn: When I went to the gate of the city, or to the main street, they prepared a chair for me.
verses.textLa: Quando procedebam ad portam civitatis, et in platea parabant cathedram mihi?

verses.textEn: The youths saw me and hid themselves, and the elders, rising up, remained standing.
verses.textLa: Videbant me iuvenes, et abscondebantur: et senes assurgentes stabant.
verses.notes: The verb ‘stabant’ in Latin does not have the same range of meaning as the verb ‘to stand’ in English. The Latin has more of a connotation of ‘remaining’ or ‘standing firm’ or ‘standing still’ or even of ‘withstanding’ something.

verses.textEn: The leaders stopped talking, and they placed a finder over their mouth.
verses.textLa: Principes cessabant loqui, et digitum superponebant ori suo.

verses.textEn: The commanders subdued their voice, and their tongue adhered to their throat.
verses.textLa: Vocem suam cohibebant duces, et lingua eorum gutturi suo adhærebat.
verses.notes: Notice that the civilian leaders, ‘principes,’ are silent, but the military leaders, ‘duces,’ speak with a subdued voice. These two words both refer to some type of leader, but the word ‘dux’ has more of a military connotation.

verses.textEn: The ear that heard me, blessed me, and the eye that saw me, gave testimony for me.
verses.textLa: Auris audiens beatificabat me, et oculus videns testimonium reddebat mihi.

verses.textEn: This was because I had freed the poor, who cried out, and the orphan, who had no helper.
verses.textLa: Eo quod liberassem pauperem vociferantem, et pupillum, cui non esset adiutor.

verses.textEn: The blessing of him who would have been destroyed came upon me, and I consoled the heart of the widow.
verses.textLa: Benedictio perituri super me veniebat, et cor viduæ consolatus sum.

verses.textEn: I put on justice, and I clothed myself with my judgment, like a robe and a diadem.
verses.textLa: Iustitia indutus sum: et vestivi me, sicut vestimento et diademate, iudicio meo.

verses.textEn: I was an eye for the blind and a foot for the lame.
verses.textLa: Oculus fui cæco, et pes claudo.

verses.textEn: I was the father of the poor; and if I lacked knowledge about any case, I investigated very diligently.
verses.textLa: Pater eram pauperum: et causam quam nesciebam, diligentissime investigabam.

verses.textEn: I crushed the jaws of the impious, and I took away prey from his teeth.
verses.textLa: Conterebam molas iniqui, et de dentibus illius auferebam prædam.

verses.textEn: And I said, “I will die in my little nest, and like a palm tree, I will multiply my days.
verses.textLa: Dicebamque: In nidulo meo moriar, et sicut palma multiplicabo dies.

verses.textEn: My root has been spread beside the waters, and the dew will remain with my harvest.
verses.textLa: Radix mea aperta est secus aquas, et ros morabitur in messione mea.

verses.textEn: My glory will always be restored, and my bow will be restored to my hand.”
verses.textLa: Gloria mea semper innovabitur, et arcus meus in manu mea instaurabitur.

verses.textEn: Those who heard me, expected vindication, and they listened closely in silence to my counsel.
verses.textLa: Qui me audiebant, expectabant sententiam, et intenti tacebant ad consilium meum.

verses.textEn: To my words, they dared to add nothing, and my eloquence poured over them.
verses.textLa: Verbis meis addere nihil audebant, et super illos stillabat eloquium meum.

verses.textEn: They waited for me as for rain, and they opened their mouth as for belated rains.
verses.textLa: Expectabant me sicut pluviam, et os suum aperiebant quasi ad imbrem serotinum.

verses.textEn: If I had ever laughed at them, they would not have believed it, and the light of my face was not cast down towards the ground.
verses.textLa: Siquando ridebam ad eos, non credebant, et lux vultus mei non cadebat in terram.

verses.textEn: If I wished to go to them, I sat down first, and, though I sat like a king surrounded by an army, yet I was a comforter to those who mourned.
verses.textLa: Si voluissem ire ad eos, sedebam primus: cumque sederem quasi rex, circumstante exercitu, eram tamen mœrentium consolator.

verses.textEn: But now, those younger in years scorn me, whose fathers I would not have seen fit to place with the dogs of my flock,
verses.textLa: Nunc autem derident me iuniores tempore, quorum non dignabar patres ponere cum canibus gregis mei:

verses.textEn: the strength of whose hands was nothing to me, and they were considered unworthy of life itself.
verses.textLa: Quorum virtus manuum mihi erat pro nihilo, et vita ipsa putabantur indigni.

verses.textEn: They were barren from poverty and hunger; they gnawed in solitude, layered with misfortune and misery.
verses.textLa: Egestate et fame steriles, qui rodebant in solitudine, squallentes calamitate, et miseria.

verses.textEn: And they chewed grass and the bark from trees, and the root of junipers was their food.
verses.textLa: Et mandebant herbas, et arborum cortices, et radix iuniperorum erat cibus eorum.

verses.textEn: They took these things from the steep valleys, and when they discovered one of these things, they rushed to the others with a cry.
verses.textLa: Qui de convallibus ista rapientes, cum singula reperissent, ad ea cum clamore currebant.

verses.textEn: They lived in the parched desert and in caves underground or above the rocks.
verses.textLa: In desertis habitabant torrentium, et in cavernis terræ, vel super glaream.

verses.textEn: They rejoiced among these kinds of things, and they considered it delightful to be under thorns.
verses.textLa: Qui inter huiuscemodi lætabantur, et esse sub sentibus delicias computabant.

verses.textEn: These are the sons of foolish and base men, not even paying any attention to the land.
verses.textLa: Filii stultorum et ignobilium, et in terra penitus non parentes.

verses.textEn: Now I become their song, and I have been made into their proverb.
verses.textLa: Nunc in eorum canticum versus sum, et factus sum eis in proverbium.

verses.textEn: They loathe me, and so they flee far from me, and they are not reluctant to spit in my face.
verses.textLa: Abominantur me, et longe fugiunt a me, et faciem meam conspuere non verentur.

verses.textEn: For he has opened his quiver and has afflicted me, and he has placed a bridle in my mouth.
verses.textLa: Pharetram enim suam aperuit, et afflixit me, et frenum posuit in os meum.

verses.textEn: Immediately, upon rising, my calamities rise up to the right. They have overturned my feet and have pressed me down along their way like waves.
verses.textLa: Ad dexteram orientis calamitates meæ illico surrexerunt: pedes meos subverterunt, et oppresserunt quasi fluctibus semitis suis.

verses.textEn: They have diverted my journeys; they have waited to ambush me, and they have prevailed, and there was no one who might bring help.
verses.textLa: Dissipaverunt itinera mea, insidiati sunt mihi, et prævaluerunt, et non fuit qui ferret auxilium.

verses.textEn: They have rushed upon me, as when a wall is broken or a gate opened, and they have been pulled down into my miseries.
verses.textLa: Quasi rupto muro, et aperta ianua, irruerunt super me, et ad meas miserias devoluti sunt.

verses.textEn: I have been reduced to nothing. You have taken away my desire like a wind, and my health has passed by like a cloud.
verses.textLa: Redactus sum in nihilum: abstulisti quasi ventus desiderium meum: et velut nubes pertransiit salus mea.

verses.textEn: But now my soul withers within myself, and the days of affliction take hold of me.
verses.textLa: Nunc autem in memetipso marcescit anima mea, et possident me dies afflictionis.

verses.textEn: At night, my bone is pierced with sorrows, and those who feed on me, do not sleep.
verses.textLa: Nocte os meum perforatur doloribus: et qui me comedunt, non dormiunt.

verses.textEn: By the sheer number of them my clothing is worn away, and they have closed in on me like the collar of my coat.
verses.textLa: In multitudine eorum consumitur vestimentum meum, et quasi capito tunicæ succinxerunt me.

verses.textEn: I have been treated like dirt, and I have been turned into embers and ashes.
verses.textLa: Comparatus sum luto, et assimilatus sum favillæ et cineri.

verses.textEn: I cry to you, and you do not heed me. I stand up, and you do not look back at me.
verses.textLa: Clamo ad te, et non exaudis me: sto, et non respicis me.

verses.textEn: You have changed me into hardness, and, with the hardness of your hand, you oppose me.
verses.textLa: Mutatus es mihi in crudelem, et in duritia manus tuæ adversaris mihi.
verses.notes: The first part of this verse does not say that God has changed into cruelty, but rather that God has changed Job ‘into hardness’ or ‘to have a hard heart.’ Notice the play on words (which is almost lost by the Latin using two different words, crudelem and duritia, to refer to hardness). God ‘has been changing’ Job into hardness and God has a ‘hard hand.’ In English, we do not use the perfect passive participle nearly as often as it is used in Latin. Therefore, ‘has been changing’ is better rendered as ‘have changed.’ The translation then becomes: “You have changed me into hardness, and, with the hardness of your hand, you have opposed me.”

verses.textEn: You have lifted me up, and, placing me as if on the wind, you have thrown me down powerfully.
verses.textLa: Elevasti me, et quasi super ventum ponens elisisti me valide.

verses.textEn: I know that you will hand me over to death, where a home has been established for all the living.
verses.textLa: Scio quia morti trades me, ubi constituta est domus omni viventi.

verses.textEn: Truly, then, you do not extend your hand in order to consume them, and if they fall down, you will save them.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen non ad consumptionem eorum emittis manum tuam: et si corruerint, ipse salvabis.

verses.textEn: Once, I wept over him who was afflicted, and my soul had compassion on the poor.
verses.textLa: Flebam quondam super eo, qui afflictus erat, et compatiebatur anima mea pauperi.

verses.textEn: I expected good things, but evil things have come to me. I stood ready for light, yet darkness burst forth.
verses.textLa: Expectabam bona, et venerunt mihi mala: præstolabar lucem, et eruperunt tenebræ.

verses.textEn: My insides have seethed, without any rest, for the days of affliction have prevented it.
verses.textLa: Interiora mea efferbuerunt absque ulla requie, prævenerunt me dies afflictionis.

verses.textEn: I went forth mourning, without anger, and rising up, I cried out in confusion.
verses.textLa: Mœrens incedebam, sine furore, consurgens, in turba clamabam.

verses.textEn: I was the brother of snakes, and the companion of ostriches.
verses.textLa: Frater fui draconum, et socius struthionum.

verses.textEn: My skin has become blackened over me, and my bones have dried up because of the heat.
verses.textLa: Cutis mea denigrata est super me, et ossa mea aruerunt præ caumate.

verses.textEn: My harp has been turned into mourning, and my pipes have been turned into a voice of weeping.
verses.textLa: Versa est in luctum cithara mea, et organum meum in vocem flentium.

verses.textEn: I reached an agreement with my eyes, that I would not so much as think about a virgin.
verses.textLa: Pepigi fœdus cum oculis meis ut ne cogitarem quidem de virgine.

verses.textEn: For what portion should God from above hold for me, and what inheritance should the Almighty from on high keep?
verses.textLa: Quam enim partem haberet in me Deus desuper, et hereditatem Omnipotens de excelsis?

verses.textEn: Is not destruction held for the wicked and repudiation kept for those who work injustice?
