verses.textLa: Numquid non perditio est iniquo, et alienatio operantibus iniustitiam?

verses.textEn: Does he not examine my ways and number all my steps?
verses.textLa: Nonne ipse considerat vias meas, et cunctos gressus meos dinumerat?

verses.textEn: If I have walked in vanity, or if my foot has hurried towards deceitfulness,
verses.textLa: Si ambulavi in vanitate, et festinavit in dolo pes meus:

verses.textEn: let him weigh me in a just balance, and let God know my simplicity.
verses.textLa: Appendat me in statera iusta, et sciat Deus simplicitatem meam.

verses.textEn: If my steps have turned aside from the way, or if my heart has followed my eyes, or if a blemish has clung to my hands,
verses.textLa: Si declinavit gressus meus de via, et si secutum est oculos meos cor meum, et si manibus meis adhæsit macula:
verses.notes: The Latin word ‘et’ is usually translated as ‘and,’ but in this and certain other contexts, it clearly means ‘or.’ Job is not saying: ‘If I have done all three of these things,’ but rather, ‘If I have done any one of these things.’ Therefore, the translation is ‘or’ not ‘and.’

verses.textEn: then may I sow, and let another consume, and let my offspring be eradicated.
verses.textLa: Seram, et alium comedat: et progenies mea eradicetur.

verses.textEn: If my heart has been deceived over a woman, or if I have waited in ambush at my friend’s door,
verses.textLa: Si deceptum est cor meum super muliere, et si ad ostium amici mei insidiatus sum:

verses.textEn: then let my wife be the harlot of another, and let other men lean over her.
verses.textLa: Scortum alterius sit uxor mea, et super illam incurventur alii.

verses.textEn: For this is a crime and a very great injustice.
verses.textLa: Hoc enim nefas est, et iniquitas maxima.

verses.textEn: It is a fire devouring all the way to perdition, and it roots out all that springs forth.
verses.textLa: Ignis est usque ad perditionem devorans, et omnia eradicans genimina.

verses.textEn: If I have despised being subject to judgment with my servant or my maid, when they had any complaint against me,
verses.textLa: Si contempsi subire iudicium cum servo meo, et ancilla mea, cum disceptarent adversum me:

verses.textEn: then what will I do when God rises to judge, and, when he inquires, how will I respond to him?
verses.textLa: Quid enim faciam cum surrexerit ad iudicandum Deus? et cum quæsierit, quid respondebo illi?

verses.textEn: Is not he who created me in the womb, also he who labored to make him? And did not one and the same form me in the womb?
verses.textLa: Numquid non in utero fecit me qui et illum operatus est: et formavit me in vulva unus?
verses.notes: The word ‘utero’ is more general in meaning in Latin than the word ‘uterus’ is in English. The Latin ‘utero’ can refer to a male’s abdomen or to a woman’s womb. So, why does the Latin use two words, utero and vulva, and two questions (or a two-part question) to ask the same thing? Because the masculine singular word utero refers, not to the womb, but to the father’s (not well understood during Job’s day) genitive capability, and the word vulva refers to the mother’s genitive capability.

verses.textEn: If I have denied the poor what they wanted and have made the eyes of the widow wait;
verses.textLa: Si negavi, quod volebant, pauperibus, et oculos viduæ expectare feci:

verses.textEn: if I have eaten my morsel of food alone, while orphans have not eaten from it;
verses.textLa: Si comedi buccellam meam solus, et non comedit pupillus ex ea:

verses.textEn: (for from my infancy mercy grew with me, and it came out with me from my mother’s womb;)
verses.textLa: (Quia ab infantia mea crevit mecum miseratio: et de utero matris meæ egressa est mecum.)

verses.textEn: if I have looked down on him who was perishing because he had no clothing and the poor without any covering,
verses.textLa: Si despexi pereuntem, eo quod non habuerit indumentum, et absque operimento pauperem:

verses.textEn: if his sides have not blessed me, and if he were not warmed with the fleece of my sheep;
verses.textLa: Si non benedixerunt mihi latera eius, et de velleribus ovium mearum calefactus est:

verses.textEn: if I have lifted up my hand over an orphan, even when it might seem to me that I have the advantage over him at the gate;
verses.textLa: Si levavi super pupillum manum meam, etiam cum viderem me in porta superiorem:

verses.textEn: then may my shoulder fall from its joint, and may my arm, with all its bones, be broken.
verses.textLa: Humerus meus a iunctura sua cadat, et brachium meum cum suis ossibus confringatur.

verses.textEn: For I have always feared God, like waves flowing over me, whose weight I was unable to bear.
verses.textLa: Semper enim quasi tumentes super me fluctus timui Deum, et pondus eius ferre non potui.

verses.textEn: If I have considered gold to be my strength, or if I have called purified gold ‘my Trust;’
verses.textLa: Si putavi aurum robur meum, et obrizo dixi: Fiducia mea.

verses.textEn: if I have rejoiced over my great success, and over the many things my hand has obtained;
verses.textLa: Si lætatus sum super multis divitiis meis, et quia plurima reperit manus mea.

verses.textEn: if I gazed upon the sun when it shined and the moon advancing brightly,
verses.textLa: Si vidi solem cum fulgeret, et lunam incedentem clare:

verses.textEn: so that my heart rejoiced in secret and I kissed my hand with my mouth,
verses.textLa: Et lætatum est in abscondito cor meum, et osculatus sum manum meam ore meo.

verses.textEn: which is a very great iniquity and a denial against the most high God;
verses.textLa: Quæ est iniquitas maxima, et negatio contra Deum altissimum.

verses.textEn: if I have been glad at the ruin of him who hated me and have exulted that evil found him,
verses.textLa: Si gavisus sum ad ruinam eius, qui me oderat, et exultavi quod invenisset eum malum.

verses.textEn: for I have not been given my throat to sin by asking for a curse on his soul;
verses.textLa: Non enim dedi ad peccandum guttur meum, ut expeterem maledicens animam eius.

verses.textEn: if the men around my tabernacle have not said: “He might give us some of his food, so that we will be filled,”
verses.textLa: Si non dixerunt viri tabernaculi mei: Quis det de carnibus eius ut saturemur:
verses.notes: Job is listing sinful things that he has not done, so this good deed is spoken of in the negative: ‘Si non dixerunt....’ The good deed is that any men who came around his tabernacle (or tent or home) knew that they might obtain food from him if they were hungry. The Latin is here translated loosely, because a strict literal translation would be more difficult to understand. Here ‘carnibus’ does not specifically refer to meat (or flesh), but to food or a meal. Notice that ‘Quis’ is not to be understood as the word ‘Who’ introducing a question, but as a pronoun, better translated as ‘He’ than as ‘Who.’ Latin uses ‘quis’ as a pronoun in a way that English rarely uses the word ‘who.’ The quote here, beginning with ‘Quis’ could be translated as a question, but it is more clearly understood in its proper meaning when translated as a statement. The hungry knew that they could count on Job for food when they were hungry. Notice also that the genitive ‘tabernaculi mei,’ referring to ‘viri’ does not connotate possession (the men of my tabernacle), for the next verse clearly indicates that these men are foreigners or travelers, not the men working or living at Job’s home. The genitive case can occasionally mean ‘among’ or ‘around’ rather than ‘of.’

verses.textEn: for the foreigner did not remain at the door, my door was open to the traveler;
verses.textLa: Foris non mansit peregrinus, ostium meum viatori patuit.

verses.textEn: if, as man does, I have hidden my sin and have concealed my iniquity in my bosom;
verses.textLa: Si abscondi quasi homo peccatum meum, et celavi in sinu meo iniquitatem meam.

verses.textEn: if I became frightened by an excessive crowd, and the disrespect of close relatives alarmed me, so that I would much rather have remained silent or have gone out the door;
verses.textLa: Si expavi ad multitudinem nimiam, et despectio propinquorum terruit me: et non magis tacui, nec egressus sum ostium.

verses.textEn: then, would he grant me a hearing, so that the Almighty would listen to my desire, and he who judges would himself write a book,
verses.textLa: Quis mihi tribuat auditorem, ut desiderium meum audiat Omnipotens: et librum scribat ipse qui iudicat.
verses.notes: Again, the word ‘quis’ in Latin does not always mean ‘who,’ even when used in a question. In this case, Job is referring to all of the previous ‘if...’ propositions, saying, if all of these faults had been found in Job, would He still grant Job a favorable hearing and a clear vindication? No, He would not. ‘Quis’ is here used as a pronoun referring to God.

verses.textEn: which I would then carry on my shoulder and wrap around me like a crown?
verses.textLa: Ut in humero meo portem illum, et circumdem illum quasi coronam mihi?

verses.textEn: With each of my steps, I would pronounce and offer it, as if to a prince.
verses.textLa: Per singulos gradus meos pronunciabo illum, et quasi principi offeram eum.

verses.textEn: So, if my land cries out against me, and if its furrows weep with it,
verses.textLa: Si adversum me terra mea clamat, et cum ipsa sulci eius deflent:

verses.textEn: if I have used its fruits for nothing but money and have afflicted the souls of its tillers,
verses.textLa: Si fructus eius comedi absque pecunia, et animam agricolarum eius afflixi:
verses.notes: This verse does not say: ‘if I have eaten of its fruits without money,’ but rather: ‘if I have used its fruits for nothing except money.’ The first translation does not make any sense. The second translation makes sense and fits with the theme of this part of the Book of Job, wherein Job lists the faults he doesn’t have. The word ‘comedi’ can refer to eating, but it can also refer to other kinds of consuming or the using of something. The word ‘absque’ can be translated as ‘without,’ but it can also mean ‘except for’ or ‘nothing but.’ Job is saying that it would be a sin to use the land as nothing but a source of money for himself.

verses.textEn: then, may thistles spring forth for me instead of grain, and thorns instead of barley. (This ended the words of Job.)
verses.textLa: Pro frumento oriatur mihi tribulus, et pro hordeo spina. (Finita sunt verba Iob.)

verses.textEn: But these three men ceased to answer Job, because he considered himself justified.
verses.textLa: Omiserunt autem tres viri isti respondere Iob, eo quod iustus sibi videretur.

verses.textEn: And Eliu the son of Barachel the Buzite, of the kindred of Ram, was angry and indignant. But he was angry against Job because he described himself to be just in the presence of God.
verses.textLa: Et iratus, indignatusque est Eliu filius Barachel Buzites, de cognatione Ram: iratus est autem adversum Iob, eo quod iustum se esse diceret coram Deo.

verses.textEn: Moreover, he was indignant with his friends because they had not found a reasonable response, except in so far as they condemned Job.
verses.textLa: Porro adversum amicos eius indignatus est, eo quod non invenissent responsionem rationabilem, sed tantummodo condemnassent Iob.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Eliu waited while Job was talking, for these were his elders that were speaking.
verses.textLa: Igitur Eliu expectavit Iob loquentem: eo quod seniores essent qui loquebantur.

verses.textEn: But when he saw that these three were not able to respond, he was extremely angry.
verses.textLa: Cum autem vidisset quod tres respondere non potuissent, iratus est vehementer.

verses.textEn: And so Eliu the son of Barachel the Buzite responded by saying: I am younger in years, and you are more ancient; therefore, I kept my head low, for I was afraid to reveal to you my opinion.
verses.textLa: Respondensque Eliu filius Barachel Buzites, dixit: Iunior sum tempore, vos autem antiquiores, idcirco demisso capite, veritus sum vobis indicare meam sententiam.

verses.textEn: For I had hoped that greater age would speak, and that a multitude of years would teach wisdom.
verses.textLa: Sperabam enim quod ætas prolixior loqueretur, et annorum multitudo doceret sapientiam.

verses.textEn: But I see now that there is only breath in men, and that it is the inspiration of the Almighty that gives understanding.
verses.textLa: Sed, ut video, spiritus est in hominibus, et inspiratio Omnipotentis dat intelligentiam.
verses.notes: The word ‘spiritus’ should not be capitalized here, as if it referred to the Spirit of God. The word ‘spiritus’ refers to the breath, or the breath of life, or life, or spirit. It does not refer to the soul, however. The ancient view of the human person was: body, breath of life (spiritus), and soul (anima). Here Eliu is saying that there is only breath or wind in men, and that, if any man has understanding, it is a gift from God.

verses.textEn: The wise are not the aged, nor do the elders understand judgment.
verses.textLa: Non sunt longævi sapientes, nec senes intelligunt iudicium.

verses.textEn: Therefore, I will speak. Listen to me, and so I will show you my wisdom.
verses.textLa: Ideo dicam: Audite me, ostendam vobis etiam ego meam sapientiam.

verses.textEn: For I have endured your words; I have paid attention to your deliberations, while you were being argumentative with words.
verses.textLa: Expectavi enim sermones vestros, audivi prudentiam vestram, donec disceptaremini sermonibus:

verses.textEn: And as long as I supposed that you were saying something, I considered; but now I see that there is none of you that is able to argue with Job and to respond to his words.
verses.textLa: Et donec putabam vos aliquid dicere, considerabam: sed, ut video, non est qui possit arguere Iob, et respondere ex vobis sermonibus eius.

verses.textEn: So that you will not say, “We have found wisdom,” God has thrown him down, not man.
verses.textLa: Ne forte dicatis: Invenimus sapientiam: Deus proiecit eum, non homo.
verses.notes: The expression ‘ne forte’ can be translated as ‘lest,’ but it has a negative connotation in Latin. So a better translation would preserve that negation. The quotation here is only two words: “Invenimus sapientiam.” And the last part explains that God chose to defeat Job through a young man (Eliu), so that it could be seen that such wisdom must have come from God, not man.

verses.textEn: He has said nothing to me, and I will not respond to him according to your words.
verses.textLa: Nihil locutus est mihi, et ego non secundum sermones vestros respondebo illi.

verses.textEn: Then they were filled with dread, and so they no longer responded, and they withdrew from their speechmaking.
verses.textLa: Extimuerunt, nec responderunt ultra, abstuleruntque a se eloquia.

verses.textEn: Therefore, because I have waited and they have not been speaking, for they stood firm and did not respond at all,
verses.textLa: Quoniam igitur expectavi, et non sunt locuti: steterunt, nec ultra responderunt:
verses.notes: The word ‘steterunt’ in this context does not refer to standing, but to remaining or persevering, i.e. ‘they stood firm’ in their refusal to respond. Notice that Eliu is now addressing Job, so that he calls the others ‘they.’ The previous verse, 32:15, is not a quote of Eliu speaking, but is used to separate the section where Eliu addresses the three men from the section where Eliu addresses Job.

verses.textEn: I also will answer in my turn, and I will reveal my knowledge.
verses.textLa: Respondebo et ego partem meam, et ostendam scientiam meam.

verses.textEn: For I am full of words, and the feeling in my gut inspires me.
verses.textLa: Plenus sum enim sermonibus, et coarctat me spiritus uteri mei.

verses.textEn: Yes, my stomach is like fermenting wine without a vent, which bursts the new containers.
verses.textLa: En venter meus quasi mustum absque spiraculo, quod lagunculas novas disrumpit.

verses.textEn: I should speak, but I will also breathe a little; I will open my lips, and I will answer.
verses.textLa: Loquar, et respirabo paululum: aperiam labia mea, et respondebo.

verses.textEn: I will not esteem the reputation of a man, and I will not equate God with man.
verses.textLa: Non accipiam personam viri, et Deum homini non æquabo.

verses.textEn: For I do not know how long I will continue, and whether, after a while, my Maker might take me away.
verses.textLa: Nescio enim quamdiu subsistam, et si post modicum tollat me Factor meus.

verses.textEn: Therefore, hear my speeches, Job, and listen to all my words.
verses.textLa: Audi igitur Iob eloquia mea, et omnes sermones meos ausculta.

verses.textEn: Behold, I have opened my mouth; let my tongue speak along with my throat.
verses.textLa: Ecce aperui os meum, loquatur lingua mea in faucibus meis.

verses.textEn: My words are from my simple heart, and my lips will speak a pure judgment.
verses.textLa: Simplici corde meo sermones mei, et sententiam puram labia mea loquentur.

verses.textEn: The Spirit of God made me, and the breath of the Almighty gave me life.
verses.textLa: Spiritus Dei fecit me, et spiraculum Omnipotentis vivificavit me.

verses.textEn: If you can, answer me, and oppose me to my face.
verses.textLa: Si potes, responde mihi, et adversus faciem meam consiste.

verses.textEn: Behold, God has made me, just as he also has made you, and I, likewise, have been formed of the same clay.
verses.textLa: Ecce, et me sicut et te fecit Deus, et de eodem luto ego quoque formatus sum.

verses.textEn: So, truly, do not let my wonders terrify you, and do not let my eloquence be burdensome to you.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen miraculum meum non te terreat, et eloquentia mea non sit tibi gravis.

verses.textEn: For you have spoken in my hearing, and I have heard the voice of your words, saying:
verses.textLa: Dixisti ergo in auribus meis, et vocem verborum tuorum audivi:

verses.textEn: “I am clean and without sin; I am immaculate, and there is no iniquity in me.
verses.textLa: Mundus sum ego, et absque delicto: immaculatus, et non est iniquitas in me.

verses.textEn: Yet he has discovered blame in me, and so he has treated me like his enemy.
verses.textLa: Quia querelas in me reperit, ideo arbitratus est me inimicum sibi.

verses.textEn: He has put my feet in fetters; he has kept watch over all my ways.”
verses.textLa: Posuit in nervo pedes meos, custodivit omnes semitas meas.

verses.textEn: Therefore, it is for this reason that you have not been justified. For I tell you that God is greater than man.
verses.textLa: Hoc est ergo, in quo non es iustificatus: respondebo tibi, quia maior sit Deus homine.

verses.textEn: Do you contend against him because he has not responded to all of your words?
verses.textLa: Adversus eum contendis quod non ad omnia verba responderit tibi?

verses.textEn: God speaks once, and he does not repeat the same thing a second time.
verses.textLa: Semel loquitur Deus, et secundo idipsum non repetit.

verses.textEn: Through a dream in a vision of the night, when a deep sleep falls over men, and they are sleeping in their beds,
verses.textLa: Per somnium in visione nocturna, quando irruit sopor super homines, et dormiunt in lectulo:

verses.textEn: then, he opens the ears of men, and, educating them, he teaches discipline,
verses.textLa: Tunc aperit aures virorum, et erudiens eos instruit disciplina,

verses.textEn: so that he may divert a man from the things that he is doing, and may free him from pride,
verses.textLa: Ut avertat hominem ab his, quæ facit, et liberet eum de superbia:

verses.textEn: rescuing his soul from corruption and his life from passing away by the sword.
verses.textLa: Eruens animam eius a corruptione: et vitam illius, ut non transeat in gladium.

verses.textEn: Likewise, he rebukes by sorrow in bed, and he causes all of his bones to become weak.
verses.textLa: Increpat quoque per dolorem in lectulo, et omnia ossa eius marcescere facit.

verses.textEn: Bread becomes abominable to him in his life, and, to his soul, the meat which before he desired.
verses.textLa: Abominabilis ei fit in vita sua panis, et animæ illius cibus ante desiderabilis.
verses.notes: There are a number of verses in Job that refer to the time of the Antichrist. This verse refers to the abomination of desolation, which is a perverse imitation of the Most Holy Eucharist.

verses.textEn: His body will waste away, and his bones, which had been covered, will be revealed.
verses.textLa: Tabescet caro eius, et ossa, quæ tecta fuerant, nudabuntur.

verses.textEn: His soul has approached corruption, and his life has drawn near to what is deadly.
verses.textLa: Appropinquavit corruptioni anima eius, et vita illius mortiferis.

verses.textEn: If there were an angel speaking for him, one among thousands, to declare the fairness of the man,
verses.textLa: Si fuerit pro eo Angelus loquens, unus de millibus, ut annuntiet hominis æquitatem:

verses.textEn: he will have mercy on him, and he will say, “Free him, so that he will not descend to destruction. I have found a reason to be favorable to him.
verses.textLa: Miserebitur eius, et dicet: Libera eum, ut non descendat in corruptionem: inveni in quo ei propitier.

verses.textEn: His body is consumed by suffering. Let him return to the days of his youth.”
verses.textLa: Consumpta est caro eius a suppliciis, revertatur ad dies adolescentiæ suæ.

verses.textEn: He will beg pardon from God, and he will be soothing to him; and he will look upon his face in jubilation, and he will restore his justice to man.
verses.textLa: Deprecabitur Deum, et placabilis ei erit: et videbit faciem eius in iubilo, et reddet homini iustitiam suam.
verses.notes: This verse in Latin uses so many pronouns, it is difficult to determine which refer to God and which to man. But the verse has a certain symmetry or pattern that reveals its meaning: the man acts towards God and God responds towards the man; then the man acts again towards God and God again responds towards the man.

verses.textEn: He will consider mankind, and he will say: “I have sinned and truly I have offended, yet I was not treated as I deserved.”
verses.textLa: Respiciet homines, et dicet: Peccavi, et vere deliqui, et, ut eram dignus, non recepi.

verses.textEn: He has freed his soul from continuing into destruction, so that, in living, it may see the light.
verses.textLa: Liberavit animam suam ne pergeret in interitum, sed vivens lucem videret.

verses.textEn: Behold, all these things God works three times within each one,
verses.textLa: Ecce, hæc omnia operatur Deus tribus vicibus per singulos:

verses.textEn: so that he may revive their souls from corruption and enlighten them with the light of life.
verses.textLa: Ut revocet animas eorum a corruptione, et illuminet luce viventium.

verses.textEn: Pay attention Job, and listen to me; and remain silent, while I speak.
verses.textLa: Attende Iob, et audi me: et tace, dum loquor.

verses.textEn: Yet, if you have anything to say, answer me and speak, for I want you to be treated justly.
verses.textLa: Si autem habes quod loquaris, responde mihi, loquere: volo enim, te apparere iustum.

verses.textEn: But if you do not have anything to say, then listen to me. Be quiet and I will teach you wisdom.
verses.textLa: Quod si non habes, audi me: tace, et docebo te sapientiam.

verses.textEn: After proclaiming these things, Eliu now had this to say:
verses.textLa: Pronuntians itaque Eliu, etiam hæc locutus est:

verses.textEn: May the wise hear my words, and may the educated listen to me.
verses.textLa: Audite sapientes verba mea, et eruditi auscultate me:

verses.textEn: For the ear examines words, and the mouth discerns foods by the taste.
verses.textLa: Auris enim verba probat, et guttur escas gustu diiudicat.

verses.textEn: Let us choose judgment for ourselves, and let us consider among ourselves what is best.
verses.textLa: Iudicium eligamus nobis, et inter nos videamus quid sit melius.

verses.textEn: For Job has said: “I am just, yet God has subverted my judgment.
verses.textLa: Quia dixit Iob: Iustus sum, et Deus subvertit iudicium meum.

verses.textEn: For, within my judgment, there is a lie: my vehement barbs are without any sin.”
verses.textLa: In iudicando enim me, mendacium est: violenta sagitta mea absque ullo peccato.

verses.textEn: What man is there that is like Job, who drinks up derision as if it were water,
verses.textLa: Quis est vir ut est Iob, qui bibit subsannationem quasi aquam:

verses.textEn: who accompanies those who work iniquity, and who walks with impious men?
verses.textLa: Qui graditur cum operantibus iniquitatem, et ambulat cum viris impiis?

verses.textEn: For he has said, “Man will not please God, even if he should travel with him.”
verses.textLa: Dixit enim: Non placebit vir Deo, etiam si cucurrerit cum eo.

verses.textEn: Therefore, prudent men, hear me: impiety is far from God, and iniquity is far from the Almighty.
verses.textLa: Ideo viri cordati audite me, absit a Deo impietas, et ab Omnipotente iniquitas.

verses.textEn: For he will restore to man his works, and according to the ways of each, he will repay them.
verses.textLa: Opus enim hominis reddet ei, et iuxta vias singulorum restituet eis.

verses.textEn: For truly, God will not condemn in vain, nor will the Almighty repudiate judgment.
verses.textLa: Vere enim Deus non condemnabit frustra, nec Omnipotens subvertet iudicium.

verses.textEn: What other is established over the earth? Or whom has he placed over the world, which he made?
verses.textLa: Quem constituit alium super terram? aut quem posuit super orbem, quem fabricatus est?

verses.textEn: But, if he directs his heart towards him, he will draw his spirit and breath to himself.
verses.textLa: Si direxerit ad eum cor suum, spiritum illius et flatum ad se trahet.

verses.textEn: All flesh will fail together, and man will return to ashes.
verses.textLa: Deficiet omnis caro simul, et homo in cinerem revertetur.

verses.textEn: Therefore, if you have understanding, hear what is said, and heed the sound of my eloquence.
verses.textLa: Si habes ergo intellectum, audi quod dicitur, et ausculta vocem eloquii mei.

verses.textEn: Is he that does not love judgment able to be corrected? And how can you so greatly condemn him who is just?
verses.textLa: Numquid qui non amat iudicium, sanari potest? et quomodo tu eum, qui iustus est, in tantum condemnas?

verses.textEn: He says to the king, “You are an apostate.” He calls commanders impious.
verses.textLa: Qui dicit regi, apostata: qui vocat duces impios:

verses.textEn: He does not accept the reputation of leaders; nor does he recognize the tyrant as he contends against the poor. For all are the work of his hands.
verses.textLa: Qui non accipit personas principum: nec cognovit tyrannum, cum disceptaret contra pauperum: opus enim manuum eius sunt universi.

verses.textEn: They will die suddenly, and the people will be troubled in the middle of the night, but they will pass through it, and the violent will be taken away without a hand.
verses.textLa: Subito morientur, et in media nocte turbabuntur populi, et pertransibunt, et auferent violentum absque manu.
verses.notes:
In the Bible, the expression, ‘without a hand’ (absque manu) generally refers to situations where God accomplishes something without making use of human intervention, i.e. by angelic or divine intervention. In this verse, they take away the violent without human assistance. They could refer to angels, but since the subject of the sentence is not specified, the translation avoids specifying the subject by converting the phrase to passive tense.
 This verse refers to the Three Days of Darkness, when many will die, and many will be troubled in the midst of darkness (or, in the middle of night), but they will survive and pass through the darkness, and then they will find that the violent have been taken away without human intervention, without a hand.

verses.textEn: For his eyes are upon the ways of men, and he examines all of their steps.
verses.textLa: Oculi enim eius super vias hominum, et omnes gressus eorum considerat.

verses.textEn: There is no darkness and no shadow of death, where those who work iniquity may be hidden.
verses.textLa: Non sunt tenebræ, et non est umbra mortis, ut abscondantur ibi qui operantur iniquitatem.

verses.textEn: For it is no longer within the power of man to enter into judgment with God.
verses.textLa: Neque enim ultra in hominis potestate est, ut veniat ad Deum in iudicium.

verses.textEn: He will break into many innumerable pieces, and he will cause others to stand up in their place.
verses.textLa: Conteret multos, et innumerabiles, et stare faciet alios pro eis.

verses.textEn: For he knows their works, and, as a result, he will bring the night, and they will be crushed.
verses.textLa: Novit enim opera eorum: et idcirco inducet noctem, et conterentur.

verses.textEn: Just as the impious do, he has struck them in a place where they can be seen.
verses.textLa: Quasi impios percussit eos in loco videntium.
verses.notes: Or, “Just as the impious do, he has struck them in plain view.” The impious strike others unjustly in plain view, for they have such influence over society that they can strike and not be held accountable themselves. But God will strike them in the same way, in plain view of the whole world.

verses.textEn: They, as if with great diligence, have withdrawn from him, and they refused to understand all his ways,
verses.textLa: Qui quasi de industria recesserunt ab eo, et omnes vias eius intelligere noluerunt:

verses.textEn: so that they caused the outcry of the needy to reach him, and he heard the voice of the poor.
verses.textLa: Ut pervenire facerent ad eum clamorem egeni, et audiret vocem pauperum.

verses.textEn: For, when he grants peace, who is there that can condemn? When he hides his face, who is there that can contemplate him, either among the nations, or among all men?
verses.textLa: Ipso enim concedente pacem, quis est qui condemnet? ex quo absconderit vultum, quis est qui contempletur eum et super gentes et super omnes homines?

verses.textEn: He causes a hypocritical man to reign because of the sins of the people.
verses.textLa: Qui regnare facit hominem hypocritam propter peccata populi.

verses.textEn: Therefore, since I have been speaking about God, I will not prevent you from doing the same.
verses.textLa: Quia ergo ego locutus sum ad Deum, te quoque non prohibebo.

verses.textEn: If I have erred, you may teach me; if I have spoken unfairly, I will add no more.
verses.textLa: Si erravi, tu doce me: si iniquitatem locutus sum, ultra non addam.

verses.textEn: Does God require this of you because it is displeasing to you? For you were the first to speak, and not I. But if you know something better, speak.
verses.textLa: Numquid a te Deus expetit eam, quia displicuit tibi? tu enim cœpisti loqui, et non ego: quod si quid nosti melius, loquere.

verses.textEn: Let men of understanding speak to me, and let a wise man listen to me.
verses.textLa: Viri intelligentes loquantur mihi, et vir sapiens audiat me.

verses.textEn: But Job has been speaking foolishly, and his words contain unsound teaching.
verses.textLa: Iob autem stulte locutus est, et verba illius non sonant disciplinam.

verses.textEn: My father, let Job be tested even to the end; may you not retreat from a man of iniquity.
verses.textLa: Pater mi, probetur Iob usque ad finem: ne desinas ab homine iniquitatis.

verses.textEn: For he adds blasphemy on top of his sins; nevertheless, let him be constrained to be among us, and then let him provoke God to judgment with his speeches.
verses.textLa: Quia addit super peccata sua blasphemiam, inter nos interim constringatur: et tunc ad iudicium provocet sermonibus suis Deum.

verses.textEn: After this, Eliu again spoke in this way:
verses.textLa: Igitur Eliu hæc rursum locutus est:

verses.textEn: Does it seem right to you in your thoughts, that you should say, “I am more just than God?”
verses.textLa: Numquid æqua tibi videtur tua cogitatio, ut diceres: Iustior sum Deo?

verses.textEn: For you said, “Having done what is right does not please you,” and, “How will it benefit you, if I sin?”
verses.textLa: Dixisti enim: Non tibi placet quod rectum est: vel quid tibi proderit, si ego peccavero?
verses.notes: The word ‘vel’ is usually translated as ‘or,’ and the word ‘et’ is usually translated as ‘and.’ However, sometimes the meaning of these Latin words is best expressed by translating ‘vel’ as ‘and,’ and by translating ‘et’ as ‘or.’

verses.textEn: And so, I will respond to your words, and to your friends who are with you.
verses.textLa: Itaque ego respondebo sermonibus tuis, et amicis tuis tecum.

verses.textEn: Look up towards heaven and consider; also, think about the sky, which is higher than you.
verses.textLa: Suspice cælum et intuere, et contemplare æthera quod altior te sit.

verses.textEn: If you sin, how will it hurt him? And if your iniquities are multiplied, what will you do against him?
verses.textLa: Si peccaveris, quid ei nocebis? et si multiplicatæ fuerint iniquitates tuæ, quid facies contra eum?

verses.textEn: Furthermore, if you act justly, what will you give him, or what will he receive from your hand?
verses.textLa: Porro si iuste egeris, quid donabis ei, aut quid de manu tua accipiet?

verses.textEn: Your impiety may hurt a man who is like you, though your justice may help the son of the man.
verses.textLa: Homini, qui similis tui est, nocebit impietas tua: et filium hominis adiuvabit iustitia tua.

verses.textEn: Because of the multitude of false accusers, they will cry out; and they will lament because of the strong arm of the tyrants.
verses.textLa: Propter multitudinem calumniatorum clamabunt: et eiulabunt propter vim brachii tyrannorum.

verses.textEn: Yet he has not said: “Where is God, who made me, who has given songs in the night,
verses.textLa: Et non dixit: Ubi est Deus, qui fecit me, qui dedit carmina in nocte,

verses.textEn: who teaches us in addition to the beasts of the earth, and who educates us along with the birds of the air?”
verses.textLa: Qui docet nos super iumenta terræ, et super volucres cæli erudit nos?

verses.textEn: There they will cry, and he will not heed them, because of the arrogance of the wicked.
verses.textLa: Ibi clamabunt, et non exaudiet, propter superbiam malorum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, God does not hear in vain, and the Almighty will look into each and every case.
verses.textLa: Non ergo frustra audiet Deus, et Omnipotens causas singulorum intuebitur.

verses.textEn: And so, when you say, “He does not examine,” be judged before him, but wait for him.
verses.textLa: Etiam cum dixeris: Non considerat: iudicare coram illo, et expecta eum.

verses.textEn: For, at the present time, he does not bring forth his fury, nor does he punish sin exceedingly.
verses.textLa: Nunc enim non infert furorem suum, nec ulciscitur scelus valde.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Job has opened his mouth in vain and has multiplied words without knowledge.
verses.textLa: Ergo Iob frustra aperit os suum, et absque scientia verba multiplicat.

verses.textEn: Continuing in a similar manner, Eliu had this to say:
verses.textLa: Addens quoque Eliu, hæc locutus est:

verses.textEn: Bear with me for a little while and I will show you; for I have still more to say in favor of God.
verses.textLa: Sustine me paululum, et indicabo tibi: adhuc enim habeo quod pro Deo loquar.

verses.textEn: I will review my knowledge from the beginning, and I will prove my Maker to be just.
verses.textLa: Repetam scientiam meam a principio, et operatorem meum probabo iustum.

verses.textEn: For truly my words are without any falsehood and perfect knowledge will be proven to you.
verses.textLa: Vere enim absque mendacio sermones mei, et perfecta scientia probabitur tibi.

verses.textEn: God does not abandon the powerful, for he himself is also powerful.
verses.textLa: Deus potentes non abiicit, cum et ipse sit potens.

verses.textEn: But he does not save the impious, though he grants judgment to the poor.
verses.textLa: Sed non salvat impios, et iudicium pauperibus tribuit.

verses.textEn: He will not take his eyes away from the just, and he continually establishes kings on their throne, and they are exalted.
verses.textLa: Non auferet a iusto oculos suos, et reges in solio collocat in perpetuum, et illi eriguntur.

verses.textEn: And, if they are in captivity, or are bound with the chains of poverty,
verses.textLa: Et si fuerint in catenis, et vinciantur funibus paupertatis.

verses.textEn: he will reveal to them their works, as well as their sinfulness, in that they were violent.
verses.textLa: Indicabit eis opera eorum, et scelera eorum, quia violenti fuerunt.

verses.textEn: Likewise, he will open their ears to his correction, and he will speak to them, so that they may return from iniquity.
verses.textLa: Revelabit quoque aurem eorum, ut corripiat: et loquetur, ut revertantur ab iniquitate.

verses.textEn: If they listen and obey, they will fill their days with goodness and complete their years in glory.
verses.textLa: Si audierint et observaverint, complebunt dies suos in bono, et annos suos in gloria:
verses.notes: The word ‘complebunt’ can mean to fill or to complete. The verse is translated somewhat loosely, such that both meanings are used: fill up their days and complete their years.

verses.textEn: But if they will not listen, they will pass away by the sword and will be consumed by foolishness.
verses.textLa: Si autem non audierint, transibunt per gladium, et consumentur in stultitia.

verses.textEn: The false and the crafty provoke the wrath of God, yet they do not cry out to him when they are chained.
verses.textLa: Simulatores et callidi provocant iram Dei, neque clamabunt cum vincti fuerint.
verses.notes: The word ‘clamabunt’ means to cry out or to call on the name of someone; in this context, it means that they will not cry out to God, even when they are in chains.

verses.textEn: Their soul will die in a storm, and their life, among the unmanly.
verses.textLa: Morietur in tempestate anima eorum, et vita eorum inter effeminatos.

verses.textEn: He will rescue the poor from his anguish, and he will open his ear during tribulation.
verses.textLa: Eripiet de angustia sua pauperem, et revelabit in tribulatione aurem eius.

verses.textEn: Therefore, he will save you from the narrow mouth very widely, even though it has no foundation under it. Moreover, your respite at table will be full of fatness.
verses.textLa: Igitur salvabit te de ore angusto latissime, et non habente fundamentum subter se: requies autem mensæ tuæ erit plena pinguedine.
verses.notes:
There is a play on words here: ‘he will save you from the narrow mouth very widely....’ The mouth of oppression is narrow (hard to escape from), but the salvation from God is very wide (easy to obtain). This play on words is lost if the verse is translated less literally: ‘he will save you from oppression very abundantly....’
 The meaning of this verse is obscure. God will save you from an oppression that is hard to escape from. He will do so very widely (perhaps this means geographically, i.e. over all the earth; or perhaps it means that it will be a wide road, i.e. an easy to follow salvation). And God will save without regard to the lack of foundation under ‘it,’ referring to the salvation, i.e. it will seem as if that by which God saves has no dependable foundation.
 The last part of the verse means that, during the respite that follows, you will have abundance (fatness) at your table. The literal translation would be ‘and the respite of your table will be full of fatness.’ But the meaning is that both the respite and the table are ‘yours.’ So the verse can also be correctly translated as: ‘and your respite at table....’

verses.textEn: Your case has been judged like that of the impious; you will withdraw your plea and your judgment.
verses.textLa: Causa tua quasi impii iudicata est, causam iudiciumque recipies.

verses.textEn: Therefore, do not let anger overwhelm you so that you oppress another; neither should you allow a multitude of gifts to influence you.
verses.textLa: Non te ergo superet ira, ut aliquem opprimas: nec multitudo donorum inclinet te.

verses.textEn: Lay down your greatness without distress, and put aside all of your power with courage.
verses.textLa: Depone magnitudinem tuam absque tribulatione, et omnes robustos fortitudine.
verses.notes: The last phrase is a play off of the first phrase; it could be reworded this way: ‘lay down your greatness and all of your power, with courage and without distress.’

verses.textEn: Do not prolong the night, even if people rise on their behalf.
verses.textLa: Ne protrahas noctem, ut ascendant populi pro eis.

verses.textEn: Be careful that you do not turn to iniquity; for, after your misery, you have begun to follow this.
verses.textLa: Cave ne declines ad iniquitatem: hanc enim cœpisti sequi post miseriam.

verses.textEn: Behold, God is exalted in his strength, and there is no one like him among the law-givers.
verses.textLa: Ecce, Deus excelsus in fortitudine sua, et nullus ei similis in legislatoribus.

verses.textEn: Who is able to investigate his ways? And who can say, “You have done iniquity,” to him?
verses.textLa: Quis poterit scrutari vias eius? aut quis potest ei dicere: Operatus es iniquitatem?

verses.textEn: Remember that you are ignorant of his work, yet men have sung its praises.
verses.textLa: Memento quod ignores opus eius, de quo cecinerunt viri.
verses.notes: This last phrase is translated strictly as ‘about which men have sung;’ but it can be better translated more loosely as ‘yet men have sung its praises.’

verses.textEn: All men consider him; and each one ponders from a distance.
verses.textLa: Omnes homines vident eum, unusquisque intuetur procul.

verses.textEn: Behold, God is great, defeating our knowledge; the number of his years is inestimable.
verses.textLa: Ecce, Deus magnus vincens scientiam nostram: numerus annorum eius inæstimabilis.

verses.textEn: He carries away the drops of rain, and he sends forth showers like a raging whirlpool;
verses.textLa: Qui aufert stillas pluviæ, et effundit imbres ad instar gurgitum.

verses.textEn: they flow from the clouds that are woven above everything.
verses.textLa: Qui de nubibus fluunt, quæ prætexunt cuncta desuper.

verses.textEn: If he wills it, he extends the clouds as his tent
verses.textLa: Si voluerit extendere nubes quasi tentorium suum,

verses.textEn: and shines with his light from above; likewise, he covers the oceans within his tent.
verses.textLa: Et fulgurare lumine suo desuper, cardines quoque maris operiet.
verses.notes: The word ‘cardines’ here refers back to the previous verse, speaking about the clouds as God’s tent. The phrase means that even the oceans are under God’s Providence, or under the limits of his tent.

verses.textEn: For he judges the people by these things, and he gives food to a multitude of mortals.
verses.textLa: Per hæc enim iudicat populos, et dat escas multis mortalibus.

verses.textEn: Within his hands, he hides the light, and he commands it to come forth again.
verses.textLa: In manibus abscondit lucem, et præcepit ei ut rursus adveniat.

verses.textEn: He announces it to his friend, for it is his possession and he is able to reach out to it.
verses.textLa: Annunciat de ea amico suo, quod possessio eius sit, et ad eam possit ascendere.

verses.textEn: At this, my heart became frightened, and it has been moved from its place.
verses.textLa: Super hoc expavit cor meum, et emotum est de loco suo.

verses.textEn: Pay close attention to the alarm of his voice and to the sound that proceeds from his mouth.
verses.textLa: Audite auditionem in terrore vocis eius, et sonum de ore illius procedentem.

verses.textEn: He beholds everything under the heavens, and his light reaches beyond the ends of the earth.
verses.textLa: Subter omnes cælos ipse considerat, et lumen illius super terminos terræ.

verses.textEn: After this, a noise will sound; he will thunder with the voice of his greatness, and it will not be tracked down, yet his voice will be obeyed.
verses.textLa: Post eum rugiet sonitus, tonabit voce magnitudinis suæ, et non investigabitur, cum audita fuerit vox eius.

verses.textEn: God will thunder with his voice miraculously, for he performs great and unsearchable things.
verses.textLa: Tonabit Deus in voce sua mirabiliter, qui facit magna et inscrutabilia.

verses.textEn: He commands the snow to descend on earth, and the winter rains, and the shower of his strength.
verses.textLa: Qui præcipit nivi ut descendat in terram, et hiemis pluviis, et imbri fortitudinis suæ.

verses.textEn: He signs the hand of all men, so that each one may know his works.
verses.textLa: Qui in manu omnium hominum signat, ut noverint singuli opera sua.

verses.textEn: The beast will enter his hiding-place, and he will remain in his cave.
verses.textLa: Ingredietur bestia latibulum, et in antro suo morabitur.

verses.textEn: From the interior, a storm will come forth, and a cold winter from the north.
verses.textLa: Ab interioribus egredietur tempestas, et ab Arcturo frigus.

verses.textEn: As God breathes out, frost forms, and the waters are poured forth very widely again.
verses.textLa: Flante Deo concrescit gelu, et rursum latissimæ funduntur aquæ.

verses.textEn: Crops desire clouds, and the clouds scatter their light.
verses.textLa: Frumentum desiderat nubes, et nubes spargunt lumen suum.

verses.textEn: It shines all around, wherever the will of him that governs them will lead, to anywhere he will command, over the whole face of the earth,
verses.textLa: Quæ lustrant per circuitum, quocumque eas voluntas gubernantis duxerit, ad omne quod præceperit illis super faciem orbis terrarum:

verses.textEn: whether in one tribe, or in his own region, or in whatever place of his mercy that he will order them to be found.
verses.textLa: Sive in una tribu, sive in terra sua, sive in quocumque loco misericordiæ suæ eas iusserit inveniri.

verses.textEn: Listen to these things, Job. Stand up and consider the wonders of God.
verses.textLa: Ausculta hæc Iob: sta, et considera mirabilia Dei.

verses.textEn: Do you know when God ordered the rains, so as to show the light of his clouds?
verses.textLa: Numquid scis quando præceperit Deus pluviis, ut ostenderent lucem nubium eius?

verses.textEn: Do you know the great paths of the clouds, and the perfect sciences?
verses.textLa: Numquid nosti semitas nubium magnas, et perfectas scientias?
verses.notes: The phrase ‘perfectas scientias’ is probably an idiomatic expression referring to a particular field of knowledge. Consider the English expression ‘the sweet science,’ which refers to boxing. It does not refer to sweet flavor, nor to a science properly speaking. Similarly, the ‘perfect sciences’ or ‘perfect areas of knowledge’ is most likely a figure of speech referring to a field of study, such as the study of weather, and perhaps also the study of the night sky, i.e. of the sun, moon, planets, and stars.

verses.textEn: Are not your garments hot, when the south wind blows across the land?
verses.textLa: Nonne vestimenta tua calida sunt, cum perflata fuerit terra Austro?

verses.textEn: Perhaps you have made the heavens with him, which are very solid, as if they had been cast from brass.
verses.textLa: Tu forsitan cum eo fabricatus es cælos, qui solidissimi quasi ære fusi sunt.

verses.textEn: Reveal to us what we should say to him, for, of course, we are wrapped in darkness.
verses.textLa: Ostende nobis quid dicamus illi: nos quippe involvimur tenebris.
verses.notes: This verse is a clear example of the use of sarcasm in Scripture. Eliu is taunting Job by saying sarcastically that they would all be wrapped in darkness if not for the wisdom of Job. Interestingly, on another level, this sarcastic statement by Eliu is true. Job does present wisdom, not in the error that he makes by blaming God, but by the example of his life and his repentance (later in the text) and by the book of Scripture that we have in his name.

verses.textEn: Who will explain to him the things that I am saying? Even while a man is still speaking, he will be devoured.
verses.textLa: Quis narrabit ei quæ loquor? etiam si locutus fuerit homo, devorabitur.

verses.textEn: Although they do not see the light, the air will be thickened suddenly into clouds, and the wind, passing by, will drive them away.
verses.textLa: At nunc non vident lucem: subito aer cogetur in nubes, et ventus transiens fugabit eas.

verses.textEn: Riches arrive from the north, and fearful praise reaches out to God.
verses.textLa: Ab Aquilone aurum venit, et ad Deum formidolosa laudatio.
verses.notes:
Literally: “Gold comes from the north, and to God (comes) fearful praise.” But ‘aurum’ can be used figuratively to refer to riches or wealth. Also, the implication is that fearful praise reaches out to God, when riches come from the North. “When riches arrive from the North, give fearful praise to God,” or “Riches arrive from the north, and fearful praise arrives before God.”
 This verse refers to the time of the Antichrist; when he arrives in the kingdom of the South (the Middle East, including Israel), he brings great wealth with him. This marks the start of a fearful time, for which we must still praise God because it is the time predicted in Scripture, the time before the return of the True Christ.

verses.textEn: We are not worthy to be able to find him. Great in strength, great in judgment, great in justice: he is indescribable.
verses.textLa: Digne eum invenire non possumus: magnus fortitudine, et iudicio, et iustitia et enarrari non potest.
verses.notes: Literally: “We are not able to find him worthily. Great in strength, and in judgment, and in justice, and he is not able to be described.”

verses.textEn: Therefore, men will fear him, and all those who seem to themselves to be wise, will not dare to contemplate him.
verses.textLa: Ideo timebunt eum viri, et non audebunt contemplari omnes, qui sibi videntur esse sapientes.

verses.textEn: But the Lord, responding to Job from a whirlwind, said:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Dominus Iob de turbine, dixit:

verses.textEn: Who is this that wraps sentences in unskilled words?
verses.textLa: Quis est iste involvens sententias sermonibus imperitis?

verses.textEn: Gird your waist like a man. I will question you, and you must answer me.
verses.textLa: Accinge sicut vir lumbos tuos: interrogabo te, et responde mihi.

verses.textEn: Where were you, when I set the foundations of the earth? Tell me, if you have understanding.
verses.textLa: Ubi eras quando ponebam fundamenta terræ? indica mihi si habes intelligentiam.

verses.textEn: Who set its measurements, if you know, or who stretched a line over it?
verses.textLa: Quis posuit mensuras eius, si nosti? vel quis tetendit super eam lineam?

verses.textEn: Upon what have its bases been grounded, and who set forth its cornerstone,
verses.textLa: Super quo bases illius solidatæ sunt? aut quis demisit lapidem angularem eius,

verses.textEn: when the morning stars praised me together, and all the sons of God made a joyful noise?
verses.textLa: Cum me laudarent simul astra matutina, et iubilarent omnes filii Dei?

verses.textEn: Who enclosed the sea with doors, when it broke forth as if issuing from the womb,
verses.textLa: Quis conclusit ostiis mare, quando erumpebat quasi de vulva procedens:

verses.textEn: when I stationed a cloud as its garment and wrapped it in a mist as if swaddling an infant?
verses.textLa: Cum ponerem nubem vestimentum eius, et caligine illud quasi pannis infantiæ obvolverem?
verses.notes: Literally, the first part reads: ‘When I set its cloudy garment....” As for the last part, some translations ignore the word infant, in favor of calling it ‘swaddling bands.’

verses.textEn: I encircled it with my limits, and I positioned its bars and doors.
verses.textLa: Circumdedi illud terminis meis, et posui vectem, et ostia:

verses.textEn: And I said: “This far you will approach, and you will proceed no further, and here you will break your swelling waves.”
verses.textLa: Et dixi: Usque huc venies, et non procedes amplius, et hic confringes tumentes fluctus tuos.

verses.textEn: Did you, after your birth, command the birth of the sun and show the sunrise its place?
verses.textLa: Numquid post ortum tuum præcepisti diluculo, et ostendisti auroræ locum suum?
verses.notes: There is a play on words in Latin here. The word ‘ortum’ can refer to birth or to daybreak. The verse compares one’s birth to the sunrise (the daily birth of the sun).

verses.textEn: And did you hold the extremities of the earth, shaking them, and have you shaken the impious out of it?
verses.textLa: Et tenuisti concutiens extrema terræ, et excussisti impios ex ea?

verses.textEn: The seal will be restored like clay, and it will remain in place like a garment.
verses.textLa: Restituetur ut lutum signaculum, et stabit sicut vestimentum:

verses.textEn: From the impious, the light will be taken away, and the exalted arm will be broken.
verses.textLa: Auferetur ab impiis lux sua, et brachium excelsum confringetur.

verses.textEn: Have you entered the depths of the sea, and have you taken a walk in the uttermost parts of the abyss?
verses.textLa: Numquid ingressus es profunda maris, et in novissimis abyssi deambulasti?

verses.textEn: Have the gates of death been opened to you, and have you seen the doors of darkness?
verses.textLa: Numquid apertæ sunt tibi portæ mortis, et ostia tenebrosa vidisti?
verses.notes: In the phrase ‘ostia tenebrosa,’ the word ‘tenebrosa’ is not genitive in case, so a literal translation would be ‘dark doors’ or ‘gloomy doors.’ But a better translation changes the case of the word ‘tenebrosa’ to genitive: ‘the doors of darkness’ or ‘the doors of the darkness.’

verses.textEn: Have you considered the breadth of the earth? If you know all things, reveal them to me.
verses.textLa: Numquid considerasti latitudinem terræ? indica mihi, si nosti, omnia.

verses.textEn: Which is the way that holds the light, and which is the place of darkness?
verses.textLa: In qua via lux habitet, et tenebrarum quis locus sit:

verses.textEn: In this way, you might lead each thing to its final place, and understand the paths of its house.
verses.textLa: Ut ducas unumquodque ad terminos suos, et intelligas semitas domus eius.

verses.textEn: So then, did you know when you were to be born? And did you know the number of your days?
verses.textLa: Sciebas tunc quod nasciturus esses? et numerum dierum tuorum noveras?

verses.textEn: Have you been admitted into the storehouses of the snows, and have you gazed upon the stockpile of the brimstone,
verses.textLa: Numquid ingressus es thesauros nivis, aut thesauros grandinis aspexisti,

verses.textEn: which I have prepared for the time of the enemy, for the day of the battle and the war?
verses.textLa: Quæ præparavi in tempus hostis, in diem pugnæ et belli?

verses.textEn: In what way is the light scattered, and the heat distributed, over the earth?
verses.textLa: Per quam viam spargitur lux, dividitur æstus super terram?

verses.textEn: Who gave a course to the rainstorms, and a path to the resounding thunder,
verses.textLa: Quis dedit vehementissimo imbri cursum, et viam sonantis tonitrui,

verses.textEn: so that it would rain on the earth far from man, in the wilderness where no mortal lingers,
verses.textLa: Ut plueret super terram absque homine in deserto, ubi nullus mortalium commoratur,

verses.textEn: so that it would fill impassable and desolate places, and would bring forth green plants?
verses.textLa: Ut impleret inviam et desolatam, et produceret herbas virentes?

verses.textEn: Who is the father of rain, or who conceived the drops of dew?
verses.textLa: Quis est pluviæ pater? vel quis genuit stillas roris?

verses.textEn: From whose womb did the ice proceed, and who created the frost from the air?
verses.textLa: De cuius utero egressa est glacies? et gelu de cælo quis genuit?
verses.notes: The word ‘utero’ in Latin does not simply mean ‘womb.’ It is often used to refer to men as well as to women. It is often translated, for men, as ‘belly’ or ‘abdomen.’ However, it has another possible meaning that is not often recognized. It can refer to the generative capability in either a man or a woman, in other words, to the ability to procreate (to conceive a child). In this verse, the word ‘utero’ is used figuratively to refer to God’s ability to create: ‘From whose ability-to-create did the ice proceed?’ Similarly, the word ‘genuit,’ often translated as ‘begot,’ in this context refers instead to God’s ability to create.

verses.textEn: The waters are hardened to become like stone, and the surface of the abyss freezes over.
verses.textLa: In similitudinem lapidis aquæ durantur, et superficies abyssi constringitur.

verses.textEn: Will you have the strength to join together the sparkling stars of the Pleiades, or are you able to disperse the circling of Arcturus?
verses.textLa: Numquid coniungere valebis micantes stellas Pleiadas, aut gyrum Arcturi poteris dissipare?

verses.textEn: Can you bring forth the morning star, in its time, and make the evening star rise over the sons of the earth?
verses.textLa: Numquid producis Luciferum in tempore suo, et Vesperum super filios terræ consurgere facis?

verses.textEn: Do you know the order of heaven, and can you explain its rules here on the earth?
verses.textLa: Numquid nosti ordinem cæli, et pones rationem eius in terra?

verses.textEn: Can you lift up your voice to the clouds, so that an onslaught of waters will cover you?
verses.textLa: Numquid elevabis in nebula vocem tuam, et impetus aquarum operiet te?

verses.textEn: Can you send forth lightning bolts, and will they go, and on returning, say to you: “Here we are?”
verses.textLa: Numquid mittes fulgura, et ibunt, et revertentia dicent tibi: Adsumus?

verses.textEn: Who placed discernment in the guts of man, or who gave the rooster intelligence?
verses.textLa: Quis posuit in visceribus hominis sapientiam? vel quis dedit gallo intelligentiam?

verses.textEn: Who can describe the rules of the heavens, or who can put to rest the harmony of heaven?
verses.textLa: Quis enarrabit cælorum rationem, et concentum cæli quis dormire faciet?

verses.textEn: When was the dust cast to become the earth, and when were its clods fastened together?
verses.textLa: Quando fundebatur pulvis in terra, et glebæ compingebantur?

verses.textEn: Will you seize prey for the lioness, and will you sustain the lives of her young,
verses.textLa: Numquid capies leænæ prædam, et animam catulorum eius implebis,

verses.textEn: as they rest in their dens or lie in wait in pits?
verses.textLa: Quando cubant in antris, et in specubus insidiantur?

verses.textEn: Who provides the raven with its meal, when her chicks cry out to God, as they wander around because they have no food?
verses.textLa: Quis præparat corvo escam suam, quando pulli eius clamant ad Deum, vagantes, eo quod non habeant cibos?

verses.textEn: Do you know at what time the wild goats have given birth among the rocks, or do you observe the deer when they go into labor?
verses.textLa: Numquid nosti tempus partus ibicum in petris, vel parturientes cervas observasti?

verses.textEn: Have you numbered the months since their conception, and do you know at what time they gave birth?
verses.textLa: Dinumerasti menses conceptus earum, et scisti tempus partus earum?

verses.textEn: They bend themselves for their offspring, and they give birth, and they emit roars.
verses.textLa: Incurvantur ad fœtum, et pariunt, et rugitus emittunt.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘Incurvantur ad fœtum’ literally means ‘they bend to the prenatal,’ i.e. that they bend or bow their bodies while giving birth. The phrase ‘et pariunt, et rugitus’ is an interesting play on words. They send forth their young (in giving birth) and then they send forth their roars.

verses.textEn: Their young are weaned and go out to feed; they depart and do not return to them.
verses.textLa: Separantur filii earum, et pergunt ad pastum: egrediuntur, et non revertuntur ad eas.

verses.textEn: Who has set the wild ass free, and who has released his bonds?
verses.textLa: Quis dimisit onagrum liberum, et vincula eius quis solvit?

verses.textEn: I have given a house in solitude to him, and his tabernacle is in the salted land.
verses.textLa: Cui dedi in solitudine domum, et tabernacula eius in terra salsuginis.

verses.textEn: He despises the crowded city; he does not pay attention to the bellow of the tax collector.
verses.textLa: Contemnit multitudinem civitatis, clamorem exactoris non audit.
verses.notes: The context of this verse is the previous description of the wild animals governed by God. It can also be taken to describe holy persons who choose to live apart from the crowds and noise of secular society. The word ‘clamorem’ is translated as ‘bellow’ because that word has a dual meaning; it refers to the loud noise of wild animals, or also to a loud noise made by a human being. The phrase ‘multitudinem civitatis’ literally means ‘the multitude of the city,’ but it is better translated loosely as ‘the crowded city.’

verses.textEn: He looks around the mountains of his pasture, and he searches everywhere for green plants.
verses.textLa: Circumspicit montes pascuæ suæ, et virentia quæque perquirit.

verses.textEn: Will the rhinoceros be willing to serve you, and will he remain in your stall?
verses.textLa: Numquid volet rhinoceros servire tibi, aut morabitur ad præsepe tuum?

verses.textEn: Can you detain the rhinoceros with your harness to plough for you, and will he loosen the soil of the furrows behind you?
verses.textLa: Numquid alligabis rhinocerota ad arandum loro tuo? aut confringet glebas vallium post te?

verses.textEn: Will you put your faith in his great strength, and delegate your labors to him?
verses.textLa: Numquid fiduciam habebis in magna fortitudine eius, et derelinques ei labores tuos?

verses.textEn: Will you trust him to return to you the seed, and to gather it on your drying floor?
verses.textLa: Numquid credes illi quod sementem reddat tibi, et aream tuam congreget?

verses.textEn: The wing of the ostrich is like the wings of the heron, and of the hawk.
verses.textLa: Penna struthionis similis est pennis herodii, et accipitris.

verses.textEn: When she leaves eggs behind in the earth, will you perhaps warm them in the dust?
verses.textLa: Quando derelinquit ova sua in terra, tu forsitan in pulvere calefacies ea?

verses.textEn: She forgets that feet may trample them, or that the beasts of the field may shatter them.
verses.textLa: Obliviscitur quod pes conculcet ea, aut bestia agri conterat.

verses.textEn: She is hardened against her young, as if they were not hers; she has labored in vain, with no fear compelling her.
verses.textLa: Duratur ad filios suos quasi non sint sui, frustra laboravit nullo timore cogente.

verses.textEn: For God has deprived her of wisdom; neither has he given her understanding.
verses.textLa: Privavit enim eam Deus sapientia, nec dedit illi intelligentiam.

verses.textEn: Yet, when the time is right, she raises her wings on high; she ridicules the horse and his rider.
verses.textLa: Cum tempus fuerit, in altum alas erigit: deridet equum et ascensorem eius.

verses.textEn: Will you supply strength to the horse, or envelope his throat with neighing?
verses.textLa: Numquid præbebis equo fortitudinem, aut circumdabis collo eius hinnitum?

verses.textEn: Will you alarm him as the locusts do? His panic is revealed by the display of his nostrils.
verses.textLa: Numquid suscitabis eum quasi locustas? gloria narium eius terror.

verses.textEn: He digs at the earth with his hoof; he jumps around boldly; he advances to meet armed men.
verses.textLa: Terram ungula fodit, exultat audacter: in occursum pergit armatis.

verses.textEn: He despises fear; he does not turn away from the sword.
verses.textLa: Contemnit pavorem, nec cedit gladio.

verses.textEn: Above him, the quiver rattles, the spear and the shield shake.
verses.textLa: Super ipsum sonabit pharetra, vibrabit hasta et clypeus.

verses.textEn: Seething and raging, he drinks up the earth; neither does he pause when the blast of the trumpet sounds.
verses.textLa: Fervens et fremens sorbet terram, nec reputat tubæ sonare clangorem.

verses.textEn: When he hears the bugle, he says, “Ha!” He smells the battle from a distance, the exhortation of the officers, and the battle cry of the soldiers.
verses.textLa: Ubi audierit buccinam, dicit: Vah, procul odoratur bellum, exhortationem ducum, et ululatum exercitus.

verses.textEn: Does the hawk grow feathers by means of your wisdom, spreading her wings towards the south?
verses.textLa: Numquid per sapientiam tuam plumescit accipiter, expandens alas suas ad Austrum?

verses.textEn: Will the eagle lift herself up at your command and make her nest in steep places?
verses.textLa: Numquid ad præceptum tuum elevabitur aquila, et in arduis ponet nidum suum?

verses.textEn: She dwells among the rocks, and she lingers among broken boulders and inaccessible cliffs.
verses.textLa: In petris manet, et in præruptis silicibus commoratur, atque inaccessis rupibus.

verses.textEn: From there, she looks for food, and her eyes catch sight of it from far away.
verses.textLa: Inde contemplatur escam, et de longe oculi eius prospiciunt,

verses.textEn: Her young will drink blood, and wherever the carcass will be, she is there immediately.
verses.textLa: Pulli eius lambent sanguinem: et ubicumque cadaver fuerit, statim adest.

verses.textEn: And the Lord continued, and he said to Job:
verses.textLa: Et adiecit Dominus, et locutus est ad Iob:

verses.textEn: Will he who contends with God be so easily silenced? Certainly, he who argues with God must also respond to him.
verses.textLa: Numquid qui contendit cum Deo, tam facile conquiescit? utique qui arguit Deum, debet respondere ei.

verses.textEn: Then Job answered the Lord, saying:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iob Domino, dixit:

verses.textEn: What could I possibly answer, since I have been speaking thoughtlessly? I will place my hand over my mouth.
verses.textLa: Qui leviter locutus sum, respondere quid possum? manum meam ponam super os meum.

verses.textEn: One thing I have spoken, which I wish I had not said; and another, to which I will add no more.
verses.textLa: Unum locutus sum, quod utinam non dixissem: et alterum, quibus ultra non addam.

verses.textEn: But the Lord, answering Job out of the whirlwind, said:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Dominus Iob de turbine, dixit:

verses.textEn: Gird your waist like a man. I will question you, and you must answer me.
verses.textLa: Accinge sicut vir lumbos tuos: interrogabo te: et indica mihi.

verses.textEn: Will you make my judgment null and void; and will you condemn me so that you may be justified?
verses.textLa: Numquid irritum facies iudicium meum: et condemnabis me, ut te iustificeris?

verses.textEn: And do you have an arm like God, or a voice like thunder?
verses.textLa: Et si habes brachium sicut Deus, et si voce simili tonas?

verses.textEn: Envelop yourself with splendor, and raise yourself up on high, and be glorious, and put on splendid garments.
verses.textLa: Circumda tibi decorem, et in sublime erigere, et esto gloriosus, et speciosis induere vestibus.

verses.textEn: Scatter the arrogant with your wrath, and, when you see all the arrogant, humble them.
verses.textLa: Disperge superbos in furore tuo, et respiciens omnem arrogantem humilia.

verses.textEn: Look down upon each of the arrogant and confound them, and crush the impious in their place.
verses.textLa: Respice cunctos superbos, et confunde eos, et contere impios in loco suo.

verses.textEn: Hide them in the dust together and plunge their faces into the pit.
verses.textLa: Absconde eos in pulvere simul, et facies eorum demerge in foveam:

verses.textEn: Then I will confess that your right hand is able to save you.
verses.textLa: Et ego confitebor quod salvare te possit dextera tua.

verses.textEn: Behold, the behemoth, whom I created along with you, eats hay like an ox.
verses.textLa: Ecce, Behemoth, quem feci tecum, fœnum quasi bos comedet:

verses.textEn: His strength is in his lower back, and his power is in the center of his abdomen.
verses.textLa: Fortitudo eius in lumbis eius, et virtus illius in umbilico ventris eius.

verses.textEn: He draws up his tail like a cedar; the sinews of his thighs have been drawn together.
verses.textLa: Stringit caudam suam quasi cedrum, nervi testiculorum eius perplexi sunt.

verses.textEn: His bones are like pipes of brass; his cartilage is like plates of iron.
verses.textLa: Ossa eius velut fistulæ æris, cartilago illius quasi laminæ ferreæ.

verses.textEn: He is the beginning of the ways of God, who made him; he will use him as his sword.
verses.textLa: Ipse est principium viarum Dei, qui fecit eum, applicabit gladium eius.

verses.textEn: The mountains bring forth grass for him; all the beasts of the field will play there.
verses.textLa: Huic montes herbas ferunt: omnes bestiæ agri ludent ibi.

verses.textEn: He sleeps in the shadows, under the cover of branches, and in moist places.
verses.textLa: Sub umbra dormit in secreto calami, et in locis humentibus.

verses.textEn: The shadows cover his shadow; the willows of the brook will encircle him.
verses.textLa: Protegunt umbræ umbram eius, circumdabunt eum salices torrentis.

verses.textEn: Behold, he will drink a river and not be amazed, and he has confidence that the Jordan could flow into his mouth.
verses.textLa: Ecce, absorbebit fluvium, et non mirabitur: et habet fiduciam quod influat Iordanis in os eius.

verses.textEn: He will seize him through his eyes, as if with a hook, and he will bore through his nostrils, as if with stakes.
verses.textLa: In oculis eius quasi hamo capiet eum, et in sudibus perforabit nares eius.

verses.textEn: Can you draw out the leviathan with a hook, and can you bind his tongue with a cord?
verses.textLa: An extrahere poteris leviathan hamo, et fune ligabis linguam eius?

verses.textEn: Can you place a ring in his nose, or bore through his jaw with an arm band?
verses.textLa: Numquid pones circulum in naribus eius, aut armilla perforabis maxillam eius?

verses.textEn: Will he offer many prayers to you, or speak to you quietly?
verses.textLa: Numquid multiplicabit ad te preces, aut loquetur tibi mollia?

verses.textEn: Will he form a covenant with you, and will you accept him as a servant forever?
verses.textLa: Numquid feriet tecum pactum, et accipies eum servum sempiternum?

verses.textEn: Will you play with him as with a bird, or tether him for your handmaids?
verses.textLa: Numquid illudes ei quasi avi, aut ligabis eum ancillis tuis?

verses.textEn: Will your friends cut him into pieces, will dealers distribute him?
verses.textLa: Concident eum amici, divident illum negotiatores?

verses.textEn: Will you fill up bags with his hide, and let his head be used as a home for fishes?
verses.textLa: Numquid implebis sagenas pelle eius, et gurgustium piscium capite illius?

verses.textEn: Place your hand upon him; remember the battle and speak no more.
verses.textLa: Pone super eum manum tuam: memento belli, nec ultra addas loqui.

verses.textEn: Behold, his hope will fail him, and in the sight of all, he will be thrown down.
verses.textLa: Ecce, spes eius frustrabitur eum, et videntibus cunctis præcipitabitur.

verses.textEn: I will not rouse him, as the cruel would do, for who is able to withstand my countenance?
verses.textLa: Non quasi crudelis suscitabo eum: quis enim resistere potest vultui meo?

verses.textEn: Who has given to me beforehand, so that I should repay him? All things that are under heaven are mine.
verses.textLa: Quis ante dedit mihi, ut reddam ei? omnia quæ sub cælo sunt, mea sunt.

verses.textEn: I will not spare him, nor his powerful words and counterfeit attempts at supplication.
verses.textLa: Non parcam ei, et verbis potentibus, et ad deprecandum compositis.
verses.notes: Or, ‘I will not be lenient to him, nor to his strong words and fabrications aimed at appeasement.’

verses.textEn: Who can reveal the beauty of his garment? And who can enter the middle of his mouth?
verses.textLa: Quis revelabit faciem indumenti eius? et in medium oris eius quis intrabit?

verses.textEn: Who can open the doors of his face? I gave fear to the circle of his teeth.
verses.textLa: Portas vultus eius quis aperiet? per gyrum dentium eius formido.
verses.notes: This last phrase seems, if translated in an overly-literal manner, to say, ‘I am afraid of the circle of his teeth.’ But the context is that of God speaking about his creation. Therefore, the correct translation is that God has ‘placed fear in the circle of his teeth,’ or, ‘given dread to the circle of his teeth,’ or, ‘gave fear to the circle of his teeth.’

verses.textEn: His body is like shields fused together, like dense scales pressed over one another.
verses.textLa: Corpus illius quasi scuta fusilia, compactum squamis se prementibus.

verses.textEn: One is joined to another, and not even air can pass between them.
verses.textLa: Una uni coniungitur, et ne spiraculum quidem incedit per eas:

verses.textEn: They adhere to one another, and they hold themselves in place and will not be separated.
verses.textLa: Una alteri adhærebit, et tenentes se nequaquam separabuntur.

verses.textEn: His sneezing has the brilliance of fire, and his eyes are like the eyelids of the morning.
verses.textLa: Sternutatio eius splendor ignis, et oculi eius, ut palpebræ diluculi.

verses.textEn: Lamps proceed from his mouth, like torches of fire burning brightly.
verses.textLa: De ore eius lampades procedunt, sicut tædæ ignis accensæ.

verses.textEn: Smoke passes out of his nostrils, like a pot that is heated and boiling.
verses.textLa: De naribus eius procedit fumus, sicut ollæ succensæ atque ferventis.

verses.textEn: His breath causes coal to burn, and a flame comes forth from his mouth.
verses.textLa: Halitus eius prunas ardere facit, et flamma de ore eius egreditur.

verses.textEn: Strength dwells in his neck, and destitution goes before his presence.
verses.textLa: In collo eius morabitur fortitudo, et faciem eius præcedit egestas.
verses.notes:
Or, ‘In his neck strength will dwell, and extreme poverty precedes his face.’ Notice that ‘morabitur’ is future tense but can be translated just as well in the present tense in English.
 By the way, this passage about the Behemoth is a poetic and prophetic description of the beast described in the book of Revelation.

verses.textEn: The parts of his body work in harmony together. He will send lightning bolts against him, and they will not be carried to another place.
verses.textLa: Membra carnium eius cohærentia sibi: mittet contra eum fulmina, et ad locum alium non ferentur.
verses.notes: This first phrase could be translated as, ‘The parts of his body cling together.’ This refers to the different parts of the ‘body’ which is the Antichrist’s kingdom. The other possible translation, ‘The parts of his body work in harmony together,’ is more meaningful, both in the literal and the figurative connotations.

verses.textEn: His heart will be as hard as a stone and as dense as a blacksmith’s anvil.
verses.textLa: Cor eius indurabitur tamquam lapis, et stringetur quasi malleatoris incus.

verses.textEn: When he will be raised up, the angels will be afraid, and, because they are terrified, they will purify themselves.
verses.textLa: Cum sublatus fuerit, timebunt angeli, et territi purgabuntur.
verses.notes: Literally, the phrase is “being terrified,” but English is more likely to phrase it something like “because they are terrified.” This verse could refer to the attempted false ascension by the Antichrist near the end of his reign.

verses.textEn: When a sword catches up with him, it will not be able to settle in, nor a spear, nor a breastplate.
verses.textLa: Cum apprehenderit eum gladius, subsitere non poterit neque hasta, neque thorax:

verses.textEn: For he will consider iron as if it were chaff, and brass as if it were rotten wood.
verses.textLa: Reputabit enim quasi paleas ferrum, et quasi lignum putridum, æs.

verses.textEn: The archer will not cause him to flee; the stones of the sling have been turned into stubble for him.
verses.textLa: Non fugabit eum vir sagittarius, in stipulam versi sunt ei lapides fundæ.

verses.textEn: He will treat the hammer as if it were stubble, and he will ridicule those who brandish the spear.
verses.textLa: Quasi stipulam æstimabit malleum, et deridebit vibrantem hastam.

verses.textEn: The beams of the sun will be under him, and he will dispense gold to them as if it were clay.
verses.textLa: Sub ipso erunt radii solis, et sternet sibi aurum quasi lutum.

verses.textEn: He will make the depths of the sea boil like a pot, and he will set it to bubble just as ointments do.
verses.textLa: Fervescere faciet quasi ollam profundum mare, et ponet quasi cum unguenta bulliunt.

verses.textEn: A path will shine after him; he will esteem the abyss as if it were weakening with age.
verses.textLa: Post eum lucebit semita, æstimabit abyssum quasi senescentem.

verses.textEn: There is no power on the earth that is being compared to him, who has been made so that he fears no one.
verses.textLa: Non est super terram potestas, quæ comparetur ei, qui factus est ut nullum timeret.
verses.notes: Here again Scripture is referring to the Antichrist. The translation of ‘quæ comparetur ei’ should therefore be ‘that is being compared to him,’ rather than ‘can be compared to him.’ For Christ still dwells, even during that future evil time, in the world in the form of the Eucharist (rare though it is on earth at that time). So, the statement that nothing on earth is being compared to the Antichrist is a true statement, but the statement that nothing on earth can be compared to the Antichrist would be a false statement.

verses.textEn: He sees every prominent thing; he is king over all the sons of arrogance.
verses.textLa: Omne sublime videt, ipse est rex super universos filios superbiæ.
verses.notes: He is king over the entire group of arrogant persons, but he does not have power of kingship over each and every one individually. His power has its limits. He sees prominent things, but not lowly things.

verses.textEn: Then Job, responding to the Lord, said:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iob Domino, dixit:

verses.textEn: I know that you are able to do all things, and that no thoughts are hidden from you.
verses.textLa: Scio quia omnia potes, et nulla te latet cogitatio.

verses.textEn: So, who is it that would disguise a lack of knowledge as counsel? Therefore, I have been speaking foolishly, about things whose measure exceeds my knowledge.
verses.textLa: Quis est iste, qui celat consilium absque scientia? ideo insipienter locutus sum, et quæ ultra modum excederent scientiam meam.

verses.textEn: Listen, and I will speak. I will question you, and you may answer me.
verses.textLa: Audi, et ego loquar: interrogabo te, et responde mihi.

verses.textEn: By paying attention with the ear, I have heard you, but now my eye sees you.
verses.textLa: Auditu auris audivi te, nunc autem oculus meus videt te.

verses.textEn: Therefore, I find myself reprehensible, and I will do penance in embers and ashes.
verses.textLa: Idcirco ipse me reprehendo, et ago pœnitentiam in favilla et cinere.
